DEBATE.TITLE: REPRESENTATION OF NEW SOUTH WALES AND SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received through the Governor-General from the respective Governors the original certificate of the choice of the houses of the New South Wales Parliament of Senator George Campbell to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Bruce Childs and the original certificate of appointment of the Governor of South Australia of John Andrew Quirke to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Dominic Foreman. I table the documents.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production: irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of Senate assembled:

That we are opposed to the unfair and inequitable assessment of AUSTUDY eligibility through the implementation of the new (and recently revised) regulations pertaining to the Actual Means Test and the raising of the age of independence for student income support to 25. We believe that AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY benefits play a vital role in ensuring a broadly accessible higher education system, which is in turn fundamental to efforts in creating a more just and equitable society.
In particular, the Actual Means Test and raised age of independence have the effect of:

PARA.TAB: forcing students to become reliant on their parents and families for support during their studies despite their family's capacity or willingness to perform this role;
reducing access to higher education for people from disadvantaged backgrounds;
further shifting the cost of higher education from the public realm into the private domain;
further complicating the AUSTUDY application process thereby deterring students from applying; and
forcing some students out of study or into dire poverty in order to continue their studies.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate lower the age of independence for AUSTUDY to 18, to entirely revoke the ill‐considered and inequitable Actual Means Test and raise AUSTUDY benefits to a level above the poverty line.

PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promoted Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Paper
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned that 14 overseas countries are allegedly dumping paper into the Australian market putting at risk up to 1,000 Coastal jobs and the loss of tens of millions of dollars to the local North West economy.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate do everything in its power to stop this paper dumping and protect the jobs of 1,000 Tasmanians from unfair foreign competitors.

25 June 1997
Senator the Hon. Robert Hill
Minister for the Environment
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 96 which provide enforcement provisions in relation to the Shoalwater Bay (Dugong) Plan of Management.

Regulation 56 provides penalties for the breach of specified provisions of the Shoalwater Bay (Dugong) Plan of Management. However, the regulation places the burden of proof on to the defendant. Although the Explanatory Statement provides detailed information on the background of the regulations, it does not explain why it was necessary to reverse the burden of proof. The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
28 August 1997
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 25 June 1997 (your ref cttee/101/97) regarding the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No. 96 and to your notice of motion on 25 June 1997 in the Senate regarding these Regulations.

At the outset I wish to say that it was never the intention of the Government or the Marine Park Authority to have the onus of proof in these Regulations reversed and that is the reason no references are made to that issue in the Explanatory Statement. Advice from the Attorney‐General's Department during drafting identified that the drafting of the provisions in the manner presented in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 96 could avoid the possibility of the offence provision being construed as reversing the onus of proof.

On further consideration however, it now appears that the provisions of ss.14 and 15D of the Crimes Act 1914 (which already provide for a statutory reversal of the onus of proof in certain circumstances) are applicable and can not be reversed by Regulations. I have therefore directed that r. 56(2) of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations be repealed as soon as practicable. Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
Robert Hill
Minister

Motion (by Senator Stott Despoja) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Privacy Act 1988 to extend the application of the act to the private sector, expand the number and coverage of the Information Privacy Principles, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Stott Despoja) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

BREAK.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: At the last election, the Coalition stated that the "Coalition regards personal privacy as a cherished right in a free society" (On‐line Policy Statement, Coalition Election Papers, 1996) and that the Government would "work with industry and the States to provide a co‐regulatory approach to privacy within the private sector in Australia, comparable with best international practice" (Law and Justice Policy Statement, Coalition Election Papers, 1996). This commitment seemed to be in place when the Attorney General launched a Discussion Paper on 12 September 1996 saying "Privacy protection will be enhanced for all Australians with the extension of the Privacy Act 1988 (the Act) to the private sector. . . I intend to be in a position to develop legislation for introduction next year" (Attorney General and Justice Minister, Press Release 142, 12 September 1996).

The Discussion Paper released by the Attorney General set out a scheme based on the existing Information Privacy Principles in the Privacy Act 1988 and met many of the concerns of consumers. In essence this was a proposal for industry codes of practice supervised by the Privacy Commissioner and subject to statutory backing—a co‐regulatory approach. This scheme would have been consistent with the schemes adopted by New Zealand, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the European Union.

Then, on 21 March 1997, the Prime Minister did a "backflip". He stated: "I took the opportunity of today's Premiers Conference to raise the Commonwealth's concern's regarding proposals to implement a privacy regime for the private sector. . . The Commonwealth will not be implementing privacy legislation for the private sector" (Prime Minister, Press Release, 21 March 1997). That was it. . . the end of Australia's international best practice privacy scheme and another election promise broken.

Privacy protection needs to extend to the collection, storage, security, access, correction, use, destruction and disclosure of all personal information. The present legislative scheme set out in the Privacy Act 1988 addresses the collection, storage, use and disclosure of personal information held by the Commonwealth Government. This scheme also extends to credit reporting, some telecommunications suppliers and operators and a limited number of other circumstances. This scheme does not otherwise extend to the private sector.

The Australian Democrats believe personal information should be protected through a comprehen sive national legislative scheme. This should be a strong, enforceable privacy protection which covers both the public and the private sectors with powers vested in an independent body to investigate and enforce its decisions based on clear principles of what constitutes a breach. The proposed amendments to the Privacy Act 1988 set out in the Privacy Amendment Bill 1997 (the Bill) will address this intention in a scheme where industry is either covered by legislated privacy principles or develops its own codes of practice with the co‐operation of the Privacy Commissioner and subject to approval by the Parliament. The privacy principles and codes of practice maintain a comprehensive and enforceable privacy protection with powers conferred on the Privacy Commissioner which are similar to those presently set out in the Privacy Act 1988.

This bill extends the definition of "agency" to include all persons (including unincorporated bodies) who would be covered by the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and in particular Article 17 of that Covenant, corporations and trading corporations and financial corporations. However, acts or practices which are done for personal or family reasons, household affairs or journalistic, literary or artistic purposes are not covered. Other amendments are made which are directed at including codes of practice into the operation of the act in its present structure and application.

New Information Privacy Principles are added which cover areas of justifiable purpose, limiting the retention of information, maintaining anonymity and unique identifiers. In the absence of codes of practice these principles will apply to all agencies.

Where an identified grouping generally, a specified person, a specified class of persons, a specified agency, industry, profession or calling or a specific act or practice has been identified either by the Privacy Commissioner or at the request of that class, the Privacy Commissioner may issue a code of practice. Before this code of practice is issued there must be reasonable efforts to inform affected classes and accept their submissions. The code of practice comes into operation following a resolution passed by both Houses of Parliament. A code of practice may override the operation of the Information Privacy Principles or specify how that principle is to apply to that industry.

The proposed amendments will also expand the functions of the Privacy Commissioner to enable the Commissioner to make public statements about privacy. This additional function is appropriate as it will allow the Privacy Commissioner to undertake community education campaigns on privacy issues and prepare materials that relate to public interest matters. The Privacy Commissioner will also be able to promote the protection of individual privacy.

When the Prime Minister performed his "backflip" on 21 March 1997 he said he was meeting the concerns of business: "The Commonwealth opposes such proposals which will further increase compliance costs for all Australian businesses, large and small. . . At a time when all heads of government acknowledge the need to reduce the regulatory burden, proposals for new compulsory regimes would be counterproductive" (Prime Minister, Press Release, 21 March 1997). It is uncertain whether the business sector generally agrees with the Prime Minister.

The quantitative research in Australia is very limited. However, Price Waterhouse surveyed 130 large businesses earlier this year and found 70 per cent favoured, 10 per cent were `neutral' and 20 per cent opposed the introduction of comprehensive national privacy laws. The survey report concluded: ". . . Australian business has identified privacy as a major business risk and they are looking to the Australian Government for guidance on how to manage it" (Privacy Survey 1997, Price Waterhouse, 215 Spring Street, Melbourne, Victoria, 3000). This survey confirms an earlier survey conducted by the Faculty of Business and Economics at Monash University which found businesses recognise the importance of personal information to their clients and employees (Boykett, J., O'Reilly, H. and Tucker, G., Private sector attitudes to information privacy, 1996, 3 PLPR 101). The Prime Minister's statement is also at odds with the major industrialised countries which have recognised the economic and social benefits of privacy protection.

In the absence of Commonwealth legislation, the States and Territories are considering filling the void. New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory are presently examining privacy legislation options. If State and Territory governments do introduce privacy schemes, businesses will be required to comply with each of those schemes which may be different for each State and Territory, therefore increasing overall compliance costs and regulatory burdens significantly. The Prime Minister's statements about compliance costs and regulatory burdens are hollow in light of these State and Territory responses, and highlights the need for a national and consistent privacy scheme.

The Ministerial meeting of G7 industrialised countries in February 1995 and APEC Ministers in May 1995 identified privacy as an issue which was important for commercial reasons. The European Union has adopted a legally enforceable law in the form of the Privacy Directive and New Zealand has implemented the Privacy Act 1993, which creates a comprehensive national privacy scheme applying to both the public and private sectors. The Euro pean Union Privacy Directive which comes into force on 1 July 1998 will prevent trade with Australia (and any other country) if there are not adequate privacy laws to protect personal information. The Government's Discussion Paper set out a scheme which was consistent with these international developments and international standards and would have met the concerns of the European Union Privacy Directive and our trading partners.

It is a fundamental principle that a person has a right to know what personal information is held about them, and if the information is lawfully held, that the information is correct. The International Charter of Civil and Political Rights Article 17 provides that "no one shall be subject to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his [or her] privacy". The Universal Declaration of Human Rights Article 12 provides that "No one shall be subjected to arbitrary interference with his [or her] privacy, family, home or correspondence, nor attacks upon his [or her] honour and reputation. Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference or attacks". Privacy is a human rights issue and the Government should deal with the issue as a part of Australia's international human rights obligations. These are fundamental human rights set out in Agreements to which Australia has attested and the domestic laws should reflect these international commitments.

This is essential to keep pace with the developments in other countries and the advances in information collection and exchange technology. The developing technology industries and consumers are likely to benefit from such a scheme, through continued access to world trade and the confidence of consumers that their personal information is adequately protected.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Senate for 1996‐97.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to have the question of the adoption of the 27th report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing relating to the transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances considered again immediately and the question put again subject to the time limits for consideration of committee reports under standing order 62.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the morning of 4 September a most extraordinary thing happened in this chamber. Most honourable senators were absolutely unaware of what occurred. What occurred was something I have never seen occur in all the time that I have been in this place. A report by a standing committee of the Senate was brought into this chamber at around 9.43 and 52 seconds. It was tabled in the parliament, the Presiding Officer ordered that it be printed and, at 9.44, seconds later, a motion was carried that the Senate adopt the committee's recommendation to note the government's decision and agree to the transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances from the Department of the Senate to the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: By that motion we were asked to adopt the recommendation in the report which was in the hands of only a very select few in the Senate, namely, the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. They are select members, they do a good job for us, but none of the rest of us had an inkling of what was contained in the report; yet at that stage we were supposed to vote on the recommendation. Of course, there was a short debate. I must say that I was caught short. I did not know the vote was going to take place. When I did find out I assumed that the normal thing would be for the matter to be adjourned. I actually came down and, when I rushed into the chamber, it was all over bar the shouting—everything had finished. I was rather concerned, but not only for myself; I believe other honourable senators who have subsequently found out what occurred are also concerned as to what occurred procedurally on that day.

Madam President, as I indicated to you in my letter to you of 5 September, I am sure that, had you been aware of these facts, you would have made sure that the matter was not finalised until senators had the opportunity of receiving and studying the report. I do not want to ask senators to indicate how many had the report, but I would say only three of the honourable senators who are currently in this chamber had the report. Almost none of those who are not currently in this chamber had the report.

That is the extraordinary thing that happened. I believe, Madam President, that something needs to be done on your initiative to ensure that that does not occur again. To order the report to be printed—and, by definition, I assume that means that people have not got the report—and then, seconds later, have a motion for the adoption of the recommendation in the report is a nonsense. But I will not belabour that point—I think it was probably just an oversight. We will just have to live with that.

I thank the Senate for giving us the opportunity to reconsider the merits or otherwise of the recommendation that we are being asked to adopt. The recommendation that we are being asked to adopt is one which I believe is flawed, in that it blurs the distinction between the executive government and the parliament. We are being asked to have the travelling allowances of the members of the Senate dealt with by an arm of the executive government. I do not believe that that is proper, given the principle of separation of powers. I know that some of the other entitle ments are dealt with by an arm of the executive government—that is another question—but this is an extension of that particular problem.

I object to it not only on that ground but also on the ground of efficiency. The Department of the Senate has, as we all know, an audit proceeding at the present moment—it is being done by an independent auditor—of all our travel allowances. I can tell you from experience that they are going through it with a very fine toothcomb indeed.

There is data matching available. I think I gave you the example the other day of where I had been picked up for claiming travelling allowance for Canberra when I was not in Canberra. It was a Tuesday night in late April of last year. For the life of me, I could not figure it out, because I knew that I was here on the Monday and probably on the Sunday—so what was I doing on the Tuesday? I asked my wife as a matter of fact, and she said, `I drove you from the service for the victims of Port Arthur to an air force plane.' What had happened was that I had come down in an air force plane—there was no record of my coming back—and I had been dropped off, as far as I can work out, in Melbourne, where I stayed overnight. There were three of us in that boat—

TALK.START.PARA: —Plane!
—In that plane, sorry. Interestingly enough, I think the rate for Melbourne is higher than the rate for Canberra—
—It is.

—Well, I expect to be paid an extra ten bucks or something. Seriously, the matter is being properly handled and was being properly handled by the Department of the Senate. With the Department of the Senate, you, Madam President, are in a position of impartial chair in this chamber and you have the overall responsibility—not an officer of the executive government, as we are going to put it into Mr Jull's—
—Senator Macdonald's area.
—Is it?
—I don't know. I was just having a stab.

—Anyhow, it is going into a department of the executive government, and I do not believe that that is appropriate at all. I make no reflections on Mr Jull. I have always regarded him as a very efficient person. I served on a number of committees with him. I am trying to deal with this on its merits. On its merits, I suggest to all senators that they should regard this as so important that an individual decision should be made on the matter. I believe it does go to the question of separation of powers. I would be happy to hear from other senators. I particularly notice that Senator Vicki Bourne has a dissent—
—An excellent report.
—Yes, Senator Woodley, she has an excellent dissenting report which is contained in the document that we are currently discussing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has made a number of points. I acknowledge, first of all, that his points about the process in this have some merit. However, I want to assure him that there was no deliberate attempt to ambush either him or other senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have to say that the issue of where travel allowance is located did not revolve only around this report; it had been a matter of public and political discussion around the building for several months beforehand. But he does make the point that some senators would not have had the opportunity of reading the report before voting on the substance of it. Hence, I do not think there is any objection today to having the matter recommitted.

But then we go to the issues of substance. Senator Harradine says that in terms of separation of powers this is a wrong move. I am afraid all the powers are pretty mixed up already. So what he is talking about is not a matter of principle; he is talking about a matter of degree. Many of the entitlements are already paid by government. No matter what happens in this, salaries will continue to be paid for senators, other than those who are office holders, by the Department of the Senate. So there is no division and there is no rationalisation when everything is one area. That point should be made first of all.

Secondly, those who support travel allowance being in the Department of Administrative Services—or indeed, if you go to the other argument that it should be in the Senate and all travel should be paid by the Senate—are basically centralisers. I am one of those. I believe a centralised system makes it easier to keep track of reconciliation between various elements than where it is dispersed over areas in which inevitably there are turf fights. Albeit that the Department of the Senate and DAS probably get along on most issues, there will be turf fights, and I think we should try to eliminate those.

The Labor Party in opposition adopted a view some months ago that all travel allowance, both House of Representatives and Senate, should go to the DAS. One of the strongest reasons we put forward in regard to this—apart from centralisation and reconciliation—really goes back to the separation of powers, Senator Harradine. If it is going to be a matter of political controversy—and it continues to be so and it may disappear in the near future but at the moment, one has to say, payment of travel allowance is a matter of political controversy—we in opposition would much rather have an adversarial relationship with the Department of Administrative Services and their minister than with the Department of the Senate.

As backbench and frontbench opposition senators and others we tend to have a different relationship with the Department of the Senate than with other government departments. That is reflected in the government's view that they are not going to have the general Public Service reform bill apply to officers of the Senate but have a separate bill. We do not like having a situation where, when we are not satisfied with travel allowance claims, we have as our adversary across the table—who is not really an adversary—President Reid. We do not like the various clerks having to try to defend—or in some way be embarrassed to expose—problems in this area, because they deal with other Senate colleagues. To us, it has always made more sense to put it in the more political arena.

To that, Senator Harradine would say, `Yes, but if you put it in a more political arena they are more likely to misuse and abuse it.' That is only true to the degree to which you do not apply accountability to it. Senator Harradine would no doubt say, `Look, the Sharp matter'—and I am not going into the details of it—`shows that there can be political interference in these area.' I say that the exposure of that says you cannot get away with it. I say that it is always likely to surface in some way in any event and that you can make a government and a minister accountable for travel allowance.

As far as the opposition is concerned, these travel allowance claims—for ministerial and office holder, backbench and frontbench—should be in the House of Representatives. These various reports that they have commissioned to get the systems up and working—and no‐one argues that they are at the moment—will improve the system. The same techniques in the process of accountability that KPMG is doing at the moment in terms of all the rest of us will be able to be applied by DAS in future, and you will not have these issues coming up again.

I am pretty certain you will not have these issues coming up again, but that will not be because of where we locate travel allowance claims or of what reconciliation we do. No‐one ever again will deliberately manipulate travel allowance. However, I do add, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there will always be mistakes. Senator Harradine will even do his for the wrong sitting days. If that has not happened another 40 times I will jump in the lake. I have my letter and I am all clear; I was probably lucky that I did not make a mistake. What we want to see in terms of accountability is that there is no repeated abuse of travel allowance.

We argue that that will be best done in a centralised system. If it is centralised it has to be in either the Department of the Senate or DAS. We would prefer it to be DAS because, in terms of a political relationship, we believe we can pursue when necessary an adversarial relationship with DAS when we may be extremely reluctant to do so with the Department of the Senate because of its unique relationship with senators.

I am sure, even though there is some heartbreak in the Department of the Senate at losing this particular matter to DAS, there will also be a sense of relief. I am sure that our valued officers in the Senate do not like calling senators in and do not like saying, `We think you have misclaimed.' They do not like that sort of relationship, because it is a department that not only administers but also gives advice and help to senators. Basically, that is why it has such a high reputation. That reputation will be tarnished if its officers are also given the tasks of policemen on these issues.
I have listened to your arguments, Senator Harradine. Maybe it is very hard to convince anyone to change their mind, but you have not done so today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues that we are looking at today. The first is the issue of the recommittal. I am tempted to begin a rave on this one but I will try to restrain myself. I believe that we are seeing, time and time again, governments avoiding the processes of the parliament. I could give lots of examples of that. Instead, I will simply make an appeal to the Senate that is based on the problem that we have right throughout Western democracies, that people are becoming more and more alienated from democratic processes. That is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only do people feel that they are not involved in the democratic processes, but the parliament itself and members of parliament feel alienated. I do not think that has come about deliberately, but certainly, in asking for a recommittal, it is against the background of that climate of alienation of representatives and of the people themselves who feel that the political and parliamentary processes are beyond them. Here is another example which will simply add to that feeling of alienation. So that issue of recommittal is the first issue.

Senator Ray raised the issue of the substance of this. I listened very carefully to what he said, and I say to him that I am willing to change my mind, but he certainly has not convinced me. The first thing that needs to be said is that there was no substance at all in the report itself. It was only one page long. The only substance was in the dissenting report. The dissenting report picked up the substance of the Baxter report to government, which none of us has been able to read, although it was read by officers of the Senate. We were given some idea of the substance of that report in the dissenting report.

In that dissenting report it was very clear that there was no reason at all that could justify the government or the opposition supporting this change. The dissenting report sets out very clearly that, far from there being a reason for the change, there are reasons for the system to remain as it is.

The other problem in relation to the matter which Senator Ray raised about Mr Sharp is that, as I understand it, none of the travel allowances of ministers have been audited, although those of the rest of us have. Is that going to happen if we transfer to DAS?

TALK.START.PARA: —Including none of the previous government.
—Yes, and that is why I believe that not only should we recommit this issue but we should also change what we have done.

—Senator Woodley, by way of clarification, we are not actually discussing recommittal. Leave has been granted for the debate to take place, and the question before the chair is that the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a rather savage irony in relation to this report. It is ironic that we have Senator Newman coming into the chamber and talking about how many tens of thousands of people she has managed to throw off social security in one week, and wearing it as a badge of pride. This is the politicisation of a process which, in my opinion, should be done with the discretion of professional officers under ministerial and professional guidelines, but not politicised to the point where you actually take away the discretion of officers to look at the circumstances of individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: Be that as it may, tens of thousands of people have been thrown off their means of living—for various reasons; sometimes for not filling out a form, or for not knowing that they needed to fill out a form, or for getting in an hour late on a deadline or for not turning up for an interview, perhaps because they did not have the bus fare. You can understand why the community is getting pretty ratted off with the way things are being dealt with in relation to such things as parliamentarians' travel allowances.

Given that, I cannot understand why the Labor Party is suggesting that it would like more politicisation rather than less. It is saying that the two‐party adversarial system is actually somehow or other going to give people more confidence in the system than a carefully crafted approach to make sure that the system is right, that the checks and balances are there and that it is not a process of politicisation.

You can understand why the public is losing more and more confidence in the parliamentary process because the community has been treated that way. The community has been treated badly in such areas as social welfare. They have been treated as frauds. They have been considered guilty. Because of a ministerial edict to throw people off their entitlements, people with no money have had to try to take legal action to get back what they were in fact legally entitled to. I can understand that anger. We should be moving to make sure that the processes are right within this Senate and that we do not make a politicisation of what should be a careful and independent administrative process.

I also would like to comment on Senator Ray's comments about the separation of powers. Over time, Senator Harradine and I have mentioned the concept of the separation of powers, a constitutional guarantee supposedly. I believe this is where the use of precedence is in fact an abuse. If things have been done wrongly in the past, and if the separation of powers has been threatened by the way the House of Representatives often takes action because it knows that the executive government will get its way because of the numbers, that is not and never should be an excuse. It is not a precedent. If somebody has been acting unconstitutionally and we know the reasons why, that is no excuse for the Senate to condone an abuse of the supposed constitutional protections of this nation. That is an abuse of precedent. To say that something has been done wrongly in the past is no excuse for doing it again.

I know there are plenty of examples in this place. One that I have spoken of on a number of occasions is the fact that, supposedly for financial reasons, more and more we get departmental officers in on committees. The House of Representatives has been doing it for a long time, but more and more it is becoming the accepted norm. I do not accept that that is right. I do not accept that having people who are beholden to the executive is right in terms of committee processes. I think it is an abuse of the separation of powers, but the fact that that has happened before is now being used as a precedent for using it more and more either in joint committees or in Senate committees.

I do not think there is any reason why this should not be challenged every time it happens. If it is against the constitutional guarantees of this nation, every time it happens it is also a threat to the constitutional guarantees of this nation. Maybe we have to talk about this. Maybe, when we have the debate on the constitution, we have to talk about such things as the separation of powers. Do we as a nation still think that the executive, the courts and the parliament should be separate? If that is the case, we should build in the checks and balances. We should make sure that we do not get to this ridiculous situation where they are eroded so much that the erosion itself is seen as a precedent for continuing to do the wrong thing.

I very much support Senator Harradine's concerns. I am glad that this vote has been committed, but I am very sad that the Labor Party is seeing fit to do what might seem to be, for it, the easiest political solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond very briefly. I actually do not think this is a big issue because I simply see it as an administrative matter. Most of us here, I think, strongly support the principle of the separation of powers. It is one of the safeguards of our democratic system, but there are areas where it becomes blurred and quite tricky.

SPEECH.PARA: The big area of consequence that we have debated many times is the one of fiscal independence, if I could put it in those terms. The debate has been as to whether the parliament has the right to determine what funds are necessary to do its job properly and the responsibility of the executive to the taxpayer to ensure that the parliament does not spend in excess of what is necessary to do its job properly.

I have had various quarrels about that that I can remember well. I can remember former Senator Walsh as finance minister holding a very strong view on that, which I think I argued with on occasions. The outcome was generally a compromise, and I think it has worked reasonably well. So I can understand those areas where it can be argued that a decision by the executive can threaten in some way the independence of the legislature, or the capacity of the legislature to operate effectively, but this seems to me to be fundamentally different.

There is no question here of either the allowances changing as a result of a transfer of the administration or someone having some greater discretion in relation to those allowances or a capacity to exert undue influence as a result of those allowances. If there was, I think there would be a stronger argument. It seems to me that this is purely a question of administrative efficiency, and the concept of all parliamentary allowances being paid through one central administrative office—and the Department of Administrative Services seems as logical to me as any other—seems to be a sensible result.

On that basis, certainly in my participation in this committee and in expressing my views elsewhere, I was prepared to support the recommendation, and I have to say that I have not heard anything today that would cause me to change my mind. If I had heard an argument that I thought demonstrated that as a result of the decision in some way the Senate was going to be limited in its capacity to perform the task with which it is entrusted I might have been otherwise persuaded, but I do not think that that case has been made out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 24 September.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to. We have some deferred amendments to clause 61.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, if I can help, we have two deferred matters. One is the question of the national schemes and how the legislation treats them. The other is part 6 of the bill which is the sunsetting of legislative instruments. I presume we will start with the national schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: To reiterate the opposition's position, as I said at the start of this particular item, we were supportive of the government. A legitimate concern was raised by Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine about the extent of exemption which is embodied in clause 61(7).

Our position last night was that we wanted some advice from the Solicitor‐General on the effect of 61(7). Of course, that has not been presented to us as yet. Our position this morning is that, though we are still of the view that national schemes should be exempt, the range of schemes that are exempt under 61(7) goes too far. Senator Margetts raised the question of the native title scheme. This is a scheme which no-one in this place anticipated would be exempt by the operation of the legislation, but I think there is a fair case to argue that it can be seen to be exempt.

We are not prepared to support the government's position at the moment. It is too wide. I do not know if the minister has any advice for us to consider, but, even if he has, I think it might be a bit hasty for us to consider it this morning. We will just see what he has got. Our position at the moment essentially is that we cannot support 61(7). We would like the government to spend some time thinking about how they can exempt schemes. We put one idea to them yesterday. Maybe they can look at a scheduled approach to this problem or maybe they can look at redrafting 61(7). Our concern does not just go to the Native Title Act; it goes to a whole range of schemes that might be in place, whether in the child‐care area, HACC related services, aged services and so on. There is a larger program of devolving social functions to the states. We would be concerned that those functions were not also exempted by the operation of 61(7).

We have a legitimate concern. We do share the government's aspirations. We do not think 61(7) achieves a proper balance. It may very well be appropriate for us to either defer consideration of this or to in fact bowl over 61(7) at this stage and the government can give some consideration to other ways of attacking this problem when the bill goes back to the House of Representatives. It is fair to say that we have come to this with the same intentions as the government, but we do not share with it the ambit of 61(7) as it is currently drafted. We want to find some constructive way through it, but we are not prepared to support 61(7) this morning. Senators Margetts and Harradine have persuaded us to a certain extent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be an understatement to say that I am greatly relieved to hear Senator Bolkus say that the Labor Party has reconsidered as a result of the points I brought up last night. I am also grateful to my electorate officer for having found those last night.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Bolkus mentioned is true. I gave just one example, but others have come forward overnight. It was pointed out that we currently do not have any national standards on anything environmentally that I know of but we might have some responsibility on such things in the future, and these could all not be subject to disallowance either. We have mainly social issues, Aboriginal issues and things like environmental standards which may well be out of the purview of accountability of the parliament. That is really not acceptable. I think the parliament is not ready to consider these issues at this stage. The implications have to be looked at very carefully before we are required to look at them again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the advice that was sought, I advise the Senate that, as I understood them, there were a number of questions. The first one was: are the existing Native Title Act and proposed native title bill with their proposed subordinate legislation to be regarded as an intergovernmental scheme? That is the point I think Senator Bolkus touched on. The answer to that is no. The advice states that the enabling legislation does not or will not facilitate the establishment or operation of an intergovernmental body or scheme involving the Commonwealth and one or more other states within the meaning of paragraph (a) of the subclause. Nor does or will the enabling legislation have either of the effects specified in paragraph (c) of the subclause.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to paragraph (a) of the subclause, it is necessary only to consider whether the enabling legislation does or will facilitate the establishment or operation of a scheme. It is clear from the terms of the provision that a scheme may yet to be established or may have pre‐existed the enabling legislation with reference to facilitating the operation of a scheme.

The Macquarie Dictionary relevantly defines `scheme' as `a plan or design to be followed . . . a program of action'. This suggests that a scheme must have some orderly sequence or ongoing operation according to established rules or principles. Moreover, the reference in the paragraph to the involvement of the Commonwealth and one or more states suggests that a scheme in the present context must be a concerted plan or program of action involving the agreement of the Commonwealth and one or more states.

The other question was: is any regulation made pursuant to the existing Native Title Act or any regulation under the proposed bill disallowable? The answer is yes. In relation to paragraph (c) of the subclause, the fact that section 214 of the Native Title Act makes or will make all of the ministerial determinations in question disallowable instruments within the meaning of the present Acts Interpretation Act indicates clearly that the determinations were intended to be disallowable.

The provisions authorising the making of the determinations therefore cannot be construed for the purposes of paragraph (c) as having the effect that determinations cannot be disallowed or could not be disallowed before the commencement date. This would be the case even if section 214 is not amended to take account of the changes proposed to be made to the Acts Interpretation Act by the Legislative Instruments Bill in relation to disallowance and other matters.

The third question, as I understood it, was: in the event that the answer to question No. 1 is yes, what effect will subclause 61(7) of the bill have on the existing native title legislation and the proposed native title legislation? That question No. 1 was whether the native title legislation and proposed legislation constituted a scheme. If it was to be construed as a scheme, the advice is that it is not considered that the determinations would fall within the provision. That applies to whether the native title legislation is a scheme or not. So that is the advice the government has obtained in the short time available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's it from?
—This advice, Senator Bolkus, is from the Office of General Counsel. I have this opinion here which I can table. It is available for tabling and I believe answers the questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a general comment about legislation. When you are looking at a provision like subsection 61(7), in my view it should be clear so that members of the parliament can be quite clear as to what they are dealing with. If you have legislation where you need a legal opinion to clarify what the position is I think that raises some worries.

SPEECH.PARA: Legislation should be as clear as possible. That means that legislation should be in a state where members of parliament, indeed the public generally, should know exactly what they are able to do without resorting to legal opinion. If it is necessary to obtain legal opinion then it might be time for us to look at how the legislation is expressed. Perhaps legislation should be expressed in better terms than it presently is so as to avoid the need for a legal interpretation.

The most that legal interpretations can do is give a person's opinion, a highly qualified and very learned person's opinion, as to what a particular piece of legislation might mean. Of course it is not definitive. It is always bad, I think, to have to rely on opinions which, by their very nature, cannot be definitive. If there are problems with subclause 61(7) to the extent of requiring opinions, I think what we ought to do is perhaps improve on subclause 61(7).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is an excellent point made by Senator Cooney in his usual style. It is a bit disconcerting when, on the face of it, one understands from subsection 61(7) that these national schemes, which involve the Commonwealth or one or more states, are such that it is clear that they are exempt from the provisions of the legislation. Now we have a legal opinion or a view—I do not know which it is—from the Office of the General Counsel saying certain things. I have not had a look at them. I heard what the minister has said and I acknowledge and thank him for getting that information.

SPEECH.PARA: But I agree with what Senator Cooney said. Indeed, the minister himself said, I think his last statement, which I do not have a copy of, `if it were to be construed to be a national scheme or an agreement between the Commonwealth and one state'. So in his mind, and even in the mind of the person who wrote the opinion, there is a question. In any event, if it not clear, who is to say that if it does come before the courts, the courts may have another view altogether? Then where are we?

Whilst I am on the subject, and I do not want to belabour it, the minister obtained advice from his officers yesterday which, on reflection, he might like to change. When the matter of certificates was being considered, when we were talking about the Attorney's certificate as to whether a matter was an instrument which would come under this particular legislation, as you know we adopted an amendment to the legislation which declares that those instruments are themselves disallowable instruments. If I go to page 6773 of yesterday's Hansard, I said:

When the previous government was in office, it introduced its bill in 1994. It was taken up as a recommendation by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee at that time. In fact, the previous Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, accepted it. So that is the history of it. I am sure that the parliamentary secretary—
the minister—
would know that. In any event, the AD(JR) processes—
the minister was saying that may be the way to go, instead of declaring that certificate would itself be a disallowable instrument; why not go the other route—the legal route? I said:
In any event, the AD(JR) process is not binding on the Attorney‐General under this bill, is it?
The response by the minister—and I recall him getting advice from his department—was:
It is. It is binding.
As I understand it, it is not binding. It is binding for the Attorney‐General to consider the decisions. But that of itself does not bind the Attorney‐General to a particular course of action.

In certain areas I am a bit concerned about the quality of advice. I know the officers concerned are not involved in the other glaring example of the minister's office or whoever advised the minister on the NVE classification. That was an absolutely glaring example of a demonstrably false statement by the Attorney‐General of this country on quite an important matter to many people in this country. I do believe that we should adopt the amendment that is currently before us.

Whilst I am on my feet, I would ask the minister, what are the government's aims in regard to this matter? Some reference to the government's aims were adverted to by Senator Bolkus and I just wonder what they are. Are the government's aims in respect of their opposition to this amendment? Is it their aim that the power should be taken away from the Commonwealth parliament alone in these particular national schemes, that is, in respect of our rights to exercise our powers in respect of disallowing subordinate legislation under these national schemes? That is what he is doing. That is what the government is doing.

The state legislatures will still have that power. The territory legislatures will still have that power. It appears that the government is saying that, in Commonwealth and state national schemes, the Commonwealth parliament should not have the power and should not exercise that power which we have to protect the rights of individuals, and indeed, as I said yesterday, exercise our `function of audit and control over executive government decisions.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a brief discussion with the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison). As I indicated, we were not prepared to support proposed subsection 61(7) of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 at this stage. The advice that has been proffered is limited to the Native Title Act. As I mentioned just a little earlier, we have got concerns about other schemes as well. As I said yesterday, I am not so sure that I would want to place the prediction of any future litigation on the advice of the Office of General Counsel.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting that aside, I think there are some real issues that we need to address here. I suggested that there were two courses of action available us to. One is to delete this provision now and let the government work on it between now and when it goes back to the House of Representatives. The other is for us to report progress on this particular provision and reconsider the bill at a later stage.

I think from discussions with the minister, it might be best for us to support Senator Margetts's amendment at this stage and put on notice to the Senate that, in doing so, we do not say outright that there should be no exemption for national schemes. We do say that we would like to consider this matter further to see how it can best be refined to cover the sorts of schemes that the govern ment and the opposition do have in mind, but not to have the unintended broad consequences that it seems to have at the moment. We will vote with Senator Margetts at this stage in anticipation that something—hopefully, something different—will come back from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Apropos of what Senator Harradine is talking about—the standing of the decision of the court if an appeal is taken under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act—the issue of whether it is an advise to the Attorney-General or is of a more binding character needs to be resolved. Is there any provision under the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 presently before us which enables the decision of an Attorney-General to be set aside and another decision by a tribunal, whether it be a court or an AAT, to be substituted?

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is the confusion that is presently before us. Is it simply that the Federal Court can say the Attorney-General has not gone around his task in accordance with the law or is it simply that it gives him very strong advice? Just what is the nature of it? The impression being left at the moment is that somehow the court can substitute its decision for that of the Attorney-General. If that is not correct, it would be very helpful to know the true situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Senator Cooney's question, which of course dovetails with Senator Harradine's question yesterday, the answer is no, a replacement decision cannot be made. As to the effect on the Attorney-General, in relation to proposed subclause 8(6), I touched on the action of the Federal Court yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: We might just follow it through. The Attorney-General issues a certificate. There is then a review of that decision available. The Federal Court can then quash or set aside the decision. The Attorney-General then must reconsider the matter. If the Attorney-General thumbs his or her nose at the Federal Court and reissues the certificate, it is then a fresh matter again and subject to the same review.

So my advice is that, although the Federal Court quashes the decision, it goes back to the Attorney-General and the Attorney-General is bound to reconsider the decision. If the Attorney-General is truculent to the court, if I can put it that way, and says, `No, I want to make the same decision,' then it can go back to the court. It keeps going in that circular motion, which would very soon, I would imagine, bring the Attorney-General into some sort of question. In the meantime, nothing further would progress.

I suppose that is the practical effect of this review mechanism. There is some sanction there, if you like—more than some sanction to the Attorney-General, because the Attorney-General knows that, if he or she makes that same decision again, it is back to the court.

I have the advice from the Office of General Counsel available here that I said I would table. Before I forget, I will table it now. There are copies available for honourable senators. I think that sums up the matter on that advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have found the contributions by Senator Bolkus, Senator Cooney, Senator Margetts and Senator Harradine very helpful in confirming our own attitudes. I particularly want to thank Senator Harradine for his contribution yesterday. I found it expressed the matter very succinctly and strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have already put on record our belief that national schemes of legislation should be subject to parliamentary purview. We are deeply concerned when the national parliament does not have regulatory and audit control over national schemes of legislation, even if we were, for instance, to delegate it to an appropriate committee or otherwise.

As I mentioned previously in the debate, the Democrats place the utmost importance on the issues of accountability, transparency and democracy. It is for those reasons that we will be supporting Senator Margetts's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apropos of the answer given by the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) to Senator Harradine's question, the minister said that people could keep going to the Federal Court. Minister, I should know this, but perhaps you could help me. If you challenge the Attorney-General's decision in the Federal Court, do you have to pay issuing fees? What would those issuing fees be? Have we any idea of what the cost would be of challenging the Attorney-General? If the Attorney-General did not comply and you again had to go to the Federal Court, would you have to pay similar costs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, any successful litigant could get an order for costs against the Commonwealth. Yes, you are right that those fees would apply in the normal course of events. If the applicant could persuade the court, by virtue of waiver provisions, of those fees—for instance, legal aid would be such an exemption—then those normal considerations would apply. What Senator Cooney says is right: the normal cost provision and issuing fees would apply.
—If somebody went to test the Attorney's decision in a legitimate concern and lost, would he or she have to pay the Attorney's costs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the normal costs in the cause would apply.
—Whilst all this to‐ing and fro‐ing is going on, the regulation is still in effect because it is not subject to disallowance. Would that be so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will seek advice on that point because there is a time limit within which things have to be done. The question is: what happens if the decision is quashed within that time limit? If the Attorney then has to reconsider that decision, then of course that elongates the time. To do the question justice—it is a very good question—we will perhaps defer the answer. I might take some little time to get back to Senator Harradine on that, although I do not think it will change his vote in this matter.

—Obviously it could become a very complicated issue of going off to the Federal Court, and an issue of costs and the problems that Senators Harradine, Margetts, Murray and Bolkus have raised are involved. Has the government any objection to a procedure that would not impose the risk of costs upon a person who wants to challenge these matters? Often times, at least in the old days, even if you did win in court, there were always solicitor‐client costs to pay. Is there any concern that somebody like Senator O'Chee is any less a judge of these matters than a Federal Court judge?
—He is sitting there with his inscrutable look.

—Having sat here and listened to his conduct of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances over the years, I must say that, like his predecessors, he has done marvellously. What is it in the quality of the Federal Court judges that makes them of a higher stature and of greater ability than Senator O'Chee, his committee and his predecessors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand Senator Cooney, the question is about full recovery of costs which, in the normal course of events, one does not get in civil litigation because of solicitor‐client costs. I understand that Senator Cooney is raising the concern that, if someone is successful against the government, they be entitled to full recovery of costs—I think I am right there, Senator Cooney. The government has no plan to change the existing situation in relation to recovery of costs, but I can take up your concern with the Attorney and, as Senator Bolkus mentioned, this matter will have to go back to the other place and matters can be considered then.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, can I clarify what you wish to do with opposition amendment 15 on sheet 493?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to not proceed with that but I foreshadow that I will be moving another opposition amendment which is about to be circulated. The effect of that amendment will be to delete part 6 of the currently framed broad sunset provisions altogether. I will also move a further amendment which will set up some system of weeding out the so‐called debt anachronistic legislative instruments—if I could speak to the amendment before moving it.
—You are wanting to do something with the sunset provisions, I take it?
—Yes.
—Are you not going to proceed with 15 on sheet 493 which relates to consultation and scrutiny of legislative committees?
—I think we can defer that one until the bill comes back, because it rides on the back of what happens.
—So you are not seeking to proceed with that?

—I am just having another look at it. It can proceed independently of what happens to the preceding part. Basically, it ensures there is some reporting system between the parliament, the Attorney and the state based scrutiny committee, so I do not think there is any real harm in proceeding with that and have it decided this morning. I spoke to it earlier; I do not need to speak to it again. I move:
