—I tend to agree with what Senator Bolkus first said. I do not think that there is any need to pursue this at this point. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: (7A) The Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances may, from time to time, report to the Attorney‐General on progress made by the Working Party of Representatives of Scrutiny of Legislation Committees throughout Australia in relation to the development, and governmental acceptance, of a national scheme for the Parliamentary scrutiny of legislative instruments, or the provisions of legislative instruments, to which section 61 does not apply because of the operation of subsection (7).
I would have thought that would be much better left until later. I do not think that there is any sense in dealing with it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I draw your attention to the fact that the amendment talks about subsection (7), which has just been taken out by the previous amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Harradine has made a relevant point. I seek leave to defer this amendment to a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us now move to the sunset clauses. We have postponed government amendments 6 and 7.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Bolkus's amendment is successful, I think it renders redundant government amendments 6 and 7, so we may as well deal with Senator Bolkus's amendments first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (l) Clause 52, page 53 (line 4), omit "or 66".
(2) Clause 61, page 66 (line 13), omit "30(7), 66(7) or 66(9)", substitute "or 30(7)".
We also wish to amend the bill in the following terms:
(3) Part 6, page 71 (line 2) to page 75 (line 29), TO BE OPPOSED .
(4) Clause 73, page 81 (line 18) to page 82 (line 10), TO BE OPPOSED .

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to opposition amendments 1, 2, 3 and 4 on page 669, which I have moved, and I will also speak to amendment 1 on page 671, which I will not move at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said yesterday, we have some concerns about the broad nature of the sunsetting of legislative instruments. Although I had circulated some amendments which sought to tackle the issue, on reflection and after further discussion with other senators yesterday, it became apparent to the opposition that what was being proposed had much broader implications, and some fairly negative implications, for the system of regulation and legislative instruments that currently prevails.

The amendments I have now moved go to deleting part 6, and to bringing in a provision which will ensure that each responsible minister, as soon as practicable after 30 June each year, has a report prepared on measures taken to determine whether the register contains any instrument made under enabling legislation administered by that minister which is no longer necessary, and to report on action taken to remove from the register any instrument which has been identified as no longer necessary.

We have a concern that there are instruments which should in fact be withdrawn because they are no longer necessary. Part of the motivation for a sunset provision in the bill was to weed out such dead instruments but, in doing so, the legislation, once again, goes a bit too far. Although the provision of a five‐year across‐the‐board sunset provision would have the effect of ensuring that only relevant legislation is kept alive, such a broad sunset provision will ensure that a lot of instruments which are still necessary would also lapse because of the provisions of the sunset part of the bill.

As I said yesterday, particularly instruments of social relevance have long‐term effect and need to have long-term effect. For instance, I would not like to be in a situation where, in five years time, a regime of quarantine, migration, education, employment, environmental, consumer and privacy related instruments were all to lapse because of us passing this legislation in the broad terms in which it is appearing before us today.

The other concern I have is not that it would lapse, but that there is no way for a house of the parliament to ensure such legislative instruments would continue in effect. We do not have the capacity here to introduce instruments. After this bill gets through we may have some capacity to amend, if the other house agrees with the amendments put up by the Senate, but we do not have a capacity to ensure that any relevant and important instrument will have a continuing effect if part 6 gets through in its current form.

As I say, we tried to find another way of doing this to try to balance the need to eradicate the not relevant instruments at the end of a five-year period. On reflection, I think the amendment that I had circulated does not protect against a wholesale extinguishment of such instruments after five years. It also does not really give us sufficient capacity to keep any individual instrument that we deem to be necessary to keep alive. That just cannot be done under the first series of amendments that I circulated.

As a consequence, I think it is playing on the safe side, but doing a bit more than that; it is playing on a side which protects the public with respect to so many social areas and also economic areas. You cannot really talk about environmental instruments without having some economic impact. You cannot talk about any of the areas I have talked about without them having broader than a specific policy concern.

To satisfy a need to continue weeding the not so relevant instruments, in discussion with some senators, and with some thought given to it even late last night, the opposition feels that a good way to approach this would be to ensure that there is some accountability to the parliament for a process which would weed out the dead and not so relevant instruments. That is the process that I signalled is embodied in amendment No. 1 on page 671; that is, an annual reporting by ministers to parliament on steps taken on stocktakes that, for instance, have been taken in the course of the year to clean up the instrument register. Such a clause makes the ministers and, more importantly, the departments focus on this issue annually. In a sense, it is probably better than a five-year sunsetting provision in terms of getting rid of not relevant instruments in that it makes the departments focus on it continually. There will be a need for an annual report to this place and, as a consequence of the need for an annual report, departments will have to focus on this issue in a continuing sense.

As I said at the start, this is not the position taken by the amendments that we first circulated but, having had a closer look at the bill and having had discussions yesterday, I think it is important for us not to proceed with a blanket extinguishment of legislative instruments after five years. If it is possible to do so, I also should move the amendment on page 671, on the basis that this amendment and the previous amendments be voted on separately.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 79 (after line 22), after clause 71, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 71AA Annual reports on unnecessary instruments

PARA.TAB: (1) As soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, each responsible Minister must cause a report to be prepared on:

TAB.TAB: (a) measures taken to determine whether the Register contains any instrument, made under enabling legislation administered by the Minister, which is no longer necessary; and
(b) action taken to remove from the Register any instrument which has been identified as no longer necessary.

PARA.TAB: (2) The Minister must cause a copy of a report prepared under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament on or before 31 October in each year

TALK.START.PARA: —More and more, Western Australia is called the sunset coast. From the sunset coast, we are talking about sunsets here. But I think what Senator Bolkus is talking about is eclipsing the sunset. In this particular case, I am prepared to support the eclipsing of this sunset. It is a problem if the whole of the legislative instruments get dumped—certainly at all at once. It is going to be a heck of a problem in five years time when they start coming up at the same time. Perhaps there will be administrative problems where there are good reasons why delegated legislation and legislative instruments have been put in place. So I think the addition of the review of annual reports is a good one; therefore, I will be supporting Senator Bolkus's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —After regulations or legislative instruments are made and pass the disallowance period after tabling, the Senate has no opportunity to revisit these regulations, ever. If the government makes or remakes regulations in a particular subject area, then we do indeed deal with the new regulation but not the old. The regulations stay there forever until the government wants to remove them.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's provision in part 6 of the bill would have meant that all legislative instruments would sunset after five years—that is, after they were made—and would expire and cease to have effect unless the purpose of the legislative instrument to which this section applied was to confer rights on a person that were intended to have a long-term effect and unless the Governor-General was satisfied that the operation of a subsection in relation to that instrument would have frustrated that purpose, and then the anniversary period would have been 15 years.

You will recall that in my speech on the second reading, we clearly indicated that we felt that the sunsetting provisions were an attractive part of the bill. Not only did we see that there was a utility component to it, if you like, in that you could chop out what was undoubtedly dead wood—old and difficult regulations—but also we hoped that, in the stocktaking manner that Senator Bolkus alluded to, there would be opportunity for regulations to be brought back into the house and be reconsidered in a reframed manner. Consequently, knowing what the advantages of the proposed system were, we found it difficult to have to debate the downside because the downside is that so much good—as the whole Senate considers it to be good—could be swept out.

So the Australian Democrats would concur with the views of Senator Bolkus that we would like the government to revisit and to re-examine this area. However, I should advise you that we have been persuaded by the arguments of Senator Bolkus. Overall, what affects us is our view that the primacy of parliament must be maintained or, as Senator Harradine quite rightly pointed out, it is the role and the duty of the Senate to perform an audit role of executive actions. If regulations or legislative instruments are automatically sunset, we think it may create a vacuum whereby strong regulatory measures—many of them enhancing the human and procedural rights of ordinary Australians—may be placed at risk.

So, Minister, we recognise your very good case for the considerable benefits of the notion of a sunset clause, but we have also been persuaded that at this stage the risks are greater than the benefits. We are reluctant to take that risk because we can see that there is a double-edged sword. In swinging it down to chop out the dead wood, we might swing it up and chop out some better parts of the regulatory systems applicable in this country. Accordingly, we will be supporting these amendments but we do repeat Senator Bolkus's view that, if you can revisit this in some other manner, we would certainly be willing to consider your alternative proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say at the outset that the government's election policy was to ensure that all new regulations would be subject to a five-year sunset clause. Indeed, the sunsetting of delegated legislation is an important component of the government's policy on regulation review. The government believes that this will ensure that the regulation of business is reduced to the minimum necessary and that remaining delegated legislation is regularly considered for its appropriateness, currency, effectiveness and necessity. It is the government's belief that this sunsetting is an effective means of cutting back the dead wood. There can remain for years regulations which are absolutely irrelevant and redundant, and this sunsetting will do away with that.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has a good deal of support for the stand it takes on sunsetting. The Administrative Review Council recommended that all existing principal instruments of a legislative character and all instruments subject to the proposed Legislative Instruments Act should be sunsetted. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs also recommended that a sunsetting regime be introduced in relation to all existing and future legislative instruments as soon as possible. As well as that, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report entitled Clearer Commonwealth law and the Access to Justice Advisory Committee report entitled Access to justice also supported the introduction of a sunsetting program.

Therefore, it can be seen that there is a good deal of support for the sunsetting regime in relation to legal instruments. I can say that this is a matter which has not been greeted warmly by the bureaucracy because it does place an onus on the bureaucracy to make sure that the good wood does not fall away with the bad. So that places an onus on the bureaucracy as well.

I might say that the sunsetting of legislative instruments is not designed to see good law done away with; moreover, it is designed to see bad law done away with—law that is no longer relevant or law that is redundant. So the government is firmly of the view that a sunsetting regime is appropriate. In any event, there is always the scrutiny of the Senate, by its committees available, to the question of regulations. It is not taking any question of review away.

BREAK.PARA: For instance, if a good regulation were coming up for the sunset period, it would be open for the Senate, via its committees and via this chamber, to raise these questions with the government: are you going to introduce a new instrument? What are you going to do about the sunsetting of this? That is a question which could be raised by the Senate to the government, and quite rightly so. So the government believes that it does not take away any question of review, but it provides a system of cleaning out the Augean stables, so to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if I could be helpful in reminding the Senate that the power granted by the Senate yesterday in the amendment to amend regulations does give the government the opportunity to appropriately amend and put a sunset clause in any regulations that it wants deal with in that manner. I appreciate that it is far easier and administratively less onerous to have a global clause, as you put up. I appreciate that it is more difficult to pursue that route, but there is the opportunity to go back to regulations and put in a sunset clause, if you wish, based on the amendment that was passed yesterday.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the point Senator Murray makes, but the problem you have there is that you then have to ask the question: is this a regulation which has its own sunsetting regime? Whereas, if you have a global approach, you know what the ground rules are; you know where you are starting from. That would be the government's approach to that.

—One of the things that has to be taken into consideration is that the government is undertaking a process where it is actually pulling down the Public Service to about one‐tenth of its original size. It does not seem quite logical that, when there may well be other ways of doing something, the government should put something in place so that all regulations—good, bad or indifferent—have to be redone every five years in a bureaucracy which has actually got fewer and fewer people to do that work. I am not saying the work, if it is necessary, should not be done. I can think of nothing better than if a lot of the revolting regulations for things like woodchip licences and so on disappeared; I would be overjoyed—
—Me too.

—There are many, on balance, that I would love to see disappear into infinity. However, the fact that the Senate is involved with disallowance debates not infrequently is the exception to the rule; the rule is that most of the regulations are quite acceptable and quite useful. I think the reality is we do have the ability to review those politically. I hope that ability remains. I hope the government will accept that. There is now an ability to amend regulations. I think that that provides a level of ability for the community to have an input. We are here on behalf of the community; we are not here on our own behalf. I am not sure that extinguishing regulations regularly after five years will actually serve any useful purpose. I hope that, whatever is worked out as a result of this legislation going through, that will not be what happens.

—I want to raise a question which is exercising my mind—a possible danger. At the present moment, if the government wants to repeal a legislative instrument or regulation it must make another regulation to repeal that regulation, and that regulation is a disallowable instrument. Either house would then be able make that decision. Here, you are really not giving either house the opportunity to consider whether those regulations should disappear or not. Under this provision you just wait for five years and sort of back catch things you can forget about after five years. The government does not need to have leave to make a conscious decision, nor does that conscious decision in the form of a disallowable instrument come before us. So, in a way, whilst I agree with what people have been saying about sunsetting, it will, in certain instances, I fear, be a very handy way for the government to have legislative instruments which might be very socially beneficial just disappear into the sunset.
—There is no way that you would be able to keep track of all those regulations that are disappearing.
—I think Senator Margetts makes a valid point: there is no way that we would be able to keep track of those regulations that are disappearing. I just raise those points for your consideration.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is alive to Senator Harradine's point, and we will take those concerns on board.

—The amendments moved by Senator Bolkus are now to be voted on. I need to explain to the committee that, because amendments (3) and (4) seek to oppose parts of the bill, I need to put the question in three parts. —Amendment No. (3) on page 699 seeks to oppose part 6, page 71 (line 2) to page 75 (line 29). I put the question that part 6, page 71, stand as printed.
—Amendment No. (4) relates to clause 73, page 81 (line 18) to page 82 (line 10). The question is that clause 73 stand as printed.
—The question now is that Senator Bolkus's amendment No. 1 on page 671 be agreed to.
—Minister, I believe you said that, if these amendments were successful, this would then overrule your amendments Nos (6) and (7). Do you now wish to move for their removal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am of the opinion, Madam Chair, that my amendment 13 on sheet 634 should also now fall away.
—Thank you for drawing that to the committee's attention. Because you have not moved it, it will lapse, but we appreciate the acknowledgment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —From the point of view of where this bill is headed, the government will not oppose the bill as amended, although it does view some of these amendments as posing a significant problem. Nonetheless, all of these amendments will be given serious consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The point has been made by just about everybody in their speech on the second reading that the general thrust of this bill is desirable and that what has occurred by means of the amendments—and there were quite a few—was finetuning to make sure that the accountability of the parliamentary system is as strong as it is necessary to be, or is moving towards what it should be. So nothing that has happened in the Senate should be interpreted as not supporting the general direction of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 but rather as making clear to the government that you cannot put these kinds of measures through and be less accountable to the parliament than you were before.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FAMILY AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Newman:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill 1997 . I suppose it is quite a difficult bill to tackle in some way—not because any of the issues raised are particularly complex, but it follows a general tendency of this government to put a whole group of largely unrelated measures together. Often it appears to me that it is an attempt to disguise some of the more negative aspects contained within it. This is one of those bills. Some of the measures contained in it are worth while; others are really quite unpalatable and will make Australian families worse off.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill contains measures that are beneficial but it does not hide those measures that are going to be harsh on families in Australia. Although the name of the bill contains the words `Family and Other Measures', the majority of it does not help families but continues to whittle away the safety net that protects many Australians.

I agree that it does contain some measures that will be beneficial but, as I have already stated, for a lot of families—and particularly for those who are struggling at the moment, who are on low incomes—it will mean that it will be harder to make ends meet and harder to put a decent roof over their head and their children's head.

The first major measure in the bill relates to immunisation. The schedule puts in place the payment of a maternity immunisation allo wance. This is an encouragement for families to immunise their children. It appears that it is quite necessary for this to occur in light of the declining rates of immunisation. In fact, the AMA indicated that 457 children died between 1980 and 1990 from diseases that they could have been immunised against. That has to be a national disgrace.

This measure provides the parents with a payment of $200 if the child is immunised at 18 months in addition to the $750 paid on birth. This is essentially the same maternity allowance that was introduced by the Labor government, with the small addition of $68. These two payments are divided in half and paid on birth and at 18 months respectively.

Some let‐out clauses are provided in the bill for a situation where the parent is a conscientious objector to immunisation or where the child has some contrary medical indicator against immunisation. I see this as a positive step to encourage parents to immunise their children. It is a move that the opposition fully supports, and it has indicated on many occasions that it does.

The payment is also coupled with an education campaign to encourage parents to immunise and financial incentives for general practitioners. There has also been a continuation of the Labor Party initiative to put in place an immunisation register. There appears to be some uncertainty at the moment about the continued funding of this register. When the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) is on his feet, I would appreciate it if he could indicate whether the funding for the register does continue post 1 July 1997. I hope he noted that.

Even though the immunisation plan is ostensibly designed to encourage parents to immunise, it concerns me that the bill indicates that over two years this change will save the Commonwealth some $30 million. That is really the sting in the tail—the fact that this government will make budget savings out of such a worthwhile initiative by punishing parents rather than encouraging them to immunise.

BREAK.PARA: It is not clear from the budget papers exactly where these savings will be derived from, but it would appear that they will be derived from parents who are unable to access the maternity allowance, child‐care assistance or the home child‐care allowance. It is worrying that those parents who fail to comply with the requirements of immunisation and who find it most difficult to overcome these hurdles are often families of low income or families who are suffering other difficulties. It is sad that the immunisation program, which is so worth while, is marred by this negative effect that may mean that families who are worse off than others will be punished even further.

I will now deal with schedules 2 to 11—the second major portion of the bill—which relate largely to the family payment, the parenting allowance and, in a minor way, the maternity allowance. Many of these changes remedy difficulties that were brought about when the original basic family payment and the family supplement were amalgamated and when further budget decisions were made that caused some unintended consequences. Many of these amendments are superficial and really go to rectifying those legislative irregularities, but there are changes within schedule 6 which make the social security system more complicated.

The first set of amendments deals with payments for more than the minimum rate of family payments while the child is outside Australia. The opposition welcomes and supports this measure, but also recognises that the way the government has implemented it introduces an anomaly into the portability arrangements for various social security payments. Labor's amendments to the schedule will remove this anomaly and align family payment portability arrangements with those applying to allowances. I will not deal with this now as it will be dealt with in some detail during the committee stage.

I would like to pay some particular attention to schedule 16 which contains the revised impairment tables used to assess eligibility for disability support pensions. An earlier version of these tables was introduced by the government last year, and members of the Senate may recall that it was withdrawn while being debated in the Senate. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) advised that she would consult with representatives of disability groups and those who are affected, and would come back with an agreed set of tables.

The minister indicated in her second reading speech that 38 disability and welfare groups were consulted on these new tables. It is interesting to note that the minister did not actually state that the groups were in agreement. I am aware from correspondence that there is a great deal of disagreement over these proposed tables.

A strong concern in the community is that the tables disregard impairments valued at less than five per cent. This means that if you do not have disabilities that are in excess of five per cent—that reach the requirement of a total of 20 per cent disability—you in fact miss out on eligibility for the disability support pension. This means that people with multiple disabilities, where these multiple disabilities substantially affect their ability to work and also their ability to get work, will be missing out on their disability payments, though in the past they would have received them.

The bottom line is that as a result of this change the government will pay out $8 million less in disability support pensions over three years. This seems to be the main concern of this government, rather than the responsibility our community has to support those who are not able to access the work force because of their disabilities. I often feel that we have hit the lowest limit of how low this government will stoop. I thought we had reached that when they attempted to take away entitlements for hearing services for those aged between 18 and 20, but I have to say that these changes to the disability tables hit a new low.

I would like to make some comments about schedule 16 of the bill. I understand that there were some discussions between the Democrats and the government about making some changes to make this a more equitable and fairer proposition. I understand that the Democrats have agreed to support the impairment tables in the form that is before us, to vote with the government to get the tables through, on the promise—I understand—of a review. I must say that, if I were a Democrat and looked at core promises and non‐core promises, I would be a little worried about whether in fact that promise will be honoured.

The government will evaluate the new tables in 18 months time. To me, that seems to be a long time in which to sell out people who are disabled and, in particular, people with multiple disabilities. I was hoping that Senator Woodley would be in the chamber. Maybe the reason he is not in the chamber is that his conscience is pricking him a little bit. Maybe he is concerned about the thousands of disability support pensioners who will be reviewed under these new impairment tables and will have their payments cancelled. I hope he will pay particular attention to this issue.

Many of these people will be forced to compete in the job market for the first time. Many of them will end up with no income at all. Thousands more Australians who will be applying for disability support pensions for the first time in the next few months will not qualify, though they would have qualified under the old tables.

I and my other colleagues in the Labor Party represent the interests of these lower income people and those people with disabilities who obviously have great difficulty in entering the work force and often have no resources or assets and little access to other income. We are very concerned about the arrangements that the Democrats have made with the government to ensure that these tables get through.

In the face of this arrangement, this deal—and I would go so far as to say this sell‐out of many people who are disabled—we will not be attempting to amend schedule 16, as obviously we can count and we know we will not be successful. But I hope that Senator Woodley and the other members of the Democrats look back at this decision today with regret and that those people in the community who lose their disability support pension write in very strong terms to Senator Woodley and the Democrats and indicate their concern.

The final matter that I would like to deal with today is the changes in rent assistance brought about by this bill. This, again, is a matter of some extreme callousness. The government has tried to railroad the reform of housing assistance by reducing the amount of rental assistance that is provided for a whole range of people, but it seems to me that it is only part of a general running down of the Commonwealth's contribution to housing around Australia.

The second leg of providing affordable housing through the Commonwealth is the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement. When this government first got in, it reduced the housing agreement from a period of three years to a period of one year. This ruled out the possibility of long-term planning and also any long-term capital commitment by the states in their public housing. It seems now that any capacity for reform and negotiation between the states in the area of public housing has collapsed. This government has now conceded that the interim agreement, as they describe it, will continue until the end of 1999.

They have been cutting back the direct funding of public housing. In fact, they cut $50 million a year. It was indicated to us in estimates that this was to come from general efficiencies. Very clearly, this means that fewer houses will be built for public housing this year. In fact, in New South Wales they have already indicated that they plan to reduce their construction of public housing units from the present 3,500 units a year to just 680 this year. It is a matter of great concern for us and for the community at large that we are not only reducing the amount of public housing available when there are huge waiting lists but also cutting the access to rental assistance.

The particular difficulty with rental assistance is that it attacks young people who are living in housing commission or public housing and whose income has already been taken into account to determine the rate of rent that is paid. That means that these young people, who at present may be obtaining some sort of financial support, particularly if they are also unemployed, would have declared that income and, accordingly, the rent that their family as a whole is paying for that public housing would be increased. These young people then make some contribution from their generally small income towards the rent.

The difficulty is, of course, that this measure takes away the payment of rental assistance for those young people. So, even though their income is taken into account in determining rent, they will no longer receive the rental assistance that every other person is entitled to if they are in that income band.

It makes us wonder why this government dislikes young people so much. Why is it that they are not entitled to rental assistance? Why is it that in the future they will not be entitled to a payment when they are out of work? It really does seem a very sad thing for our young people that they somehow are not entitled to the same support as older people, that they are of less value to the community, that in fact this Commonwealth government cares less about young people than it does about everybody else.

As I said at the outset, this bill is an amalgamation of many provisions, but there are four major areas that we are concerned about. We are concerned that the immunisation provisions will be used to punish families, those who have a lower income and who may not be able to access the child‐care assistance, the home care allowance and the immunisation payments, because they are less likely to make their way through the maze and achieve full immunisation by 18 months.

Minister, you missed my earlier comments because you were not in the chamber. In brief, the opposition has very much indicated all along support for the encouragement of immunisation and a program for the education and encouragement of parents to immunise their children. But there is a concern within the opposition that the budget savings indicated in this bill show that the end result will not be that more children will be immunised but that a lot of parents on low incomes will be punished.

The second area of concern is in relation to family payments. There is concern about the payment for those who are temporarily leav ing Australia, and we will be moving an amendment in that regard. The third—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk primarily about schedule 16 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill . This schedule introduces an amended set of revised disability impairment tables to be used when assessing a person's eligibility for the disability support pension, or DSP as we know it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am sure all senators will remember, this is not the first time we have considered the introduction of a revised set of impairment tables. It was something that we looked at in the spring session of parliament last year. At that time the government introduced legislation which would have made it very much harder for people to qualify for the DSP. Because they lowered the ratings for many impairments, last year's disability impairment tables would have ensured that many people receiving the DSP would be thrown off it. It would also have meant that anyone who failed to qualify for the DSP as a result of the new tables would have also become ineligible for many other programs which are specifically designed for people with disabilities.

The Australian Democrats believe that the disability impairment tables this government introduced last year were insufficiently researched, ill considered and far too harsh. If they had been accepted in their original form, many people with disabilities would have been left without any form of income or any assistance at all. This is because those people who became ineligible for the DSP would have moved on to other forms of income support, principally newstart. They would have been required to look for work and they would have been required to meet the relevant activity tests, with any breach of this being punishable through the withdrawal of income for extended periods.

What the government failed to recognise, however, was that many people who may have failed to meet the eligibility requirements for the DSP under the new tables would still not have been capable of consistently meeting the requirements of an activity test and would therefore have faced unfair breaches and the total loss of income.

When we were deciding on how we would vote on these tables last year, the Democrats consulted very widely with people with disabilities and those who work with them to help us better understand the implications of what was being proposed. During this consultation process we found that there was a great deal of concern, a great deal of anguish and a great deal of fear about the potential effects of the proposed changes.

There was a widespread belief that, yet again, the basic rights and needs of people with disabilities were being ignored. Virtually everyone we spoke to agreed that the ratings the government had allocated to the various impairments in the revised tables were so far removed from the real experiences of people with disabilities that it was almost beyond belief. I do not know: perhaps this huge dichotomy was just a reflection of how out of touch the government was with the needs and the experiences of people with disabilities at the time.

Last year the Democrats worked very hard to try to reduce the negative impact of the tables which were being proposed—the impacts that they would have had on people with disabilities. This was not an easy task, as I think we would all agree, as disability impairment tables are highly technical instruments. But, with a great deal of assistance from those working within the disability sector, the Democrats were able to put together over 60 amendments which, if accepted, would have greatly improved the govern2ment's legislation.

In response to these Democrat amendments, the government withdrew its legislation in the Senate during the debate and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) promised to go away and consult with people working within the disability area before bringing the tables back before the Senate. Over the past nine months I understand that the government has met with a number of groups and individuals within that sector and, as a consequence, has made a number of very positive changes to the tables it presented us with last year.

BREAK.PARA: Indeed, the Democrats are happy to give the government a big tick for some of the changes they have made in response to this latest consultation process. They have improved the requirement to accept treatment regardless of the cost, the possible side effects or the likely impact on a person's disability. They have improved ratings for interrelated conditions; there has been the recognition of some minor impairments and, very importantly, the inclusion of a rating for chronic fatigue. These changes are very positive and very welcome.

However, I would hasten to add that there are still several outstanding issues which the government has failed to address, and Senator Neal referred to these a little earlier. These are that some of the tables still do not have ratings for minor impairments, with the psychiatric table being especially harsh in this respect; there is still a wide disparity in assessment ratings across various tables; and the assessment process is still somewhat messy and unclear.

The Democrats once again put together a series of amendments aimed at addressing these problems. We have put these amendments together with a great deal of assistance from people who have vast experience in working in the disability area. However, we will not be moving those amendments today. Instead, we will be looking towards moving them when the Senate next considers legislation which amends the Social Security Act 1991. We have decided to take this course because we wish to give the government that additional time it has requested to investigate the effects of these amendments. We also want to ensure that, because of the highly technical nature of the area we are dealing with, there are no unintended consequences associated with the changes we are proposing.

With this desire in mind, and as a result of the Democrats' negotiations with the government, the minister has also given us a commitment that she will establish a wide ranging review into the operation and effects of the tables we are considering here today and that she will report to the Senate on the outcome of this review in 18 months time. There is also a commitment for an interim report before that time. Whilst the Democrats strong ly believe the substance of our amendments are worthy of the Senate's support, we think it is in the best interests of those who would be most affected by any unintended consequences to take this extra time and proceed down the course I have just outlined.

The tables contained in schedule 16 of the bill are, as I said earlier, a vast improvement on the revised disability impairment tables the government presented us with during the spring session of parliament last year. It is good to see that the minister has taken the time to fix many of the problems which were contained in the previous tables. The Democrats will be supporting the schedule today. However, we will be continuing our discussions with the minister and her department and we will be looking at moving our amendments a little further down the track.

On the matter of rent assistance for adult family members living with their families in public housing, the Democrats have reserved judgment on this. The decision to remove rent assistance would appear to be fair, at least from a federal perspective. If the public housing rent is already being subsidised in effect by the state government and the tenants are not paying market rent then perhaps we agree it would appear to be generous to offer such people a further subsidy. Of course it must be understood that more and more public housing tenants are being shifted to market rents and state governments such as that in Victoria are making permanent tenure a thing of the past. This may well mean that the savings the federal government expects to make with this measure will not be long lasting.

As I understand it, around 44,000 people are expected to be affected by this legislation. I will be very interested in how accurate this figure turns out to be when the department has in place its data matching. The Democrats would like to know whether the changes will have the effect of encouraging family members to seek independent accommodation in order to comply with rent assistance criteria. If this did turn out to be a significant number then perhaps the legislation will do very little more than to increase the waiting lists and put further pressure on the private rental market.

We will listen to the debate on this matter and apply our usual test of fairness. I would have to say that, compared with the very severe cuts made to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement funds, some $200 million over the next four years, and the defunding of important advocacy groups such as National Shelter, this is likely to be a relatively small saving. We are interested to know what the real effects will be on those who are likely to be affected. In particular, it would appear that these people are doing much better than people on low incomes who are struggling to make ends meet in the private sector.

It would be my very strong preference to see this saving, whatever it turns out to be, channelled into provision of new social housing and a reversal of the trend, I might say started by the previous government, to reduce public housing stock to the point where only the most severely disadvantaged welfare tenants are housed. I look forward to the outcome of the current housing inquiry for a way forward on housing in this country. I hope, too, that the government will very seriously look at the recommendations from that inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the two senators for their contribution to this debate. I do feel that Senator Neal is labouring under a misapprehension about the maternity allowance which I would like to explain at this stage. The savings which you have identified in the first couple of years in the maternity allowance are simply a deferral of part of the existing maternity allowance to be provided when the evidence of immunisation is provided at the 18‐month level.

SPEECH.PARA: The total maternity allowance is increased overall, so it goes up to $950; it currently is $870. The savings are occasioned by the fact that the first payment will be $750 and the remaining $120 of the current payment has $80 added to it and it becomes $200 on the evidence of immunisation. In those circumstances, Senator, your concerns about making savings out of this matter are ill founded. I urge you to have a closer look at that.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to thank Senator Allison for her recognition of our consultative process which has been genuinely undertaken. It has been very wide ranging. It has improved the tables. I think she is right in saying that. I recognise that the question of minor impairments in particular is still an issue for the Democrats. I should inform the Senate that the Democrats' amendments have only been received by the government this week. I think the Democrats have taken a very responsible position in agreeing with the government to work with the department on further investigation of those amendments rather than moving them now.

We are always in danger in a very technical area of changing legislation in ways in which there are unforeseen circumstances that nobody would want. I think their agreement to allow the tables as arrived at after this substantial consultative process to go through in this legislation and still work with the department on any other measures that they believe need addressing is a responsible position and I thank them for it.

I certainly have given them an undertaking that a process for evaluating the experience with the impairment tables will be set in train, that an independent group will be established to oversee the evaluation, and that I will report to the parliament on the results of the evaluation within 18 months of the implementation of the tables. I seek leave to incorporate that undertaking in Hansard so it is clear to all that the government is committed to this process.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I undertake, subject to unamended passage of Schedule 19 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill 1997:
1. that a process for evaluating experience with the Impairment Tables be set in train,
2. that an independent group be established to oversee the evaluation; and
3. that I report to Parliament on the results of the evaluation within eighteen months of the implementation of the Tables.
JOCELYN NEWMAN
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Government amendments to this bill have been circulated in the form of requests. The amendments confer a power on a minister to make determinations which may be exercised in such a way as to exempt certain superannuation assets from the operation of the assets test and thereby increase expenditure under the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate in the past, by express resolution, has followed the principle that an amendment which confers a power on a minister which may be exercised in such a way as to increase expenditure is not an equivalent of an amendment increasing expenditure and therefore does not require a request.
I also note that the explanatory memorandum accompanying the amendments states that their financial impact is negligible. The amendments will therefore be treated as amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it really is impossible for the opposition to let this go through without comment at all. You may recall in many debates in the Senate that the opposition indicated their concern about the inclusion of superannuation in the assets test for those who are 55 and over. There has been a great deal of community concern about this entire issue of people who hit 55 and who, in many cases, have been in the work force for many years. Unfortunately, in this day of restructuring and changes within our industry, and high rates of unemployment, they may find themselves out of the work force and having to access the nest egg that they had put aside—their superannuation—at 55, despite the fact they do not intend to retire and are actively seeking to go back into the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: We always saw it as a fundamental breach of the contract between individuals accumulating superannuation and the government that, if they put aside funds for their superan nuation, they could retain it until they actually did retire. I must say it is very good to see that, by this amendment, this government is conceding that we were right and that, in fact, the minister should have the power to exclude superannuation and rollover assets that, as of last Saturday, were included in the assets test.

I suppose it is too much for the minister to have the good grace to actually stand up in this chamber and concede that that is the case, that the argument that we have put to her has in fact been proven to be correct. But I suppose we can be satisfied in knowing that those people who are over 55, who are seeking work, will not be forced to use their superannuation until, in fact, they do retire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the statements of Senator Neal. The minister will know the Democrats disagreed with this policy move, although I am not sure it really was a policy move. I think it was one of those government actions where they needed money or were looking to save money and it looked like a good idea at the time. What we said some months ago is being proven, and that is that this policy change is a nightmare and a mess. What the minister is acknowledging and underlining by this amendment—which we accept as a good amendment—is what we said previously, that the policy was wrong. It would be far better for the government to admit that the policy is wrong, go somewhere else to try and find the money, and restore the previous arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to repeat all of the things I said in previous debates. I remember that the minister did say that she thought I was disgusting in moving an amendment to a previous bill that fixed this up. Perhaps she will understand now why it was that we were raising these concerns. But let me say that we do support the amendment because it does go part of the way to recognising that the policy is wrong. The next step would be for the government to drop the policy altogether and restore the previous arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I utterly reject that the government has changed the policy on this. If honourable senators really believe that, then I am afraid they do not have much understanding of what these amendments mean. I always said that I would exempt, in special circumstances, income from superannuation that people could not access. That is the case and it is limited on a case by case basis to three main areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that I do not have that discretion in relation to the assets test. I could have left it at that, but I chose to make sure that people, particularly allowees, who could get an exemption on the income test could also get an exemption on the assets test. These amendments are simply to give me that discretion—that beneficial discretion—to exempt people who might be exempted under the income test but not under the assets test. I imagine you do not have a problem with that.

I think you misread more into these amendments in terms of policy. It is appropriate in these circumstances to make it quite clear that the policy is the one that the previous government administered until 1993 and that all governments have administered in respect of the age pension. What happened in 1993 was we gave a gap, if you like, between the age of 55 and age pension age for people to not have their superannuation included in the assets test, even though for most people over the age of 55 it is accessible to them.

The previous government thought it was not going to cost a lot to do that. In fact, the predictions about the cost to revenue were quite minor, but the reality was very large. So a responsible government, seeing what misuse was being made of it—in my view, by financial planners—moved as soon as possible to shut that option down so that we do not have the ridiculous situation where people who end up not being eligible for age pension at 61 or 65 because of their total assets are eligible for support from the taxpayer from the age of 55 onwards when they do have means that they can use to support themselves.

There has been no further change of policy. We have simply reverted back to what the previous government was doing up to 1993—the assets test included superannuation. It has gone back to that. There is no change to that. It is a pity if the water is so muddy that that very clear situation is not allowed to remain clear, because I think it does a disservice to the people we as senators are all sworn to look after.

The principal act simply does not always allow exclusion of a superannuation asset in the same circumstances that an exemption could be provided under the income test. Under the existing legislation I did not have the discretion to exempt those under the assets test but I did under the income test. We are remedying that situation so as to make it quite clear that people do not get free of one but caught on the other.

When the assets test was extended down to the age of 55, the opposition and, I believe, the other minor parties warned the government that this would bring into play superannuation and rollovers.
