TALK.START.PARA: —How do we deal with such ignorance? The whole measure that was originally introduced that Senator Neal is complaining about was all about superannuation and rollover funds. There was no question of suggesting anything otherwise. It was in the legislation that we amended. We were including superannuation—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Neal interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I think you do not begin to understand these matters. I'm sorry. Do your homework. The superannuation and rollover funds were excluded by your government from the assets test in 1993 and the amendment that went through last year put them back in. That is that.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that, in very limited circumstances, people who could not access their superannuation or their rollover would get an exemption from me using my discretion. I can do that and I will be doing that. I also want to make sure for the small number of cases, relatively speaking, that get caught instead on the assets test that I have the discretion to do the same for them. I presume you are not arguing against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Newman, I do not want to open the whole policy debate again. I have to make the comment that the Democrats and, I presume, the Labor Party support your amendments. That is not the problem. I do need to say that there is a disagreement on policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' disagreement on policy is that, no matter what the Labor Party did in 1993, after 1993 and up to the present time there has been a sea change in the whole approach to superannuation. That is why going back to 1993 is fairly irrelevant from our point of view in this debate. It does not apply. Superannuation since 1993 and in the intervening years has been changed significantly by a multiparty approach.

The disappointment I have in all of this is that unilaterally the government has denied that multiparty approach which we had for the last few years, is taking a decision which goes against all of the discussions and all of that multiparty agreement which we had, and is doing something with which we now in a policy sense disagree fundamentally.

BREAK.PARA: However, certainly we agree that these amendments are going to remedy in a small way part of the problem you caused. But, Minister, I think you are going to find that you have to revisit this and that there are going to have to be further amendments to give you further discretion to exempt further issues in terms of superannuation as we go along and find further problems and further anomalies in the action that you have taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to congratulate Senator Woodley. He is much more perceptive about the overall goals involved in superannuation and its application in this country than is Senator Newman. The changes in 1993 have to be looked at in context, together with, for example, the introduction of the superannuation guarantee which ensures the spread of superannuation to the overwhelming majority of the Australian work force—I think the latest figures are about 89 per cent. The objective was to allow all Australian workers the choice—that word is often overused by this government—of having a decent retirement income, and I stress the words `retirement income'. Where we differ philosophically is this money grab by your government—I think it is over $125 million a year—in effect forcing people to retire when they have turned 55 and forcing them to draw down on moneys that are meant for their retirement, not forcing them to draw down on the moneys when they reach 65. That is the fundamental difference in our approach.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me what we have here is a mismatch in approach between your attitude and the attitude of the Treasurer. Everything we have seen from the government, except for this measure, shows the government is closing off access to superannuation. In the last budget announcement, the government announced a phase‐in of access for superannuation from 55 to 60. Whether you agree or disagree with that approach, 55 to 60 is going to become the age at which you access superannuation. This measure that is being discussed is in contradiction of that approach—it is a very strong contradiction. The government has not funded and has again broken its commitment to the co‐contribution, the government funding of superannuation.

Senator Ellison is well aware from the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that there were three issues we dealt with in respect to closing off access to superannuation that the government announced in the budget and to which we will be moving a disallowance next week. It is the basic contradiction that you have in regard to superannuation.

We have debated the issue extensively on two occasions: one was a win for you, one was a loss for you. Unfortunately, the final outcome has been a loss to those Australian workers who reach the age of 55 and are going to be affected by this dreadful measure. They are not all millionaires—that is your usual excuse, cutting millionaires out of the system. Certainly in the hundreds and thousands of people who have contacted the opposition, I have not sighted too many millionaires. I do not want to keep the time of the Senate unnecessarily on the central principle. We have debated it before. I conclude by saying that Senator Newman got it wrong in her public announcement and press release. What we are doing today, much to your embarrassment and to your party's embarrassment, is correcting an announcement which you made incorrectly by a public press release which caused a significant amount of confusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chaos.
—Chaos and a significant amount of confusion amongst financial institutions.
—In your mind.

—It was not in my mind. You ring up the AMPs, the National Mutuals, the financial managers and advisers, a number of whom contacted my office asking us what on earth was going on with your press release. I am sure you got the same response in your office. You can laugh and smile but it was a very serious issue. What we are dealing with here today is a piece of legislation to correct a false statement which you made in a press release which grossly misled the financial community and left them wondering as to their confidence in you and your ability to handle this particular issue. That is what we are dealing with today. You should admit your error and apologise not just to the financial institutions—I am not so much worried about them because they can get their own legal advice—but to the many tens of thousands of people affected by the measures who were misled by your advice and confused by your public announcements.
—Senator Ferguson can help; he was at the public hearings.

—That is right. I hope Senator Ferguson gets a promotion. Certainly Senator Newman needs some assistance in this area. I hope Senator Ferguson is putting Senator Newman right on this issue at the moment and the concern that was caused amongst people approaching the age of 55 and over the age of 55 in the general financial community that were seriously inconvenienced by Senator Newman's error. I put to the Senate: why can she not be honest and admit she made an error? I put that on the record for the various parties that were adversely affected by her public comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to amend the bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 6, item 1, page 28 (lines 6 and 7), TO BE OPPOSED .
(2) Schedule 6, item 2, page 28 (lines 8 to 10), TO BE OPPOSED .
(3) Schedule 6, item 3, page 28 (lines 11 to 14), TO BE OPPOSED .
(6) Schedule 6, item 6, page 28 (lines 22 and 23), TO BE OPPOSED .
(8) Schedule 6, item 9, page 29 (lines 9 to 11), TO BE OPPOSED .

These amendments relate to schedule 6. The arrangements being put in place create an anomaly which can be easily avoided. The issues revolve around current portability arrangements for primary income payments, and whether or not an income support payment can be made while a person is overseas. As a general rule, pensions like the disability support pension, or a wife pension, can continue to be paid for up to 12 months when a person is overseas. Allowances, on the other hand, like mature age, widow, partner and parenting allowance and, in some limited circumstances, sickness allowance, can continue to be paid for up to three months when a person is overseas.

These arrangements recognise that it may be necessary to leave the country temporarily for medical treatment, to visit relatives and for other necessary reasons. The shorter portability arrangements for allowees generally recognise that people of work force age are less likely to go overseas for longer periods as they are looking for work in Australia. Under the arrangements being proposed by the government, higher rates of family payment will be able to be made to people when they or their children go overseas for up to two months. Previously, higher rates of family payment could be made for up to three months if a parent was absent from Australia, but higher rates of family payment could not be made for any time that a child was outside Australia.

A classic example of this situation is where a person on a low income, and in receipt of a parenting allowance, and her child, leave Australia temporarily for lengthy medical treatment for the child. The parenting allowee could continue to receive parenting allowance for three months, but the higher rate of family payment would stop after two months.

A woman leaving the country in these very difficult circumstances—a sick child seeking treatment—could come back and find that she was overpaid family payment for up to five weeks and may be required to pay that money back, or, alternatively, she would receive the lower rate and find that she does not have the income that she expected.

The Labor amendments line up the portability arrangements for family payment and allowances, removing an anomaly at negligible cost to the government. This involves an extraordinarily small group of people, but, of course, however small the group, we must still concern ourselves with those difficult situations—those people, in those circumstances, who are away for between eight and 13 weeks. I am not sure whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is aware of the cost—she might wish to advise us—but I suspect it is an extraordinarily small amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your proposal?
—The cost of that proposal.
—Yours or the government's?
—Ours.
—I am advised by the department that it is $3.9 million. Can I make that clear: that is for all of your changes in that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the Labor amendments. Rather than read into the record a letter from Welfare Rights, I seek leave to table this letter, which explains the position that we are taking.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, it is estimated that the Labor Party amendments to schedule 6 as a whole would cost an additional $3.9 million a year. In saying that, I wish to speak to the totality of schedule 6, because the proposals in amendments 4 and 5 have to be seen in the context of the whole schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: You will recognise, Mr Temporary Chairman, that this government has acted to correct an anomaly that existed under the previous government. That anomaly resulted in more than the minimum family payment not being payable in respect of a child as soon as the child left Australia. We believed that that was very harsh. It meant that no payment could be made, even if a child left Australia for urgent medical treatment, for example, or if they were on a short sporting trip with their school, or a choir trip. There were sad stories of children whose last dying wish was to go to Disneyland—and their families, too, got cut off from the family payment during the period they were away. We thought that, for the small number of people involved, it was desirable to turn it around, even though we were in a difficult financial position in terms of the national budget.

BREAK.PARA: The government proposal acts to address that anomaly, but at the same time I believe it is taking a balanced approach to those families affected, as well as the cost to taxpayers as a whole in helping those families.

I oppose the direction in which the opposition and the Democrats are going, which is to increase to 13 weeks the length of time during which a family can get family payment overseas and, at the same time, increase to 13 weeks the amount that the more than minimum family payment can be paid when a child goes overseas. We have taken the entitlement for a child to leave the country to a period of eight weeks. In doing that, we have brought back the time that payments can be received while the parents are out of the country from 13 weeks to eight weeks. So it is now a consistent period of eight weeks.

If we were to accept the opposition amendments, everybody could be getting paid by the Australian taxpayer for 13 weeks while they are out of the country, but that would be at an additional $3.9 million. We think we have dealt with the circumstances which we inherited from the previous government in a fair way—fair to the families and fair to the taxpayers who have to be taken into account as well—so we would not be inclined to accept the amendments proposed by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —We obviously are supporting this change proposed by the government for exactly the reasons that the minister has stated; that is, it did create very heart‐rending situations where children, who were either going overseas as maybe a last wish or to receive much needed medical attention, were having their payments reduced or taken away from them.

SPEECH.PARA: Our additional amendments are really just to ensure that, in making that change, there is not this anomaly developing between two months and three months, between the parents and the allowance and the family payment. We feel that it is very important, as I stated previously in the second reading debate, to ensure that there is as simple a system as possible, more particularly for the recipients than for the department. We believe that these amendment that we are discussing and the next amendments that we are proposing will ensure that the most simple system is in place, bearing in mind the changes being proposed by the government on this issue, which we support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that items 1 to 3, 6 and 9 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 6, item 4, page 28 (line 17), omit "8", substitute "13".
(5) Schedule 6, item 5, page 28 (line 21), omit "8", substitute "13".
(7) Schedule 6, item 7, page 28 (line 24) to page 29 (line 6), omit "8" (wherever occurring), substitute "13".
I will not speak further. Essentially these amendments form the balance of the necessary amendments to schedule 6 to put in place the changes which I have already outlined.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Schedule 19, item 2, page 110 (line 18), at the end of subsection (3AC), add:

PARA.TAB: , unless the person shares the premises with the person who pays, or is liable to pay, Government rent in respect of those premises and the person's income has been taken into account in calculating the amount of Government rent payable in respect of those premises.

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 19, item 5, page 111 (line 6), at the end of subsection (4A), add:

PARA.TAB: , unless the person shares the premises with the person who pays, or is liable to pay, Government rent in respect of those premises and the person's income has been taken into account in calculating the amount of Government rent payable in respect of those premises.

SPEECH.PARA: The negative effects that arise from changes to the rental assistance were discussed at some length in the speeches on the second reading by all parties, particularly by me. Essentially what it means is that young people who are living within a family which is in public housing will no longer receive the rental assistance that they were previously entitled to. This is a particularly harsh change, bearing in mind that the income of such young people will already have been taken into account by the public housing authority in determining the rent that is payable by that family. We believe that, by putting into place this measure proposed by the government, we are double punishing those young people. We see it as a very harsh and unjust provision. So amendment Nos 9 and 10 have the effect of reversing this position and allow young people living with their families in public housing to continue to receive rental assistance where they are otherwise entitled to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important that I put on the record at this stage what this measure really is about. We are intending to remove the entitlement to rent assistance of people who live in public housing but do not pay rent directly to the state or public housing authority, except in those circumstances where they live in public housing where market rents are being charged.

SPEECH.PARA: We are doing that because public housing tenants do receive subsidised accommodation from the state and territory housing authorities. Some of the money for that subsidy comes from the Commonwealth government as well. They currently charge rent at between 20 and 25 per cent of income. Accordingly, public housing tenants are not entitled to rent assistance. But the legislation does not preclude the payment of rent assistance to a person who is paying rent for living in public housing but is not paying rent directly to the state or territory authority. We believe it is anomalous that rent assistance may be payable to a person who is living in government subsidised accommodation. The amendments remove the entitlement to rent assistance of any person who pays rent for living in premises in which the public housing tenant receives subsidised accommodation.

Where subletting is authorised by the state or territory, the state or territory housing authorities assess additional rent at subsidised levels for each subtenant. These additional rents are generally low enough to preclude the subtenants from entitlement to rent assistance. But nothing precludes the payment of rent assistance to subtenants who are living in public housing and paying rent to the primary tenant. They are often friends and relatives of the public housing tenant, although they may not be. Often, you will find that subtenants will be paying more rent to the primary tenant than the total amount payable to the state or territory housing authority. That is clearly a case of double subsidisation by the Commonwealth for people living in public housing.

Subtenants will not be affected by this measure if they live in public housing where market or unsubsidised rent is being charged. In these circumstances, there would be no element of double subsidisation. Those are the reasons that the government has seen fit to take the action that we have been taking; therefore, we could not support the opposition amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am quite astonished by your proposition that those who are subletting in public housing often pay more than the total rent that is payable. Minister, could you table any evidence you have that indicates this?
—I will wait for the response by the minister to the quite reasonable question that has been put to her by the shadow minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —May I first of all make it clear that that is the advice from my department. I do not have the details of it here, but I could provide it for you as soon as it is possible. That is the advice that has been given to me for the debate.

—That is a highly inadequate response. It seems to be very much in line with this government's view on all issues. You assume that a group of people—who are generally unemployed and often have an unemployed child living with them—somehow have some secret source of funds which they use in some way to cheat and rort the system. I am continually offended by these bald statements that families living in these circumstances, extra ordinarily difficult ones, are cheats and rorters—particularly when, on almost every occasion that evidence is sought, the minister is unable to provide it. I think her failure to provide that evidence indicates, in fact, that it is not a true statement. I believe it would be fair to allow young people whose income has been taken into account in determining the amount of rent paid in public housing to still be able to receive rental assistance.

—I am inclined to support the amendments. The amendments go to the question of double counting. To my way of thinking, the amendments are self-explanatory. Senator Neal explained those amendments in the second reading debate. In all events, I have not heard anything that would convince me otherwise than to support those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be unfortunate if the Senate were to take the action that it is foreshadowing. I am not in the custom of coming into the Senate and misusing advice from my department. I do not have the figures here, Senator Harradine. I will try to get those as soon as possible. I have advised the Senate based on the advice from my department, which I read out to you, as you no doubt noticed.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that my department has been doing a considerable amount of work over recent months with the state housing authorities, which are also concerned at what they believe is a fairly substantial level of non-reporting of additional income in a household. The two levels of government have been trying to work together on that issue. There is also an issue for my department which has seen a degree of, shall I say, suspected—and I think in some cases it has been proven—misuse of receipts from one member of a household to another for rent that was not, in fact, paid but which enables, under the current arrangements, rent assistance to be paid by my department.

Unless these issues are able to be worked through at the state and the federal level, unless there is good cooperation between those two levels of government, the taxpayer is the one who suffers. We believe that the right and proper thing is that people do declare the amount of household income. It then means only a very small increase in the rent charged to the public housing tenant, but it means that the affairs between the tenants and the state governments are on a more honest and open basis.

We also would like to have the ability to be sure of that at the state level. Currently we are paying rent assistance to people who are, we believe, sometimes not even paying the rent. They are simply providing a rent receipt. I have that advice on a first-hand basis. I have talked to my regional officers around the country, and they have shown me rent receipts which they have found to be fraudulent. This is all part of that bigger picture, Senator. I do not have the statistics to justify the advice I just gave you on that particular point, but the advice is consistent with the problems in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would just like to say that that proves the minister does not have the evidence. Secondly, her whole argument seems to be based on the fact that there are examples of fraud in this particular situation. Therefore, you have to punish everyone, even those who are honest. If there is fraud, let the minister and the department use the resources they have available to make the prosecutions and cut off the benefits in accordance with their real incomes. Do not punish the honest by putting this measure in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had some advice brought to me which I have not had an opportunity to deal with yet. I understand that the situation is that if a subtenant in a public tenancy has that income declared to the state housing department and it is an appropriately small level of rent—as appropriate for, say, one room in a dwelling—it would not attract rent assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is historic. That term is often misused in this place. However, these bills genuinely do represent a significant milestone in the financial management of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The original Audit Act of 1901 was the fourth act passed by this parliament. When that law was passed we lived in a very different world. Since that time, of course, there have been two world wars—

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a few smaller ones.

—Yes, and a few smaller disputes, unfortunately. There has been a whole range of other massive economic and social changes up until this time. Certainly the world was fundamentally a different place to live in 1901. But, just as the world has changed massively over the course of this century, so have the needs concerning financial management, accountability and auditing in the Commonwealth sector. This legislation seeks to modernise, streamline and improve the existing financial management framework, and is supported by the Labor opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the intrinsic merits of the legislation, the package of bills is supported because it is an initiative of the former Labor government. It is to the shame of this government that they have delayed the passage of the bills during this parliament. We have waited more than a year—it is 18 months—since they were elected to have them debated in the Senate.

Many senators would be aware of the fairly tortuous history of this package. However, it is important to put on the public record the origin of the bills. It was Joint Committee of Public Accounts report No. 296 which suggested reform of the Audit Act. That was released in 1989. The then Labor government responded to this report in 1989, accepting inter alia this recommendation. The complex policy development and drafting process was completed and the legislation was introduced into the House in 1994. It was considered in detail by the JCPA, which issued its advisory report No. 331 in September 1994.

Unfortunately, it was not possible to get agreement on the final design of the package—it is interesting how the wheels of history turn in regard to this legislation. The now government, then opposition, indulged in what can only be described as the most monumentally opportunistic behaviour in the Senate. As a result, the legislation lapsed when the parliament was prorogued before the last election. It is this opportunistic behaviour by the now government that I wish to make some comments about.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) wrote to the new chair of the JCPA, the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), on 12 August 1996 requesting that the JCPA consider how the functional independence of the Auditor‐General could be improved in the context of the government finalising the details of this package of legislation.This resulted in JCPA report No. 346 being issued in October 1996—about 150 reports later we got another report. The now government introduced the bills on 12 December 1996.

It is not surprising but it is disappointing that the current government has changed many of the positions that it vigorously argued here in the Senate—and in the House, of course, but certainly in the Senate, as I recall—when it was in opposition. They have suddenly seen the wisdom of Labor's proposals, yet they have not had the decency to acknowledge this. I will return to some examples of this later in my remarks.

In relation to financial management, there are two different categories of entity within the Commonwealth sector. Either a body has the legal capacity in its own right to acquire ownership of assets, including money, or it may function only as a financial and custodial agent for the legal entity of the Commonwealth. Whether a body falls into a particular category is dependent upon the legislation which establishes it. The legislation package consolidates the regulatory accountability framework of each of these two categories into separate bills. Literally, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1996 applies to those entities in the first category, and the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1996 applies to the second category. The proposed bills will provide a modern, appropriate framework which specifies the responsibilities and powers necessary for the efficient, effective and ethical use of resources available to the Commonwealth.

I will now turn broadly to the specific matters covered by each bill. The Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1996 maintains the central role of the finance minister in the functioning of the constitutional treasury of the Commonwealth. The minister retains the sole power to agree appropriate banking arrangements for public money and its investment. The current legislation is silent on the issue of management performance. The new FMA legislation seeks to place responsibility specifically on chief executives of agencies. The CEOs are to be required to manage their agencies efficiently, effectively and ethically. They are required to implement fraud control plans and establish audit committees.

The Minister for Finance will also be able to request financial information more regularly than annually from agencies to ensure better supervisory standards. The chief executives are permitted to subdelegate to officials. This is designed to achieve a major strengthening of the financial framework. The rationale behind this is that the CEOs are better placed than the finance minister to manage the specific tasks of officials. The bill is virtually indistinguishable from the one proposed by Labor, and we are certainly not going to oppose that legislation.

Turning to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1996 , Commonwealth authorities and companies are generally regulated by part XI of the Audit Act. Since this is to be repealed, replacement provisions are needed. Whilst most authorities are regulated under the Audit Act, only about two-thirds of these bodies are currently caught under the general legislation, with the rest having their own financial, reporting and auditing provisions.

Similarly, the memoranda and articles of association of many Commonwealth companies contain their own requirements in so far as accountability to ministers is concerned. The new bill proposes to replace these diverse accountability requirements with a single set of core requirements. Many of the requirements are modelled on comparable areas of the Corporations Law as well as best practice applying to individual authorities. The standardisation is a major reform which should both strengthen and simplify the current regulatory requirements.

Again, this bill is virtually indistinguishable from the one proposed by Labor, and we are certainly supporting it. The major change is the strengthening of the penalties applying to office holders of Commonwealth authorities and/or companies to include a civil penalty regime in addition to the criminal penalty regime. Labor supports this initiative.

I will now consider the Auditor‐General Bill 1996 . Whilst each piece of this legislation package is significant, the Auditor‐General Bill is the key element of the package. The mere existence of a separate Auditor-General bill is recognition of the unique position of the A-G in the constitutional, institutional arrangements of this nation. The unique position of the A-G arises because of the unique duties of the A-G, the unique responsibilities of that office, and the fundamental importance to effective and accountable democracy that a fearless, truly independent watchdog provides.

Subclause 8(1) of the bill proposes to designate the A-G as an `independent officer of the Parliament'. Labor has no problem with this approach. Indeed, we think it is appropriate to recognise the uniqueness of the position. But let it be clearly understood that this change is cosmetic and meaningless. Indeed, the following provision in the bill, subclause 8(2), specifically states:
. . . There are no implied functions, powers, rights, immunities or obligations arising from the Auditor-General being an independent officer of the Parliament.
So the designation of the A-G is utterly meaningless in terms of the functions of the office. It is mere window dressing without any substance—like so many other policies of this government.

The establishment of the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority is a more substantial step towards ensuring the independence of the A-G. Currently, the ANAO exists as an administrative body only. It is, therefore, technically at the mercy of the executive of the day and could be abolished at any time. With the passage of this legislation, that unsatisfactory state of affairs will have been ended and the ANAO will have the protection of this parliament.

I referred earlier to government Liberal‐National Party hypocrisy. The bill contains numerous examples of where the government has displayed what could only be the most breathtaking hypocrisy whilst in opposition. There are a number of issues which were vital to the coalition before the last election, on which they have now been utterly exposed as opportunists because they have altered or completely reversed their previous positions. I find it hard to recall any package of legislation where I have seen such a number of U‐turns.

I present some examples. The Senate amended the Labor legislation to ensure that the A-G could not be appointed unless at least two‐thirds of the JCPA agreed with the appointment. The government's bill proposes that a simple majority should be necessary to agree to the appointment of the A-G. Obviously, the change to a majority vote of the JCPA keeps the power with the executive and, because the coalition have a majority on the JCPA, they will obviously do exactly what they are instructed to do by the executive.

The Senate also amended the Labor legislation to allow for consultation between the A-G and the chair of the JCPA where the A-G wishes to suppress the disclosure of sensitive information. Clause 37 of the bill currently proposes that the A-G should not be allowed to disclose information if he or she is of the opinion disclosure would be contrary to the public interest or if the Attorney-General has issued a certificate to suppress the disclosure of information.

Just imagine what would have happened if Labor had proposed this type of secrecy regime when in government. It would have been vigorously denounced by members of the present government, but now they are running mute on the issue, when they are proposing an absolute blanket of secrecy from an officer of the parliament to any member of parliament.

BREAK.PARA: Labor does have some concerns about this provision. Current government members were very keen to ensure that the Auditor‐General was able to conduct performance audits on Commonwealth GBEs or any of their subsidiaries and amended the 1994 bill in the Senate to that effect, except for the partly privatised GBEs. The current bill basically adopts Labor's model, which involves a request from either the Minister for Finance or the JCPA before a performance audit of a GBE can be undertaken. We agree with the proposal, but again I condemn the hypocrisy of the now government in opportunistically changing its views to agree with the previous government.

I do not want to reflect too much on the career of former Senator Jim Short, but I can recall his contributions in the areas that I have referred to today. If he were still in the Senate and still Assistant Treasurer, we would certainly be demanding that he come into this chamber and provide an explanation for his government's U‐turn, but he is currently examining the U‐turn of Eastern European economies in his new position with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and I wish him well in those new duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —And wish the Eastern Europeans well, too.

—I certainly wish the Eastern Europeans well, and I certainly wish Jim Short well in scrutinising the U‐turns in their economies. He is fortunate not to be here today to explain the U‐turns in this legislation, given his public record in the Senate Hansard . But enough of former Senator Short.

BREAK.PARA: The final bill in the package contains the myriad consequential and transitional provisions which arise from a rewrite of the Audit Act. The major initiatives in this bill are the provisions which increase the role of the JCPA. The JCPA is to become the audit committee of the parliament. The JCPA's additional responsibilities will include considering and reporting on the operations and resources of the Australian National Audit Office, examining the draft budget of the ANAO and subsequent reporting of recommendations to the finance minister and both houses of parliament, and determining the audit priorities of the parliament and advising the Auditor-General of those priorities. Labor has no objection to these proposals and we will be supporting them.

In my concluding remarks, I just state that this is very important legislation and Labor will be giving swift passage to it. The comprehensiveness and flexibility of the new provisions should provide a good framework for Commonwealth financial management well into the next century. It should have been a lot higher on the government's priority list, rather than being relegated to something that will be advanced almost 18 months after the election.

I understand that Senator Campbell is dealing with this legislation, and I would request that he at least make some attempt to explain the difference between his party's position now from when they were in opposition. I know it is very difficult to do. I know you have to explain why Senator Short put a totally different position some time ago and why you have reversed that position today, but we would like some attempt from you to explain the number of U‐turns, the reasons for the U-turns and the monumental hypocrisy that the government is now displaying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right, Senator Sherry. It would make the consideration of these bills relatively entertaining if Senator Ian Campbell did explain that hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: Few bills in this place have had a longer history than these particular bills. They represent an essential reform. I am pleased they finally made it to the Senate and I want to congratulate the government for bringing them forward. The four bills in front of us will replace the Audit Act 1901, which was amongst the very first acts of the new federal parliament after Federation.

The Democrats have strongly supported this overhaul of the audit bills. We have long supported a strong and active mandate for the Commonwealth Auditor-General and for all auditors-general. Accountability is essential to democracy, but we must recognise that accountability does have a cost, and that cost includes a range of measures to ensure that all spending of the government is legal, authorised, efficient, transparent, open and honest. That is why we have an audit office and why this package of bills is so long overdue.

I wish to commend the coalition government for bringing the bills forward, although I should note that I was disappointed that the government was unable to give the bills sufficient priority to allow them to be debated and passed prior to the commencement of this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —For Christ's sake!
—Giving all that time to a private member's bill to overturn territory legislation, for instance, might have been sacrificed in this cause.
—We wanted to. But we could not get agreement to sit for another few hours last year.
—That is not my fault.
—It is not mine either; it is not the government's fault.

—And you would know it is not mine. The government's attitude to financial accountability after 18 months in power can be contrasted with the previous government, which took five years to develop a package of audit bills. Even then, the draft Labor legislation was a poor replacement, we thought, for the original set of bills.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the determined intervention of the Democrats in 1994, following the outrageous lack of accountability by then minister Ros Kelly in the sports rorts affair, that forced the government to revise its auditing approach, rejig this package and provide a proper and comprehensive mandate for the Auditor-General. I should note and approve the contribution of the then finance minister, Kim Beazley, in moving quickly to improve the legislative package and the financial accountability measures then in place. I should also note and approve the strident defence of the role of the audit office by the then Auditor-General, John Taylor, who publicly reiterated the importance to our democracy and all democracies of proper accountability regimes.

But even then, the Labor government, when this package of bills was last before the Senate in 1995, refused to agree to a range of amendments moved by the Democrats and the coalition designed to close the gaps still left in the Auditor-General's mandate. I would like to particularly acknowledge the resource of Senator Cheryl Kernot and Senator Brian Gibson in working to improve the legislation at that time.

I am pleased that, in the resurrected legislation before us, the government has accepted the vast bulk of the amendments pursued by the Democrats and the coalition two years ago. I am disappointed that the coalition has changed its mind on the importance of ensuring that the Auditor is able to report fully to parliament and not be restricted by executive interference. This was an important issue in the 1995 debate and has been again identified by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee as a vital issue. I will be moving amendments in the committee stage of the bill to ensure that the Auditor‐General does preserve a full mandate to report to parliament on financial accountability issues and be unrestrained by ministerial executive interference.

As I said, this package of bills does have a very long history. It dates back to a 1989 Public Accounts Committee inquiry into the office of the Auditor‐General. That inquiry found that the office of the Auditor‐General was understaffed, subject to unnecessary interference by the executive arm of government and needed stronger legislation and parliamentary support. This call seemed to be ignored for many years, despite repeated calls from the Auditor-General for a stronger statement of his role as a servant of the parliament and for adequate funding arrangements.

It took the dramatic events surrounding the Ros Kelly sports rorts affair for Senator Cheryl Kernot and the Democrats to break open the log jam holding up the bill and set these bills on the path of providing a more comprehensive mandate for the Auditor-General to audit all government departments, authorities and business enterprises. Once again, the role of the coalition in advancing this cause is much appreciated.

This is provided for in the new Auditor‐General Bill 1996 . But the mandate of the Auditor-General has been expanded in this bill as opposed to the 1995 bill, picking up issues raised by the Democrats, the coalition and others in 1995. These include strengthening the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament by establishing the Joint Committee of Public Accounts as the audit committee of parliament, with a role in setting the audit priorities of the audit office and with the ability to direct the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of government business enterprises; extending the term of the Auditor-General to 10 years and giving the Joint Committee of Public Accounts a say in the appointment process through a veto right on the appointment of the Auditor‐General; confirming that the Auditor-General has unfettered access to intelligence and security agencies reports and matters of confidentiality; and strengthening the Auditor-General's position with regard to the potential for unwarranted interference by the executive.

The Democrats particularly welcome the changes to the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to establish it as an audit committee of parliament. The establishment of an audit committee of parliament was first recommended by the JCPA in 1989 and has long been supported by the Auditor-General to better reflect the role of the Auditor as the servant of the Commonwealth parliament.

As a result of the Democrats' accountability measures agreed to with the previous government in 1994, the former government moved to establish an audit committee by resolution. It was our view that the function of the audit committee should be reflected in legislation, which was one of the items of disagreement in 1995.

I note that not just has the JCPA formally been given an audit oversight role in this legislation, but the Public Accounts Committee Act is to be amended to expand the number of senators on the committee by one, to be filled according to the practice of the Senate. What that means to us is that a senator from the crossbenches will be appointed to the JCPA, thereby reducing the government majority on that committee. I note, however, Senator Sherry's caution on the committee structure, and I look forward to hearing his views on that in the committee stage of the debate.

Undoubtedly, the biggest disappointment in this 1997 bill is clause 37, which does have the effect of unilaterally and absolutely restricting the ability of the Auditor-General to report to parliament if the Attorney-General certifies that the matter is sensitive. The list of reasons for what is sensitive is simply too long, and the power of the Attorney-General—a politician—to nobble the Auditor‐Generals' reporting to parliament is absolute. In particular, clause 37 could be used to prevent the Auditor-General reporting on Commonwealth-state financial relations on any matter involving contracting out, tendering, government business enterprises, payments to private companies or on the basis that the information may `unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person'.

Section 37(3) then goes on to limit the privileges of the Senate by stating that the Auditor-General cannot be compelled by parliament to override the Attorney-General's direction. This device will allow governments to avoid public scrutiny of potentially all of their relations with the private sector and prevent any embarrassing little shady deals or improper actions coming to public light. For the Senate to allow such a provision to pass into law would be an absolute outrage and a travesty of accountability, and I for one will mark very carefully the actions of the Labor Party when that matter comes to debate.

The finance department, through the current government as it did through the former government, argues that this provision largely replicates subsection 48(5) of the current Audit Act. The department claims that this provision has not been controversial and that no certificate under those provisions has ever been issued—in which case, why do we need it? That may be the case, but the level of contracting out, of commercialisation of government services, of tendering for government services and of general commercial relations between the government and the private sector has risen dramatically in the last three years under competition policy reforms, particularly since the change of government. This provision, we believe, is now a potentially massive hole in the accountability regime, and it could easily be used to avoid scrutiny on a wide range of deals.

Such a provision that the government is suggesting in this act would have prevented any public reporting of any audit reports on WA Inc. style deals within the government sector. As a Western Australian, I am well aware how often the commercial-in-confidence and the secrecy defence was wheeled out in parliament during those debates. It is disgraceful, disgusting and unacceptable to lack that kind of accountability. Once again I say to Labor, `Be careful that you don't let something through in the idea that you might end up in government yourselves and want to participate in that kind of larking.'

I am extremely disappointed by the coalition's backflip in government on this issue. In 1995, Senator Brian Gibson and Senator Jim Short were very strong opponents of these restrictions to the parliament's powers to receive reports, and I will be interested to see whether Senator Gibson turns up in the committee stage later on. There are senators from all sides of the chamber, including the major parties, who are very disturbed indeed about clause 37.

The Australian Democrats will also be making a financial accountability amendment to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1996 . The Democrats recently proposed amendments to the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 which were designed to have the effect of guaranteeing accountability through an independent Auditor‐General to the public of Victoria, and to the public of all the states and territories. Those amendments were designed to maintain what we regard as the desirable status quo in terms of safeguarding the independent auditing functions currently in place in the states.

The Labor Party, despite strong support in some sections of the party, wimped out on our amendment despite indicating in the debate how uncomfortable they were with the Victorian review of the Audit Act, and the consequential diminution of the Victorian Auditor‐General's position. They also indicat ed how uncomfortable they were with the removal of the Victorian Auditor‐General's direct control over his department, and the ramifications of this change in terms of public accountability. But their executive side got the better of them, and they overturned our amendment.

However, Senator Sherry indicated during that debate that the Labor Party would support such an amendment to this package of audit legislation. I regard it as second best, and I do not regard it as an appropriate way to amend this set of bills. I am looking forward to seeing if they adhere to that undertaking when I put up that amendment to this bill.

We need to ensure that the Auditor‐General has the full powers to investigate and report on all commercial dealings involving government money. To allow a member of the cabinet to prevent him reporting on such matters must be vigorously and stridently denied by any member of the Senate who believes that government accountability is important.

In closing, Minister, I again congratulate you and your government on presenting this package of bills to the parliament. We are delighted to see it before us. Our amendments will be relatively few and will all focus on accountability and the few issues you know are dear to our hearts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1996 and other audit bills are being dealt with at lunchtime during consideration of non‐controversial bills, over time it has become glaringly obvious to people that this package of audit bills has been anything but non‐controversial.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens (WA) agreed to the second reading debate on this package of bills being held at lunchtime today because there has certainly been movement towards addressing a number of those controversial issues. Also, there is no doubt that it is an issue which has been canvassed on a number of other occasions. So we are not dealing with a new package of bills for which there has been no debate in this chamber before. That is why we are prepared to make an exception, and it should not be seen as a precedent for other packages of otherwise highly controversial bills.

As we are all aware, this package of bills is designed to replace the Audit Act 1901, and it flowed from the previous government's response to the 1989 Joint Committee of Public Accounts report on the Auditor‐General entitled The Auditor‐General: Ally of the People and Parliament. It is an important reform and, in a similar vein to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 which we have just debated, provides a framework that facilitates proper scrutiny of government decisions and procedures. This could be even more important than it has been in the past, as we are moving towards greater outsourcing and competition policy.

I have concerns in three broad areas: the ability to scrutinise the activities of government business enterprises; the need for Commonwealth authorities and companies to have some form of requirement that they act in the public interest; and, finally, the very important question of parliamentary committees having access to organisations in receipt of money appropriated by the parliament.

Senators will remember that we have just recently debated a package of bills in relation to the Productivity Commission. That was voted down by the Senate. But one of the issues that came up in that debate was competitive tendering and competitive neutrality. That means that, in effect, there will be money going to the private sector for providing services. Taxpayers' money will be used to provide certain services to a whole range of areas which have not been provided with those services before. There will be budget allocations going out to the private sector in many areas.

The issue of whether the Auditor‐General has the ability to conduct a general performance audit of a government business enterprise as part of a general examination of a whole or part of the public sector at any time without needing any prior approval is, I believe, absolutely crucial.

It is my belief that this parliament must have absolute faith in the ability of the Auditor‐General to act appropriately. It must provide the Auditor‐General with the independence and framework that facilitates the proper independent auditing of government business enterprises, as well as Commonwealth companies and authorities, particularly in the context of broader sectoral examination. As a consequence, I will be moving an amendment to clause 18 of the Auditor‐General Bill 1996 to eliminate the current exclusion in respect of government business enterprises.

With respect to the ability of the Auditor‐General to conduct a performance audit of a government business enterprise, I am prepared to accept the qualification in clause 16(2) and clause 17(2), which give the Joint Committee of Public Accounts an audit role in requesting audits. I will, however, be watching the operation of these sections with interest.

As indicated earlier, I am also keen to see that Commonwealth authorities and companies are required to act in the public interest. The definition I have incorporated in the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1996 is an adaptation of a definition I have attempted to incorporate in the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill and the competition policy reform bills. I believe it is fundamentally important that legislation which provides the broad framework in which the public sector operates should incorporate a broad requirement to act in the public interest.

We need to be reminded that issues such as equity, efficiency, ecological sustainability and regional concerns have a crucial impact on the daily lives of Australians, and that those who determine and interpret public policy must act consistently with those overriding principles.

Finally, I will be moving a second reading amendment which reaffirms the right of parliamentary committees to require representatives of a body in receipt of money appropriated by the parliament, or subject to any direction or control by the Commonwealth, to appear before those committees. As other senators will be aware, I have been concerned about this issue for some time, and I feel it is important that such an amendment reaffirming the rights of parliamentary committees is passed by the Senate.

There have been a number of occasions—and the example of Australian Defence Industries springs to mind—where, basically, we have had very severe restrictions placed on the committee as to what they can do and what they can ask, and the bodies themselves choosing what they are asked, with a very wide‐ranging and broad cover under commercial in confidence. Obviously, this also ought to be considered. I urge the support of the Senate for my amendment. I move:

At the end of the motion, add `and the Senate declares that, in spite of anything contained in these bills, it expects and requires ministers to ensure that, as far as practicable, when senators request representatives of a body in receipt of money appropriated by the Parliament or subject to any direction or control by the Commonwealth, to attend before any committee considering estimates or annual reports, such representatives will attend as requested'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to sum up briefly because I think most of the issues have been addressed in great detail by a range of committees, including the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the Senate finance and public administration committee and so forth. There are some things I would like to respond to now. However, the detailed issues in relation to clause 37 and other matters can be dealt with in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I will respond formally to Senator Murray's generous congratulations for this government's progressing this package, which has had a gestation period of slightly more than eight years. He did genuinely and frankly congratulate the government for bringing this forward. I know those who have been associated with these bills have been very keen to progress them through the Senate and it is genuinely an historic day in the Senate that this is now happening.

Senator Murray did give us a bit of a brickbat, saying that perhaps we had been a little tardy in not bringing them on before this session. I say to Senator Murray that the government had listed them for debate at the end of the last session and, from memory, possibly even the session before that. Indeed, to get this package through, we had negotiated with other parties in this place to sit for an extra four or five hours on the last Thursday night at the end of the last session. I had the agreement of quite a large number of senators, including Senator Kernot, to do just that but in the event we were not able to do so.

For the record, if the Senate were able to come to sensible, modern, practical ways of managing the time that it deals with legislation, and tried to divide the time more evenly between important matters, we would get to deal with a lot of other matters before this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were one of the worst offenders in opposition.

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President; Senator Evans, we did take a long time on one particular bill at the end of 1993. However, we took a very long time on that bill after all of the other government legislation had been dealt with and set an extra five days to do so. There may have been one or two other bills in 13 years where we did that.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, that in the first 12 months of this government's term, the Senate took 100 hours to deal with two bills: the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 , more commonly known as the workplace relations legislation, and Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership Bill 1996). It took 100 hours—the equivalent of nearly 10 sitting days—to deal with two bills. I feel quite sure that we could have had a constructive debate on a range of other packages of bills if we had been a little more sensible about allocating time. I reiterate a plea I made in a speech outside this place: if senators, particularly leaders and whips of parties, could come together and agree to allocate sensible amounts of time—and even generous amounts of time—to packages of bills, you could end up dealing with a lot more legislation. Definitely, if that had applied prior, the audit package of bills would have passed into law many months ago. At the committee stage of the bills—which looks likely to be the next day of sitting—I will deal with clause 37 and some of the points that Senator Murray made, in detail.

In some contrast—and Senator Margetts made the point in her contribution, although I do not think she was making the same point—when we were dealing with the package of legislation in relation to the Productivity Commission, the legislation failed at the third reading on this issue of the right of small business people, or business people in general, to bring a complaint about competitive neutrality before that body. That was one of the core issues for some senators. We needed only one more vote and we would have had the package.

I do find it somewhat ironical that the Democrats are saying to the business community, `Look; you can't have a complaints mechanism if you think that a Commonwealth government business entity is competing against you unfairly. We think that that is unfair on the Commonwealth government business enterprise' and then come along here and say that the Commonwealth should be able to compete against business, even if it is unfairly, and also ensure that the Commonwealth can make a report about a commercial operation which would confer—and I think these are the words of the legislation or the amendment—`unfair commercial damage.' Perhaps it is not ironical; perhaps it is, in fact, consistent.

The coalition government is trying to protect private businesses—often small businesses run by families—from unfair intrusion by `big brother'. We think that in the productivity commission legislation small business should be able to complain if they believe they are being unfairly competed against by one of the big brother government's business enterprises, but the Democrats have said no to that.

We also think it is unfair that a Commonwealth government, or the Auditor‐General in this case, should cause to be published a report that would create unfair commercial damage. That matter will be debated in the committee stage, hopefully on the next day of sitting.

BREAK.PARA: I conclude by thanking the many senators—both those in the Senate now and those who have left; this matter has gone virtually over a generation—for the contributions they have made. It has been an eight‐year process to get this legislation into the Senate. Members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts have made a tremendous contribution over that period. Ros Kelly has already been thanked for her contribution in seeing this package come forward. We thank Mrs Kelly again. We do thank all senators and you, Senator Margetts in particular, for agreeing to have this second reading debate during lunch time, which has allowed the package to be dealt with more speedily, using up time that otherwise would have been spent eating our sandwiches.

Senator Margetts, I note that you have distributed a second reading amendment. The government's view on that is that we believe that the Senate has appropriate powers—some would say very important powers—to call before it people in these categories. This amendment certainly would not add or detract from those powers and so the government will not be supporting it.
It would be neat to have the second reading completed today but clearly, if you wanted to have a division on this amendment, I would not want to bring the debate to a close.

—Very well, I will adjourn the debate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
