We have announced that as a licence condition imposed on Telstra, if by 1 May next year there has not been agreement reached between the parties—that is, Telstra and Optus—as to the appropriate level of remuneration that should pass between them, the terms recommended by Austel in its final review released publicly just before the close of the financial year, and, indeed, prior to its going out of existence, will be imposed on Telstra.

ANSWER.PARA: This is very good news for consumers. It will provide a major boost to competition. It will inevitably provide more flexibility for customers wanting to shop around. We have followed all of the proper processes, and that is why I think the question asked by Senator Tierney is very important—that is, whether this is well understood by all the major stakeholders. There is one in particular who has a very serious level of difficulty in understanding the true nature of this decision, and that is the representative of disgruntled unionists, presumably their candidate at the next election.

Senator Schacht put out a press release on local number portability in which he said that our decision would be `a major boost to competition'. He got that dead right but, unfortunately, it is all downhill after that. If you look at his press release, he says:
. . . the Minister has been excessively slow in dealing with this important issue.
Two paragraphs later, he says:
It is surprising that such difficult legal decisions appear to have been made so quickly.
He says:
. . . Telstra's Registration Statement filed with the US Securities and Stock Exchange Commission last week makes no mention of the new licence condition or its financial impacts.

I would have thought that it was axiomatic that a decision that was made only this week could not have been contained in a document filed last week. Senator Schacht, you do not want to hear it. I know. Get back into the sandpit. Tune out. Listen to the House of Representatives. Do everything you can to avoid learning, but it is about time you faced up to the fact that you cannot even put two words together in a press release. How do you expect to be taken seriously? You talk about the `US Securities and Stock Exchange Commission'—no such animal. It is the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

Telstra's registration statement is the first of two preliminary documents. The first one, filed last week, is actually a pink herring. I know you are in the business of red herrings because the rest of this press release is all about red herrings. You will have to wait a bit longer before they actually file the red herring, and you will have to wait even longer—until you get to the end of the float process—before they file the final document. It is on that basis that people will take into account the impacts on Telstra of these sorts of announcements.

Senator Schacht seems to think that you should not be doing anything in the lead‐up to the float process without understanding that there is an obligation to actually disclose issues that might be material to the value of Telstra. So to put out a press release along these lines of saying: `I do not believe the minister has solved the complicated problem by imposing a licence condition. Clearly the achievement of number portability involves action by more than one party,' again, shows a fundamental misunderstanding.

We have imposed interim arrangements pending agreement and, in default of the agreement, determination by arbitration by the ACCC. Of course, this only applies to Optus and Telstra. So, in due course, they will both come to an agreement to the extent that, if Optus customers want to access Telstra and vice versa, that will emerge under the new competitive regime.

It is a pity that Senator Schacht did not, once again, come and ask for some help. We were more than happy to provide it. All I can say is, `Back to kindergarten.' I know you are a failed primary school teacher, but you must be able to do better than that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. I refer to the national launch of Centrelink which took place yester day. Minister, could you please advise how much was spent on the refreshments for the 200 guests invited to the national launch in the Great Hall of Parliament House; the national television, radio and press advertising campaign commencing 24 September; the broadcasting of the national launch live to all agency sites on agency TV; the production and distribution of Centrelink media kits and banners; and the refreshments for guests at local Centrelink launches in Liberal and National Party electorates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell the senator that I am very glad he has such an interest in Centrelink, because he should have. His constituents will hopefully receive a much better service as a result of the establishment of Centrelink. Certainly, people in regional and rural Australia will have much better access by way of the telephone with an upgraded teleservice call system—much better than the one we inherited from your government, which was under‐resourced. As you know, that has already provided about another 125 new jobs in our home state of Tasmania. Around Australia another thousand new jobs have gone into a teleservice system which will give proper service for people in country Australia. It is no wonder that the people who live in these rural areas have found these developments in television and radio very interesting and exciting.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very necessary that the message of Centrelink gets out to as many people as possible. After all, Centrelink is responsible for payments to something like eight million Australians—age pensioners, disability pensioners, families with family payments, child-care payments and people who are unemployed. The eight million people who are customers of Centrelink need to know what is happening. That is the first thing. The second thing is that the taxpayers of Australia are paying for this service and they need to know that we are introducing a new service which is going to be much more efficient than in the past.

An education and information campaign is required to make sure that the taxpayers and the customers know what is happening. The total cost of the campaign, which was available to you in estimates, was $2.4 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I will investigate in estimates whether or not $2.4 million covered the lunch for the few people. Minister, can you provide me with a list of the non-government members and senators who were invited to attend the Centrelink launches in their local or duty electorates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell you that there were people representing national welfare organisations from around the country. There was the vice‐minister from the Netherlands for social security and employment and the Dutch ambassador. He is visiting Australia to learn about the reforms in social security, such as Centrelink. That is why he has come here. He finds it a very exciting concept.

ANSWER.PARA: There were also a number of members of parliament there. I cannot say what the list was. Certainly, Centrelink arranged the launch yesterday and I do not have that information available to me. I know that you will find in your electorates that there are great opportunities to be associated with Centrelink because it is an important reform which is important to you as senators for your states and for your constituents. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Federal Agencies and Departments: Contracting Out

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Minister, what is your response to the fact that there has been a 19 per cent increase in complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman concerning federal agencies and departments? Ms Phillipa Smith says:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the rules associated with contracting out government services are muddy, contradictory or not yet written, and when it comes to issues of accountability and redress there is a new twilight zone.

She also draws attention to the conflict of interest and cronyism in tender selection procedures. Minister, will the government now call a halt to tendering out, particularly in your area of government IT services, at least until these and other widespread and serious criticisms about the government's failure to put in place proper processes for contracting are dealt with?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could deal with the last part of that question first, whole of government IT outsourcing is the responsibility of the Minister for Finance. I trust that Senator Allison is aware of some changes that were announced yesterday in that area. As far as the Ombudsman's annual report is concerned, it clearly raises a number of issues which we acknowledged as important in our election policy commitments prior to the last election. In particular, we acknowledged that consumers should have information on the level of service they can expect, that services should be accessible and that there should be complaints handling procedures within departments.

ANSWER.PARA: We therefore committed ourselves to service charters. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the government is delivering on that commitment. On 24 March the Prime Minister reinforced that commitment to service charters in the `More time for business' statement. We subsequently released a set of principles to guide the development of service charters. The government's timetable for introducing charters was launched on 21 August last and all ministers have made a commitment to deliver service charters over the next two years.

Under the framework agreed by the government for service charters, each agency developing a service charter will be required, in consultation with its customers, to set standards of service, to put in place complaints handling systems and to report annually on performance against service charter undertakings. The Ombudsman's office is represented on the task force which developed the service charters principles and which is now providing guidance on monitoring issues.

This country is breaking new ground, as service charters will apply to regulators, Commonwealth agencies providing services direct to the public and private sector bodies contracted on behalf of the Commonwealth to provide services to the public. The government will be placing great emphasis on the need for charters to set rigorous standards and to have meaning. There will be an annual report to the parliament on how the Australian Public Service has performed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response. Can the minister also to respond to the Commonwealth Ombudsman's remarks that commercial‐in‐confidence can be and is being used as a convenient excuse for avoiding transparency in the spending of public moneys?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is any surprise that that argument is often run. I suppose we have all run it on occasions when information has been denied to us. Obviously there is always a suspicion that that might be the case. The matter has to be judged objectively on the merits. However, ultimately, it is important to err on the side of ensuring that commercial‐in‐confidence matters are properly protected.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, it would not make any sense to simply say that in the interests of transparency you should disregard those sorts of claims or not take them very seriously because you could seriously jeopardise sensitive commercial arrangements, sensitive private contractual arrangements, that have been entered into. Therefore, all I can say is that the government will be no doubt responding in due course to the comments and criticisms to which Senator Allison has referred. I think we would always do so on the basis that we would be anxious to protect all commercial‐in‐confidence arrangements. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you confirm that since 1 July this year health care cards have included a code which identifies which social security payment a person is receiving? Do you think it is appropriate for any member of the general public—for example, the chemist who is dispensing their prescription—to know whether a person is unemployed or a widow? Does the Privacy Commissioner agree with this blanket release of personal information when, in fact, the card need only identify sickness allowees so that they can access the extra concessions, such as free hearing aids, to which they are entitled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibbs may or may not be aware of the fact that there have been over a number of years real troubles with the administration of health cards of one kind or another. It had got to the stage where when we came into government there was criticism from the people who were supposed to be receiving the cards because they were getting duplicate copies or quadruplicate copies, and also from chemists saying that there was no effective way of knowing whether a card was still current or not. As a result, I know that the Department of Social Security last year did a review of what we should be doing about cards generally.

ANSWER.PARA: You will recall that we reduced the number of cards from four to three, which was an exercise in simplicity. Also the department was trying to produce better cards that would pass the test of time in usage, that they would not disintegrate, as people have had those problems too. I do not know whether the Privacy Commissioner was consulted. I certainly will ask that. I would expect that the Privacy Commissioner would have been consulted because Social Security has been meticulous over a number of years in consulting with the Privacy Commissioner on any new moves. I hope and trust that that has happened on this occasion. I would be very happy to get that information and bring it to you.

I am sure you would agree that an efficiently managed card system is very important to those on low incomes who are getting income support from the Department of Social Security and who have an eligibility for a card, and that it is delivered to them efficiently, does not breach their privacy and is useful for the purpose for which it is intended. The taxpayer also has an interest to make sure that cards are not usable beyond the eligibility date. That has been a continuing problem.

I know the department has done a lot of work in trying to improve the systems to prevent multiple release of cards. They also have contracts with private firms to improve on the printing. I know they have had some troubles in that area, but there has been a continuing effort to improve this area of service delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The former Minister for Administrative Services said that using Jetset for parliamentary travel will save $1 million and $1.5 million per annum. Minister, firstly, will the government make the contract with Jetset public so that we can see whether there are to be real earnings or whether it is a matter of shuffling figures? Secondly, what was the cost of the tender process and what is the duration of the contract with Jetset? Could the minister tell the Senate what the cost of refurbishing the Senate office space was for Jetset and what the cost of rental of that Senate space is to Jetset?
—Better still, get David Jull to take Jetset with him and give us back the Senate transport office.
—Senator Brown has asked a large number of questions in relation to Jetset. I will seek a response from the minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I look forward to the specifics but the general question I put back to the minister: will the contract with Jetset be made available? Will the government meet the same standards of public sector accountability as in New Zealand where such contracts are made available except for a schedule of costs?
—You will breach commercial‐in‐confidence for sure.

—If it is okay in New Zealand, it is okay here. Finally, can the minister say whether there have been teething problems with the Jetset contract and whether there have been members of parliament who have missed planes or otherwise been inconvenienced by the new arrangements?

—Senator Brown asked a number of questions and made statements in relation to that matter. Again, I will raise the issue of whether the contract can be made available. That is a matter for the minister to decide, Senator Brown. Have there been any complaints? I heard one from Senator Bob Collins. The final comment was that if it is okay in New Zealand it is okay in Australia. I would be surprised if you would press that too hard, Senator Brown.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the minister to the proposed cabinet reforms to the Child Support Agency and other child custody changes. Has the minister's attention been drawn to comments by a Queensland MP that `domestic violence orders are flying around' and `are issued like confetti these days'? Are you aware of claims that `in Queensland, domestic violence can be ringing up your partner and saying "Please can I see my children?"' Do you agree with a recent observation that the extent of child abuse is `grossly overstated' and that during marriage break‐ups accusing a partner of child abuse was a common strategy to obtain advantage and was akin to dropping the atom bomb? Do you agree that child abuse is `the easiest allegation to make'? If, like many members of this parliament, you find these statements highly offensive and detrimental to the task of tackling domestic violence, have you counselled the member of your parliamentary party who insists on making them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the quotes that Senator Crowley has raised in here, but I will say that, long before I came into this place, I was working for a Labor government in Tasmania on the protection of children from child abuse. So don't let there be any doubt about it that, to the extent that I can do anything in this country to prevent the abuse of children, I will be doing it and I will not countenance ignorant statements that try to minimise a social disease and disaster.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally, domestic violence against either spouse is to be condemned. Whether it is caused by men against their female spouses or women against their male spouses, I would condemn it. That also is a scourge not only because of the damage it does to the couple but also because of the continuing damage it does to their children and their children's children. I am sure you would agree it is a generational issue. We need to break the cycle.

Both child abuse and spouse abuse are cankers which are transmitted from generation to generation. Those who have been subjected to it in their youth are lucky if they do not become participants in it in their adult lives. That is why the Prime Minister is committed to the national summit against domestic violence to develop a national strategy with the heads of the governments of the states and the territories, and to do all that we can not only to bind up the wounds of the victims but to prevent that disease in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, has your attention been drawn to this individual's attempt to raise during committee hearings the individual circumstances of a case in which he was professionally involved as an attorney? Can you confirm that this is contrary to both the professional standards of his profession and, were it not covered by privilege, the provisions of the Family Law Act? Can you confirm that he was only prevented from doing so because the witness refused to answer his questions and cautioned him on his professional obligations? Minister, in the light of your saying that you were unaware of those comments, can we have your assurance that you will pursue them and follow up by speaking to your parliamentary colleague?

—I have made perfectly clear my views on those issues. There can be no doubt and it. I am not aware, as I said earlier, of these comments. If there is any opportunity for me to take them up with the person concerned—and I do not know who it is—
—Make an opportunity.

—I will make that opportunity at the first available chance. I also point out to you that, sadly, there are views in this country which none of us will endorse, but we all endorse the right of free speech. Having said that, I personally will take up the issue with the person concerned.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I noted with interest that earlier in question time the Assistant Treasurer informed the Senate of the good news for the Australian economy in the form of improved business expectations. Minister, will you outline the achievements of the Howard government in fixing the mess left by 13 years of Labor mismanagement and whether any lessons have been learnt since Labor was thrown out of office 18 months ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, certainly. It is pleasing to get this further good economic news as a result of the Howard government's policies.
—Nobody believes you.
—Members of the opposition don't want to hear good economic news, of course. They turn their backs on good economic news.
—Sad reflection.

—It is a sad reflection, as my colleague said. What has been delivered in 18 months? Five interest rate reductions, interest rates down from 10.5 per cent to around 6.7 per cent, the lowest inflation rate since 1963, a budget deficit down from $10.5 billion to a surplus by the end of our first term of government, housing affordability increased significantly, business investment as a proportion of GDP at a record high in real terms, accelerating economic growth and now a strengthening in business expectation. This is a very good economic record and something of which we are very proud. Compare it with Labor.

—On a point of order, Madam President: the minister has been talking now for about a minute or so and as yet has failed to mention the great contributions made by Mr Sharp, Mr Jull, Mr Prosser, Senator Gibson and others. I think sooner or later he should get around to really answering the question and referring to the efforts of those ministers.
—Senator, there is no point of order and you are wasting the time of the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ALSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a substantial point of order: that is typical of the performance that you are being confronted with. In my submission you should ensure that, when a question is being answered by any minister on this side, there is an opportunity for it to be heard in relative silence.

INTERJECT.PARA: We do not object to the odd interjection, as you well know. But an orchestrated campaign of talking, as we are seeing right now, is designed to do nothing other than to distract and to make life more difficult for the people of Australia to hear the answers delivered by ministers.

These conversations could be had outside the chamber at any time. They can talk between questions if they want to. Madam President, all that is happening now is a deliberate insult to your authority because they are trying to ensure that the people cannot listen to the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

—It is astonishing, in fact, to find yesterday that one of the `old guard' ministers of the Labor Party, Senator Cook, had the nerve to give a lecture on economic policy. Senator Cook visited CEDA yesterday to tell them something about how to run the economy. This was the Senator Cook who believed before the last election that the economy was running in surplus. This was the Senator Cook who said, and I remind you, Madam President:

ANSWER.PARA: But I tell you one thing for sure: our budget will be balanced and in surplus.
Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus—

This was just before the election when we found they were, in fact, $10 billion in deficit. The nerve of the Labor Party to give any lecture on the economy. Do you remember their record? We had massive unemployment of 11.2 per cent in December 1992; foreign debt of over $180 billion, up from $23 billion when they came into office; a massive current account deficit; Commonwealth debt of over $100 billion; the widening gap, of course, between the rich and the poor, with about 1.9 million Australians living in poverty; and the recession that we had to have when interest rates rose for small business to over 20 per cent.

This was the legacy that Labor left us. This was a demonstration of how Labor runs the Australian economy. Yet Senator Cook fronted up to CEDA yesterday to give them a lesson on what he believed good economic management would hold for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they throw him out?

—It would be interesting, Senator Alston, if you have time, to look at a few of the things he said. He said, `There is a case for tax reform.' There certainly is in Labor's eyes. Tax reform for Labor means you push taxes up. Do you remember the 1993 budget: sales tax up two per cent, petrol tax up, tobacco excise up, HECS payments up. Or the 1995 budget: the Medicare levy up, sales tax up, increased company tax and increased tobacco tax. This is Labor's recipe for taxation reform—you push it up.

ANSWER.PARA: He said this new government was pandering to special interest groups. Which government gave $143 million to over 1,500 special interest groups in 1994? Labor! Labor turned it into an art form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, the time for answering the question has terminated.
—I would love to go on, Madam President.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I have listened with interest to the minister's answer and I would be very pleased if he would give me more detailed information as to the improvement in the Australian economy under the government. Also, could he advise whether there have been any misleading claims made in relation to the waterfront and industry policy?

—I will come to the point I was just finishing. I was reminding the Australian people that funding to trade unions increased from $2.4 million in 1983 to $18.5 million in 1994. That was Labor pandering to special interest groups.
—Did you have a look at what the employers got, Robert?

—He called for waterfront reform, he did. They were the party that spent $450 million of taxpayers' money to buy out waterside workers. What did it gain? Five containers an hour for $450 million of taxpayers' money. They increased performance to 17 containers when world's best practice is 30. That is how Labor spends the Australian taxpayers' money. On industry policy, he said that we copied Labor on TCF policy. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman. Has your attention been drawn to the proposed abolition of the social policy and cross‐sectoral branch in DEETYA? Is it a fact that this branch deals with equity policy and includes the Women's Bureau? Are you aware that the Women's Bureau was the first women's unit to be incorporated into the federal bureaucracy? Are you also aware that this branch of DEETYA analyses education and labour market participation rates of disadvantaged groups such as women? Doesn't this send a clear sign that the coalition no longer sees a role for assessing the impact of education and labour market policies on disadvantaged groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, it is a scare campaign by the Labor Party. They do not seem to have anything much to do except smears and scares. I am advised that the claims, such as Senator Neal has just made in the chamber and have been made outside previously, about the abolition of the women's unit are wrong. It still exists and for first time it will have a clear policy focus.

ANSWER.PARA: The functions of the bureau will be located in a new strengthened equity and participation branch. A decision on the name will be made by staff in the new structure. I am further advised that as another measure the secretary to the department will chair a new corporate committee on equity which will significantly boost DEETYA's capacity to address equity issues in the education, employment and training sectors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you advise us whether in fact you were consulted before this decision was made?
—I understand that the two departments and the two offices have been in communication over this issue and the development of it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Council on Smoking and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Given the health minister's public statements in support of the anti-smoking movement and the government's current anti-smoking campaign, and also the recent substantial settlements reached in the United States between governments and tobacco companies, will the Australian government now show it is serious about tackling tobacco companies in Australia and reverse its previous decision not to grant legal aid to the Australian Council on Smoking and Health to pursue a smokers' class action? If the government is not prepared to fund the class action by ACSH, will the government itself initiate action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lees for the question. There is no doubt that tobacco smoking is a great scourge affecting this country. As I am sure most members know, the government embarked on a $7 million national tobacco campaign to advertise the deleterious effect of tobacco smoke and the fact that so many thousands die each year as a result of cigarette smoking. I know that Senator Lees has a very keen interest in this, as we were members together of a community affairs committee that looked at this problem for Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The minister is involved in that campaign, as you know. The campaign is the first truly national collaborative Quit Smoking health initiative between federal, state and territory governments and non‐government organisations. This is the first time all have come together on this scale in a campaign to reduce smoking. The Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the divisions of general practice, the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, the Pharmacy Guild, the Australian Cancer Society, the National Health Foundation, the Quit organisations across Australia and the National Asthma Campaign have all pledged their support and contribution to the campaign.

I am greatly encouraged by early indications from the tracking surveys that the campaign is a success, having generated a very high awareness of its advertisements, stimulated significant discussion about its smoking and health message and prompted more than 35,000 calls to the national Quit telephone hotline which provides information and counselling services for smokers. Among people who recalled health advertising—54 per cent of all respondents surveyed—31 per cent described smoking advertising prior to the campaign, 62 per cent in the first three weeks after the launch and 54 per cent for the next four weeks.

Obviously, it is in the interests of this country to diminish the amount of cigarette smoking that occurs in the community and all actions that can be taken in that regard are being looked at by the minister and by the department because, as the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs showed in its investigation, the economic advantages to this country far outweigh the possible economic return from taxation and the various things that occur. That fact is not well known and is, of course, significantly denigrated by the tobacco industry of this country.

I can assure Senator Lees that everything possible that can be done will be done by the minister and by the department. It is of significance that the issues that she raised are under consideration and, concerning the specific question that she has in that regard, I will come back to her with an answer from the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. While the campaign is of great interest, the people who are actually launching this class action are virtually all those groups you mentioned as supporting the campaign. Wouldn't it be great if, rather than us having to fund that campaign, it was actually funded by the tobacco companies and they really put back some of what it is costing us, particularly in the public health system? So I ask: when you go to the minister, if the answer is still no, they will not support the legal aid application, what does this government intend to do to compel the tobacco companies to come to the table and admit, as they have done in the United States, that their product is harmful, it is addictive and it kills? The campaign is great, but really, Minister, I think that is a soft option considering this government has not taken up most of the recommendations of the Senate committee that you just mentioned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question that Senator Lees's statement is correct that it is harmful, it kills and it is a product that is of great danger to the Australian community. Regrettably, it is still a legal product and I think that is a problem in the sense that those of us who feel very strongly about this issue, as both of us do, recognise that while it remains a legal product—and there are those on that committee that considered that aspect of it as well—there are constraints on government in regard to funding against something that is a legal product in any case. But I will be happy to come back to you with an answer from the minister in due course.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, yesterday at your extravagant launch of Centrelink, the Prime Minister said, `The board of Centrelink includes private sector members with extensive experience in the establishment of customer service networks.' Is it not the case that three of the six Centrelink board members have direct links with the financial sector and particularly banks: Ms Gillies from the Bank of Melbourne; Mr Pearce from Rothschilds and Sons investment bank; and Mr Thame, the ex‐Managing Director of Advance Bank? Is it not the case that Centrelink will make 159 million payments estimated to be worth almost $51 billion in 1997‐98, most of them by electronic transfers to financial institutions including banks? Is this not already a conflict of interest? How will the board deal with decisions about things like the introduction of smartcards when only one of its members will be able to vote under the conflict of interest provisions in the CSDA Act 1997?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably very timely that that silly question has been asked because you have just asked it in front of some of the members of the board who have been sitting in the gallery right through this question time. I am very sorry for them. It has been really quite opportune for them to see what a stupid opposition we have and to realise the difficulties that a government has to operate under when you have an opposition that is not in the least interested in policy. It is simply interested in game playing because it has nothing better to do with its time. It is a bit like kids out in the playground.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, we have some eminent Australians on the board of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency. Would you suggest that we have hopeless do‐nothings who have not achieved anything in their lives? No. That is clearly what the opposition would like.

The situation is that the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, now known as Centrelink, is a huge organisation, making the 159 million payments that you referred to, and spending about one‐third of the federal budget. That is the enormity of the task that has been given to them. It involves good administration, a good background in administration, an understanding of information technology, an understanding of the need to change a culture so that it is very much more customer focused than it has been in the past.

I point out to you in that regard the criticisms made yesterday in the report by the Ombudsman. I would have thought the opposition might have asked questions about that. But no; that refers to the system that we inherited, so perhaps you do not like to ask about that. A number of the measures which the Ombudsman criticised related directly to a lack of customer focus and an understanding of the needs of the customer.

Those are the sorts of responsibilities that this board has. I cannot believe that you are suggesting that we would put people onto a board who were unethical. If that is what you are suggesting, you should go outside and say that these people will behave in an unethical manner. They are on the boards of other companies. They understand perfectly well the responsibilities that are required under Australian law for the declaration of interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you assiduously avoided the essence of the question. Really, the question was about whether there was going to be a conflict of interest created by this situation. You did not touch on that once in your answer, so perhaps you will do so in your supplementary answer. You might also tell us whether you know whether there are any service organisations with prominent people who could assist on the board of CSDA, other than representatives of the banks. By the way, do you think that the banks, with their massive profits on the back of increased fees and charges for the battlers who use them, provide the best example of customer service?

—I think Senator O'Brien was so determined that he was about to make a political statement that he did not listen to the fact that I addressed the conflict of interest question very clearly. You were shouting. I said that these people, who are eminent Australians, who are on the boards of other companies, fully understand issues of conflict of interest and the requirements on company directors. If you are suggesting otherwise, I suggest that you go outside, where they can allow the full impact of the law to take effect, because I reckon they would have you for dinner in the law courts. That is the reality of the matter. I do not think there is anything more I can answer to such a stupid question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the minister aware of the criticism of the government's position on greenhouse by Clive Hamilton of the Australia Institute? What is the minister's response to Dr Hamilton's assertions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of interjection is disorderly. Senators on my left will cease interjecting in this fashion.

—We have all been subject, on both sides of the parliament, to Dr Hamilton's outpouring of media releases which, without exception, are anti‐ABARE and can best be described as anti‐Australian. It is the same line, coincidentally, which is run by the Australian Democrats and Senator Brown.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is this Dr Hamilton who, in his last press release, accused the Prime Minister of `fantasy' and `desperation'? In 1994, Dr Hamilton appeared on the ABC National program The Search for Meaning . Let me quote what this person said on that program:

BREAK.PARA: Out of the blackness one day appeared the figure of my shadow. He'd shown himself, somewhat obscurely, several times in dreams over the previous months, I realised subsequently, especially in one where this figure appeared as a murderer and an abuser of women. And I had learned and absorbed and accepted from Jung that every character that appears in our dreams, no matter how horrible and unpalatable that character might be is an aspect of ourselves . . .
I entered into a dialogue with this figure who appeared before me. I spoke to him . . . and he told me that his name was Jacob and from his mouth spewed the most foul salvo of abuse—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. Senator Abetz has asked a question which is being answered by Senator Parer and I suggest that you listen to the answer, if you want to know what it is about.

—On a point of order, Madam President: I invite you to apply the standing orders to what is happening over there. They are not isolated interjections. It is an orchestrated campaign to disrupt the proceedings.
—Oh!

—Exactly—it hits a raw nerve. They know exactly what they are doing. It is a pre‐determined campaign to ensure that Senator Parer's answer cannot be heard. I submit to you that you ought to bring them into line on that, not just in terms of interjections, but in terms of that complete campaign.

—On the point of order, Madam President: a good confidence builder for Senator Richard Alston after his bad day on Tuesday, but could I direct your attention, Madam President, to the fact that it has been a little rowdy in the chamber during this answer from Senator Parer. It does appear that Senator Parer has somewhat lost the plot, I think you would have to agree. We are in the middle of a very longwinded and apparently totally irrelevant quotation. I would also ask you to rule on the fact that Senator Parer ought to be directed to answer the question that Senator Abetz asked.

—Senator Abetz has asked a question. He has not made any protest about the answer that he is receiving. I suggest that senators listen to the answer. There has been so much noise that I am surprised that some have any idea what has been said.
—I continue the quote from Dr Hamilton:

BREAK.PARA: And he told me his name was Jacob and from his mouth spewed the most foul salvo of abuse that was imaginable and I was racked by overpowering emotion, almost more than I could bear . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. That is what I meant by relevance.
—There is no point of order.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order.

—Order! Senators will remain silent and allow me to hear the point of order being raised by Senator Abetz. There has been persistent interjecting on my left throughout question time and it is totally disorderly behaviour.

—Madam President, because of all the interruptions from the other side, I was not able to hear whether or not you had said to Senator Faulkner that there was no point of order. If there is no point of order, there is no need for me to address you.
—There is no need for you to address me.
—To continue quoting from this person, he said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . I was racked by overpowering emotion, almost more than I could bear . . . I was frightened of this creature, particularly as I knew it was inside me, it was part of me, and yet I'd come far enough to understand that I had to draw it all out and to try to integrate this creature, this character, back into my own psyche.
And so I talked to Jacob and calmed him down and befriended him and, ultimately, forgave him for being part of me.
With Clive Hamilton's recent press release, I fear Jacob is now in control.
Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my left! The behaviour on my left is totally disorderly. Senator Parer still has time to answer this question.

—If the Australian people want guidance on the economic consequences of the proposed greenhouse gas abatements, they have a choice of Dr Hamilton, Jacob, the Democrats or ABARE. I think we have to go for ABARE.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 23 September Senator Bolkus asked me a question without notice relating to the government's employment transition framework. The Minister for Finance has provided additional information regarding this matter, which I now table.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday, 23 September Senator Cook asked me a question without notice regarding a survey by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business provided additional information, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The additional information read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: IMPACT OF SUPERANNUATION SURCHARGE ON SMALL BUSINESS
Question from Senator Cook:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Minister, has your attention been drawn to a survey by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants which shows that Australian small businesses will have to pay more than $30 million in extra costs to collect the 15 per cent tax on superannuation? Can you also confirm that the survey revealed that the cost of collecting the tax would increase charges by at least $100 for each small fund member? Is it a fact that half the accountants surveyed said that they would need to increase their fees to clients as a result of complying with the tax? How do you reconcile these developments with your government's professed commitment to reducing small business compliance costs and to cutting red tape?

PARA.EMPHASIS: Additional Information

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the Honourable Senator's question, I am advised that the survey commissioned by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants used a sample of only 376 registered accountants, a very small representation from the 67,000 accountants and tax professionals in Australia. Therefore, the Government would be unwise to rely on these results as indicative of the views of the wider small business community and its advisers.

The figure of $30 million referred to by the Senator was an extrapolation calculated by the Society. It was based on the survey finding that 50 per cent of the registered accountants surveyed (ie. 188 of the 376 surveyed) believed that administering the surcharge on behalf of their clients would result in client fees having to be increased by $100 per superannuation fund member.
However, it must be recognised that 42% of the survey respondents believed that their fees would remain the same, 2% believed their fees would be reduced, and 6% said "don't know".
These results clearly show that there is a wide divergence of opinion on this matter even within the small group of accountants surveyed.
The Government is committed to reducing small business compliance costs and cutting red tape.

Evidence of that commitment is our recent decision to pass regulatory responsibility for self managed superannuation funds from the Insurance and Sup erannuation Commission to the Australian Taxation Office. One advantage for small businesses who utilise self managed superannuation funds is that only one regulator will be involved.
We will monitor the impact of the superannuation surcharge arrangements on small business and continue to have regard to their views.

—I would like to know then, Senator. I invite you to tell me. That answers the two parts of the questions asked by Senator Faulkner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by Senators Neal and Crowley today, relating to government programs aimed at women.

I asked the minister about the abolition of a women's bureau within the organisation known as the social policy and cross-sectoral branch of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I do not know whether the minister intentionally misunderstood my question or whether she was being mischievous in the way she responded to the question. Very clearly, the women's bureau does not exist, and any statement that this bureau still does exist—if she intended it to be construed that way—was completely and utterly incorrect.

BREAK.PARA: Originally the women's bureau was set up during the time of the Menzies government. It is rather amusing for those of us on this side of the Senate to know that this particular government in the late 1990s, close to the turn of the century, has a more traditional and less generous view of women than the Menzies government, which has become a symbol of conservatism and a symbol of putting forward policies that would have women return to the home and not be treated as equals in our community.

When you see in the 1990s a government taking these sorts of steps—doing away with a bureau that was originally put in place in the 1950s to ensure that women were not disadvantaged within employment and education—it really does give a pretty strong indication of this government's view of women and their role in the community.

I feel very sorry for those women who are members of the government who obviously have quite a contrary view. I have to say that I know Senator Coonan and Senator Payne are amongst those, and I hope they will get up and put forward their alternative view later on today. Certainly the view that is being put by this government, as represented by Senator Newman, is not the view that most people in Australia expect. Certainly it is not the view of Australian women. Women still believe that they should be able to go to work if they choose, and they should not be discouraged. They should not be encouraged to remain solely in the home.

The attitude that Senator Newman is displaying in her lack of concern for the abolition of the Women's Bureau is not restricted to just the internal machinations of the government's bureaucracy. As we are all aware, it is reflected much more broadly. It was only recently, after intense pressure from the backbench, that this government reversed its decision to abolish the position of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner within HREOC. There has also been very severe criticism by the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women within the United Nations for the way that this government's policies have changed to adversely affect women in the community.

It has also been very well highlighted in a recent survey released that the $820 million that has been cut from child care in the last two years has had a very severe effect on women and also their families, the children that they are caring for. In fact, the National Association of Community Based Children's Services report said that 4,000 families have taken their children out of child-care services in the last three months. Of those who have left, 74 per cent of those people have reported that the escalating costs were the reason that they left. The additional, on average, $18 a week that parents are being forced to pay to have their children in child care is making it impossible.

In most cases, those families who leave formal care put their children into informal care. In fact, 67 per cent of parents who leave child care because of these financial reasons are putting their children into backyard care. Not only is that occurring but, if you are a woman at work and you cannot afford to have your children cared for in child care, you often have to give up your job entirely or reduce the hours that you work. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Payne, Sen Marise

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that Senator Neal should choose this particular time to make her comments in relation to the work of the government and women in Australia. It is ironic for a number of reasons. Firstly, this is the centenary year of the birth of Dame Enid Lyons, who, I might remind the Senate, was the first woman elected to the Australian federal parliament and, as a Liberal, the first woman cabinet minister. It is no accident that Dame Enid Lyons was, in fact, a Liberal because the Liberal Party has always stood for merit and the principle of equal opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: Merit brings me to an interesting and telling point—telling in that, even after the adoption of the ALP's quota system several years ago now, this week saw the swearing in of two new male ALP senators. With all due respect to those gentlemen, in the same circumstances, the Liberal Party has managed to replace, of three senators in this past six months, two with women—humbly, might I say, on merit and without the need for a quota system.

Rather than accepting the criticisms of Senator Neal, I will make reference to some of the historical notes which she glossed over. It was the Menzies Liberal government that delivered child endowment in this country, national divorce laws, a medical benefits scheme, a national health scheme and tax concessions for married pensioners. It was in the Holt, Gorton and McMahon governments that the Liberal Party delivered assistance to wives who had been deserted, lifted the Commonwealth Public Service marriage bar, introduced equal pay legislation and the Child Care Act in 1972. It was the Fraser government that introduced the new family allowance system with payments made directly to mothers and established the Office of Child Care, the National Women's Advisory Council and the Institute of Family Studies.

The Liberal government's commitment to women is all about giving women choice—choice in what they wish to do with their lives. The Howard government has funded growth in child-care places. It has taken a child-care program that was out of control. It was oversupplied in some areas while families elsewhere had little or no access to the child care that they needed.

In making vast improvements to the child-care program in this nation, we are providing more equitable access to child-care places for families. We are addressing the legitimate concerns raised by Australian families and the child-care industry in extensive consultations, and we have addressed the unregulated growth of the industry of the last six years. What the child-care program now does is target working families and low and middle income families. Far from cutting child care, we have funded 83,000 new child-care places over the next four years. These places are located in areas of greatest need, especially rural areas.

The Howard government has introduced the family tax incentive, which provides an extra $34 per fortnight for battling families, and rebates for private health insurance, which makes families $450 a year better off. We have introduced the parenting payment to ensure people with children moving from single to couple households, or vice versa, are not disadvantaged. The enshrining of pension entitlements at 25 per cent of male weekly earnings is an important safeguard for women, and the government is treating the income security needs of older women as a policy priority.

In terms of choice, our commitment to women in the work force is as important as our commitment to women outside the work force. The Workplace Relations Act makes permanent part-time work and family flexible working arrangements legally possible and provides all the necessary protections. It is our goal to provide women with greater choice. We do not believe in patronising quotas, but we do believe in effective anti-discrimination laws.

I am very glad that Senator Neal chose to raise this matter during her few words. That is why we have retained and will expand the role of the Sex Discrimination and Equal Opportunity Commissioner in the restructured human rights and responsibilities commission. We send a message from this that is self‐evident: we do respect the rights of women to be treated equally and fairly, whether in the workplace or elsewhere. We are making it safer and fairer for women in Australia.

The decisive ban on semi‐automatic weapons enhances the safety of women. I think that even the opposition would not quibble with that point. Later this year the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) will be holding a domestic violence summit in conjunction with all state and territory governments. Our determination is to take a united stand against this abhorrent crime. I remind the Senate of the words of Senator Newman in her response to a question from Senator Crowley earlier this afternoon: it is a canker on society. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not for me to be a nitpicker, Senator Payne, but you ought to check the facts about Dame Enid Lyons. As I understand it, she was never a cabinet minister; she was Secretary to the Cabinet, but never a cabinet minister—a point of tedious scholarship, but I could not resist it.

BREAK.PARA: What we are concerned to do today is to take note, as you did not, of the answers by Senator Newman to two questions. Both those answers indicate very importantly the insufficiency of Senator Newman's actions in protecting women's rights in this government. Minister Newman, when asked had she been consulted about the proposed abolishment of the women's bureau in DEETYA, said, `Well, my department did.' That department did, but clearly the answer—not said, but hanging in the air—is `No', with a very big capital `N'. No, Senator Newman was not consulted.

A week or so ago I asked Senator Newman why the Prime Minister's women in sport awards had been abolished and whether she had been consulted. She talked about everything except sport, and the answer once again was no; no, this minister was not consulted. No, there is no reason those awards are not continuing, except that this government wants to abolish them. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women knew nothing about it and was therefore totally unable to protect the needs of women, sporting women, in this country.

Today it is quite clear, according to the minister's own claim—and this will be checked—that apparently nobody has told her what a certain Queensland MP has been saying about domestic violence. I have here some 10 or more pages of copious references and comments by that aforementioned person in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Some of the points that I alluded to in my question are spelled out here in much greater length by that MP, making an absolute nonsense of Senator Newman's answer. If she does not know it, she should; if she does not know it, why not? Who is failing to draw these matters to her attention?

I totally accept Senator Newman's statement that she personally is opposed to domestic violence. She has had a long history of that. Indeed, I believe she was one of the people involved in founding a women's shelter in Launceston, I think—I am not sure. I know it was in Tasmania. I have nothing against Senator Newman's personal involvement in and commitment to the abolition of domestic violence. That was not the question. This side of parliament will not be distracted from the main game by Senator Newman trying to obfuscate.

Senator Newman is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. The question is: if she is concerned to be the minister running the campaign for government to abolish domestic violence, why is it that no‐one has drawn to her attention what is widely known throughout the community—these disgraceful and shocking remarks about domestic violence and child abuse by one of her parliamentary colleagues? Where has she been? If she has not been given this advice, who has failed to give it to her? She is the minister and she is being overlooked. She was not consulted about the abolition of the women's desk in DEETYA, she was not consulted about the abolition of the women in sport awards and apparently she was not told that one of her own parliamentary colleagues was speaking most disgracefully about domestic violence and child abuse.

What kind of assistance is she providing on behalf of the women of Australia? I do not want a list of the things that may or may not have been done, all of which could be argued. From our point of view, we totally disagree with Senator Payne's assessment of all those things, for example, her claim that the industrial relations changes protect women. What do you make of legislation that has removed the commitment to equal pay for women? Forget about anything else: it removed the commitment to equal pay for women. Why? What good is that to women? Absolutely none, and yet that is what Senator Payne would argue is an example of this government's commitment on behalf of women. It is a splendid illustration of just what is concerning us and why, in the light of what this minister, Senator Newman, is not being consulted about—according to her own report—we are so concerned on behalf of the women of Australia.

If you have read any newspapers in the last few days you will have seen how upset and angry are the women and the families of Australia who can no longer attend their child‐care centres because they are closed or because the cost of that child care has gone through the roof. That is what the women of Australia are saying. Many of those women who work in child‐care centres have now lost their jobs specifically because of the decisions by this government. Choice indeed! You have got one choice: out of the work force and onto the unemployment list. Many of those women are older women. As of last Saturday they have to use up their superannuation, their very modest amounts of superannuation, before they can even claim any assistance through unemployment benefits. This minister reckons she is representing the women of Australia. She said to me in answer to a question on 23 September that she listens to women; she is not listening well. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —My, my. She thinks she is angry. What a pathetic outburst. I want to deal with a couple of issues before us right now. The Labor Party has adopted the practice of taking note of a number of answers. One can only conclude from that that they have not got the capacity to actually address an issue which is contained in a question. The sooner we get back to what taking note of answers to a question really means the better, and then we can deal properly with some of the issues. The previous speaker referred to an answer to a question that she received last week. Surely Madam Deputy President, that must be stretching the standing orders in terms of what this part of the debate is meant for.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I also want to take the opportunity to recognise Dame Enid Lyons for her magnificent contribution to the parliaments of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: is the senator actually taking note of the questions before us?
—We can say the same about the previous two speakers on your side.
—Order! Senator Calvert! There is no point of order. Senator Crane, please resume.
—That just shows how out of touch they are. What a spurious point of order.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a spurious point of order. The contribution of Liberal governments was adequately covered by my colleague before me, Senator Payne. But I want to make the point that as of today, in terms of representation of women, we can boast of eight senators, and we can boast of 17 members of the House of Representatives. That was all done, as has already been said, on merit.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many things I wish to touch on in regard to that matter, but I want to move to the Workplace Relations Act, which makes permanent part‐time work and family flexible working arrangements legally possible and provides all the necessary protections.

I remember, as Senator Jacinta Collins will, when we tore around Australia in 17 days, the opposition that you people raised to this, and how you had your lackeys running in one after the other saying, `Oh, we don't want any of that. We won't have a bar of that.' This was one of the greatest incentives for women ever put into legislation in this place. Never forget that it gave them equal opportunity and maximum flexibility.

There are many other aspects that I could deal with, but I just want to touch on one from Senator Neal, where she made reference to the fact that the backbench did something or other in our party room. It was a very strange reference, because in the time of the previous government the backbench did nothing. They were dictated to by two Prime Ministers, Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. The one person who stood up and tried to argue some of the issues was Graeme Campbell, the member for Kalgoorlie. What did you do? You booted him out. You got rid of him. You could not stand a bit of competition. You could not stand someone in the party room arguing the case. That is the way your party behaves.

It is worth noting here that we have retained and will expand the role of the Sex Discrimination and Equal Opportunity Com missioner in a restructured human rights and responsibilities commission. Who is doing that? Us. This is on top of what was done by the previous Liberal governments, which have already been referred to.

I want to go now to the most damaging thing that has occurred with regard to women in this country—that is, the stewardship of the previous government. It was referred to in another question that was answered here today by Senator Kemp. I particularly want to refer to Senator Cook's press release and what the Labor government did—not only to women but to women in particular—to all Australians. Senator Cook—and he was part of the cabinet—starts off by saying:
The government continues to have failed the Australian economy.

I cannot believe this. Is this the same Senator Cook and Labor Party which gave Australia massive unemployment—11.2 per cent in December 1992? Who suffered from that? The women, the mothers of this country, were affected greatly by the damage that was done to their families, to their children, to their loved ones.

You took foreign debt to $180 billion from $23 billion. In office you had stewardship over a massive current account deficit. Commonwealth went over $100 billion. The widening gap between the rich and the poor—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow through on some of the comments that have been made earlier but actually focus my comments on the questions of which we are actually taking note. Some listening to us at the moment might have thought that we were actually taking note of the question `What has the Liberal Party done for women over the last several decades?' I do not believe that that was the actual question that was raised in question time. but it was certainly the matter that was dealt with by both Senator Crane and Senator Payne.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not originally intending to take note of these questions until, while waiting for a copy of some tabled documents to arrive, I listened to Senator Payne's comments. I must say that, in comparison to what I thought about her first speech, I was somewhat disappointed to hear the sorts of issues that she raised.

When I saw the invitation to attend a function in relation to the anniversary of the birth date of Dame Enid Lyons, I thought, `My goodness. Is that the best that they can come up with?' Surely, Dame Enid Lyons did something more significant that an anniversary could take note of than her actual birth date. I am sorry, but I would have thought that this government could have something of more significance to say about Dame Enid Lyons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jacinta, you denigrate any icon!

—Actually, Senator Coonan, I do know who Dame Enid Lyons is. In fact, I have made submissions to the Lyons Forum, as has been noted here, I think, about two years ago. I cannot say that they took particular note of my comments at the time, but I have been before the Lyons Forum.
—Are you proud of it?
—I am actually proud that they did not take note of my comments at the time, because perhaps that association might be concerning, had they done so.

SPEECH.PARA: But let us go back again and look at the actual issues that were raised in the questions. The issues go to the heart of what role Senator Newman plays as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I think that that is very much the heart of the questions that were raised. How that role is being conducted is quite concerning.

That Senator Newman knew nothing of the broad comments that have been made with respect to a member of the House of Representatives in Queensland is, in my mind, astonishing, particularly given some of the media reports about how backbench Liberal women are reacting. That is why I found it very surprising to hear that Senator Payne also did not address herself to the questions that she was actually taking note of. Senator Payne got up and trotted out a list of purport ed achievements of the Liberal Party but did not deal with the question.

The question was: what is the minister doing with respect to the abhorrent behaviour of one of her colleagues in relation to the status of women? Finally, after interjections, she conceded that she would actually make an opportunity to do something about it. Originally, she was going to say that she might do something, should an opportunity arise. Interjections forced her to the position of saying that she would make sure an opportunity occurred.

The other question was in relation to the women's bureau. It is one thing for Senator Newman to say, `We are mainstreaming provision of services for women', but we all know that this government is cutting the heart out of government services directed towards achieving improvements for women. They are cutting the heart out of it and they using mainstreaming as an excuse.

Let us look at HREOC, another recent example. Some of us are very familiar with what HREOC stands for. It is the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. But no, this government is making it the Human Rights and Responsibilities Commission.

The ideology behind it is obvious for any of us who have worked in this area for many years. It is cutting out equal opportunity in the same way they sought to do with workplace relations. If we go back to workplace relations, this government claims to have brought in equal pay in 1972. We improved those provisions. We made equal remuneration the principle. But this government cut that out of the act, too.

Why should we consider equal pay in its broad sense and improve the conditions of women? This government did not want us to. They cut equal remuneration—an internationally recognised principle—out of the Workplace Relations Act, but still we get Senator Crane and Senator Payne standing up here, compromising themselves, not taking into account what was really done with the Workplace Relations Act. That was not done to give women choice; it was done to remove the choice. It did not acknowledge that often in the work force there is a power differential for women in terms of their negotiating position, and they have not got a hope in hell of exercising any real choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am getting heartily sick of the continual allegations that this government stands for anything other than equal opportunity and the promotion of women's rights. It constantly amazes me that commentators and critics alike assert that the Howard government would deliberately or intentionally alienate women—its largest constituency base—who now make up 50.5 per cent of the Australian population, or further, that the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman, would do anything other than strenuously promote and assist women and women's rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this week it was announced that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will be restructured to enhance the role of the former sex discrimination commissioner in that we will now have a deputy president who will be solely responsible for both discrimination and equal opportunity. Enhancing the former functions and the role of the sex discrimination commissioner will hardly cut back rights for women!

The changes to the commission are really very good news for women because they will enhance the educative function and will mean, in particular, that the changing culture of the workplace will not have to wait until a complaint about discrimination is made, but that there will actually be some possibility to address, in the work force, systemic problems with discrimination against women, and real opportunities to do something about it before discrimination complaints need to arise.

That is hardly cutting back on rights for women; it is actually trying to advance the rights of women. It is trying to identify where the previous regime did not hit the mark effectively, and it is trying to address the problems in a much more effective way. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that Senator Newman has done anything other than vigorously promote the rights of women in her role as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women.

For some reason, it seems to be thought by Senator Jacinta Collins, Senator Crowley and others on the other side that mainstreaming will somehow reduce the rights of women. But we all know now that most women do not want to be treated as a special case. They do not want to be pigeon‐holed and stuck somewhere so that they might get a few crumbs from the budget—that is, they might get a grant or they might be remembered in the process of what the big boys get. Most women are now grateful that they are part of the main game. That is what we started out to do. We started out to be recognised as equal participants with equal rights, not only in the work force but also with legitimate claims to government funding.

The notion of mainstreaming simply addresses the need for women to be able to actually get a fair slice of the cake. To suggest, in those circumstances, that Senator Newman somehow is not looking after the interests of women because she may or may not be aware of every little program that might have been rationalised around the place, so that women can be treated as grown‐up and able to access some decent funding for worthwhile programs, is really a silly statement.

What is really serious is that in 1995‐96 sexual harassment continued to be the largest single ground of complaint under the Sexual Discrimination Act. Forty‐eight per cent of complaints were of sexual harassment in the workplace. That, of course, mainly relates to women, and that is why I am so proud that we have enhanced the sex discrimination role in the new commission.

It is a significant achievement of this government; it is a significant achievement for women. Senator Newman and all the coalition women are very proud to be associated with this very significant initiative. It actually addresses the problem in a constructive way. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
