SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to report No. 341 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Financial Reporting of the Commonwealth: Towards greater transparency and accountability . I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
ACTING TREASURER
Parliament HOUSE CANBERRA ACT 2600
Mr A M Somlyay, MP
Chairman
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Mr Somlyay
Attached is the Government's response to recommendations 12-20 the Committee's 341st report entitled "Financial Reporting for the Commonwealth: Towards Greater Transparency".

I will be writing to you separately in my role as Minister for Finance in respect of recommendations 1-11 of the Report. I will again write to the Committee when the Government has further considered the policy issues associated with the implementation of a full accrual budgeting, accounting and reporting framework.

The Government agrees with the Committee (as outlined in recommendation 12 of report 341) that there is a need for legislation to establish a fiscal reporting framework binding on Commonwealth governments. The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 introduced to the House of Representatives on 11 December 1996 will implement the Government's approach to such a reporting framework.
The Government agrees with many of the suggestions of the Committee and a number are incorporated in the Charter. These include requirements that governments:
. report on fiscal indicators that will demonstrate government financial performance (recommendation 15);
. disclose forward year fiscal estimates (recommendation 15);
. provide a statement of government fiscal strategy (recommendation 16);
. provide information on contingent liabilities (recommendation 16);
. update fiscal information midway through the financial year (recommendation 16); and
. present budget outcomes at the end of each year (recommendation 16).

However, a number of specific recommendations are not included in the Charter. To a large extent these are the recommendations that seek to require governments to report on specific fiscal measures within a particular accounting framework. The Government's view is that the legislation

should not be prescriptive about fiscal measures and the accounting framework. This less prescriptive approach enables government reporting to adjust to changing fiscal objectives and incorporate future developments in accounting and reporting. Accordingly, the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 provides a more flexible framework for government reporting notwithstanding this Government's in principle agreement to the phased implementation of a full accrual budgeting and reporting framework.
Yours sincerely
JOHN FAHEY

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12

The Government should prepare and introduce into Parliament legislation to establish a fiscal reporting framework binding on Commonwealth governments, such legislation to be called the Fiscal Reporting Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with this recommendation and introduced the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 to the House of Representatives on 11 December 1996. The Charter will establish a framework for the formulation and reporting of fiscal policy, and will be binding on all future Commonwealth governments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13
The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should require:
a) that fiscal reports be prepared in the form of whole of government reports on an accrual basis; and
b) that the form and content of fiscal reports for the Commonwealth accord with the Committee's recommendations in Chapter 2 of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Charter does not specify the scope or form of government accounting. Instead the Charter has a general provision requiting government reports to have regard to the standards set by external agencies, including those of the accounting profession. Where a government is to report on a basis different to external reporting standards, the proposed approach and the reasons for the departure are to be explained. This aspect of the Charter aims to ensure government reporting keeps abreast of best practice as perceived by external standard setters unless there is good reason for the government to depart from the prescribed reporting approach.

With respect to whole of government accrual reporting, the Committee would be aware of the release of the Australian Accounting Standard on Financial Reporting by Government (AAS31). Moreover, the Government has accepted, in principle, the introduction of an integrated accruals based financial management framework incorporating budgeting, accounting and reporting, including reporting on a consolidated whole of government basis, subject to a scoping study being undertaken to examine costs and other implementation issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14
The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should require:
a) that the Commonwealth adopt accrual budgeting following the tabling of the first audited whole of government reports for the Commonwealth; and
b) that the first accrual budget for the Commonwealth be introduced into Parliament for the 1999‐2000 financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: As is the case with accrual reporting arrangements, the Government does not consider that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 is an appropriate vehicle to specify accrual budgeting

As noted above. the Government has accepted, in principle, the introduction of an integrated accruals based financial management framework, subject to a scoping study of the costs and other implementation issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15
The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should require the tabling or publication of fiscal reports of specified format, as follows:
a) that an agreed set of indicators of a government's financial performance—including net debt as a proportion of GDP—be specified in the legislation;
b) that governments be required to report against these indicators their achievements and future policies in each report required under the legislation;
c) that fiscal reports incorporate estimates for the budget year and the following four years of all major fiscal variables (such as net debt);
d) that the fiscal reports specify the macroeconomic assumptions on which estimates are based;
e) that fiscal reports incorporate forecasts or projections for the budget year and the following four years of all appropriate economic indicators on which fiscal estimates are based;
f) that fiscal reports contain a statement of sensitivity of fiscal estimates to economic conditions;
g) that the format and context of the fiscal reports prepared under this Act remain constant over time to allow historical comparisons.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that governments should regularly report against a set of indicators that will allow for the evaluation of a government's financial performance. However, the Government considers that these indicators should be specified by individual governments and not set in legislation. The Government does not consider there is one set of indicators that will meet all requirements. The most relevant indicators will depend on contemporary fiscal circumstances and the fiscal strategy adopted by the government of the day to address those circumstances. Accordingly, the Charter requires each government to outLine its fiscal strategy and to report against that strategy using the most relevant fiscal indicators.

Similarly the Government does not believe that legislation should require the format and context of all fiscal reports to remain constant This would limit the ability of reporting to reflect changing priorities and adapt to developments in external reporting standards

The Government agrees that government fiscal reports should incorporate estimates of all major fiscal variables for the budget year and a number of years into she future. The Government believes the current practice of providing fiscal estimates for the budget year and three forward years is appropriate as longer run projections would suffer from reduced reliability

The Government agrees that all fiscal reports should specify the macroeconomic assumptions on which estimates are based and that all economic indicators on which fiscal estimates are based should be outlined The Government also agrees that fiscal reports should contain details of the sensitivity of fiscal estimates to economic conditions

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 16
The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should require the tabling or publication of fiscal reports in accordance with a mandatory reporting cycle, as follows:

a) that governments be required to table a statement three calender months prior to the day on which the Budget is introduced into the Parliament stating their Fiscal Strategy for the coming financial year and the next two years;
b) thatch on the day the Budget is tabled in Parliament, the Treasurer table a statement specifying how the Budget conforms with the Fiscal Strategy;
c) that, on the day the Budget is tabled in Parliament, the Treasurer table Budget Papers;
d) that the Budget Papers contain the following information:
‐ the Commonwealth operating statement, including estimates for the budget year and the following four years;
‐ the financial position of the Commonwealth including estimates for the budget year and the following four years;
‐ the statement of cash flows for the Commonwealth, including estimates for the budget year and the following four years;
‐ notes to the financial statements including information about contingent liabilities, restricted financial assets and capital expenditure commitments;
‐ statement of borrowings and other financial commitments; and
‐ accrual based forward estimates of each government agency funded from Consolidated Revenue;

e) that the operating statement, statement of financial position and statement of cash flows for the Commonwealth, including forward estimates, be updated and published midway through the financial year; and
f) that accrual budget outcomes and audited whole of government financial statements be published as soon as they are available.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that governments should release a fiscal strategy statement that outlines the government's fiscal strategy and update this strategy when it changes in response to changing circumstances.

The Government fees not agree that the fiscal strategy statement should be released 3 months before the budget. The Government views a fiscal strategy statement as an integral part of the budget to be released at the time of other budget documentation.

The Charter sets out a comprehensive reporting cycle that will result in more frequent and comprehensive fiscal reporting. For example, the Charter introduces mid-year reporting of the economic and fiscal outlook. Enhanced disclosure is also achieved through requirements for disclosure of risks to the budget. including potential costs such as contingent liabilities, and the disclosure of information on the cost of tax expenditures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 17

The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should provide that the Treasury prepare a condensed version of the Budget Papers, to be tabled with the Budget Papers, in a format which is accessible to the general public and which includes a commentary explaining the meaning of the budget figures to lay readers unfamiliar with economic concepts or accounting terminology.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury currently prepares a Budget Overview and Economic Outlook that aims to summarise the budget and the economic outlook in an easy to read format. The Government is committed to the continued production of this report but does not consider it necessary to legislate for its continued publication.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 18

The proposed Fiscal Reporting Act should establish a joint committee of Parliament to examine and report on fiscal reports produced pursuant to the legislation. All fiscal reports would automatically stand referred to this committee for inquiry and report.
The Act should make specific provision for the committee to call relevant Ministers of State to give evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that existing arrangements allow extensive scrutiny of the Budget and that further provisions are not required.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 19
The proposed Fiscal Reporting Bill should be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts following its tabling in the House, for inquiry and report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that Parliament should determine if the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 is to be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 20

The Department of Finance and the Treasury should commence discussions in the Heads of Treasuries forum with a view to identifying technical and procedural issues that would need to be addressed prior to encouraging the adoption by all Australian States and Territories of mirror fiscal reporting legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that fiscal responsibility,v legislation has considerable merit for the States and Territories but also recognises that adoption of such legislation is a matter tor each government to considers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern:

PARA.TAB: (i) the failure of the Government to protect the interests of older Australians,
(ii) government policies which have resulted in growing levels of economic insecurity for older Australians, including a decline in job opportunities and forced early retirements,
(iii) the massive transfer of funding responsibility from the general community to older people which will result from implementation of the aged care changes on 1 October 1997,
(iv) that the new aged care measures will, for the first time, link access to care to income rather than need, and

(v) that older people will have to bear a disproportionate share of other government cuts and charges, such as those to pharmaceutical benefits, home and community care, superannuation and redundancy payments; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to reconsider its policies for older people and, specifically, to reintroduce capital funding for nursing homes, thus removing the requirement for entry and extra daily fees, with the hardship this is causing older Australians and their families.

The motion that is before the Senate today deals with a matter that is of particular concern to me—that is, the treatment of the elderly by this government. I have the privilege of residing on the central coast of New South Wales where many people who are elderly have travelled to retire and enjoy all the benefits and pleasures that a seaside lifestyle at Penrith prices provides.

Since the election, and with all the things that have occurred, they have been telling me very loud and clear that life is more difficult for them now than it has been for a very, very long time. The elderly in the Australian community are being hurt in very many ways: the provision of health services—including dental health, hearing services, pharmaceuticals and hospital funding—the failure of this government, despite their promises, to do anything about private health insurance; the changes to social security; and the restriction of benefits, particularly the requirement that older Australians access their superannuation at age 55 before they can get unemployment benefits, even if they intend to go back into the work force.

BREAK.PARA: The general attitude of the federal government to unemployment impacts also on older Australians as many people between the ages of 50 and 60, who previously enjoyed that decade in making a final contribution in the work force, now find that there is no place for them. They have also cut grants to state governments, which means that a whole range of services—including the funding of public hospitals and the services which our elderly people used to rely upon in order to have a lifestyle that, I believe, they are entitled to expect—are no longer available to them.

I have to say that, for me, the cruellest, the most distasteful and the most vicious of all the things that have happened in relation to elderly people is what has occurred with our nursing homes. Nursing homes are those things that all of us would like to avoid. We all hope that we will go into old age healthy and happy and able to enjoy all the things we would have liked to have enjoyed when we were younger but did not have the time. But the reality is that, for many people, as they get older their health deteriorates, and quite markedly for some people. For this group of people—the elderly, the very unhealthy and the frail—nursing homes are not an option; they are an absolute necessity.

People do not go into nursing homes for a holiday. They do not go there because it would be a bit of fun to visit a nursing home. They go there because they have no other option. The vast majority of people who now reside in nursing homes—and, I believe, the group of people that will continue to reside in nursing homes—are frail, elderly women who have chronic illnesses. It is this defenceless group of people which this government has decided to single out for particular punishment.

As from 1 October 1997—this is why it is important to have this debate today to emphasise the issue—they will have to pay up‐front fees for nursing home care if they have, in the opinion of this government, assets from which to pay, and that includes their family home. The only limitation on the amount of fees that are payable is that, after a lifetime of contribution and hard work, residents will be left with the princely sum of only $22,500. It is really quite appalling.

I remember that when this issue was first raised in this chamber we heard extensively from Senator Newman about how we were exaggerating about the size of these up‐front fees. When we used the figure of $27,000, Senator Newman said that we were using scare tactics—her favourite term—that we were scare mongering and that, in fact, the fees would not be anything like that. I suppose in the usual situation of politics, some people might have thought it was true that we were exaggerating. But let me tell you: what we predicted was far below what the fees have turned out to be.

During the Senate community affairs inquiry we took extensive evidence from all sorts of people involved in the nursing home industry. In particular, we heard from those who are suppliers of nursing homes, those people who run the business of providing age care. We also heard from the churches in particular that provide nursing homes on a not for profit basis. That second group of people assured us that they would attempt to still cater for those people who could not afford it. But they said that the situation was made extraordinarily difficult because of the paltry amount of money that this government was prepared to offer to subsidise disadvantaged residents.

I have digressed for a moment. I go back to the evidence that was given to us about the size of the fees. We received evidence that, on average, the entry fee for residents who had to pay fees would be $40,000. That is well in excess of anything the minister has ever conceded. That is not where it stops. Some providers of nursing home care went even further. They said that, in fact, some fees in some of the more salubrious nursing homes—I suppose you are a bit unlucky if you have only those sorts of nursing homes available—would be well in excess of $100,000.

It is a very sad situation when these elderly and frail are not able to get access to nursing homes unless they have that sort of money available. Also, from 1 November 1997, every nursing home user will pay a daily fee of 25c per dollar earned outside the pension free area—effectively, a tax of 25 per cent. The end result of this system of up‐front entry fees and daily fees will be the development of a two‐tier system of aged care.

This is the proposition that the Howard government is providing for our aged and our elderly. There are two groups. There are the well off that can go to well‐appointed nursing homes, maybe of the standard of a five‐star hotel, or not too far off. They will be well cared for. There is a second level for those who are not so well off, who do not have those sorts of assets, who do not have that sort of money available to them and who do not potentially have affluent members of their family who are prepared or able to bail them out. Those people will go to the second tier of nursing homes—those starved of resources. It is a very sad situation when those are the options that are being provided for our elderly.

I mentioned at some length the other nursing home changes that occurred and how they affect our elderly people. But I suppose I have not really talked about how all these changes affect elderly people, what the pensioners in Woy Woy and in every other area of Australia feel when they see these sorts of changes occurring. You might think you have got away with it. You might think these people have not noticed. To some extent they have not felt the full impact yet because a lot of the changes do not come into effect until this year and some of them not till next year or even later.

The elderly people in our community feel that they have contributed a great deal during their lifetime. Many of them have gone through the Depression, have gone through world war, have seen economic recession and now see many of their children and their grandchildren unemployed. On top of all that—the difficulties and problems—they now see a government that does not care about them and is in fact prepared to punish them in trivial and callous ways.

I have dealt mainly with the nursing homes. My colleagues will deal with some of the other areas that I listed earlier. Let me sound a warning: if you believe that the elderly of Australia will lie down and take this and they will not tell you how they are affected the next time they go to the ballot, you are very much mistaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating yet again the issue of aged care, a subject that should be very near and dear to the hearts of the opposition because, after all, they were in government for 13 years. Yet what never ceases to amaze me is the fact that we never saw them initiate debates on aged care when they were in government—quite the reverse. The legacy they left this government in aged care is nothing short of breathtaking. It is disgraceful. It is something about which they should be thoroughly and utterly ashamed, yet it is an issue which they conveniently ignore.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Neal has just spoken for approximately 10 minutes and she did not tell the Senate or the people of Australia one single solitary word about what the Labor government did for 13 years to aged people and aged care in particular. Therefore, I think it is about time the Senate was informed of their record. They left a totally and utterly inflexible aged care system incapable of meeting the rapidly increased demands. Even today, thanks to the Labor governments, we still have nearly 40 per cent of residents sharing a room of four beds or more and we are trying to turn that around.

Did we hear Senator Neal say that after 13 years we had more than 40 per cent of people sharing rooms with four beds or more? No, she did not tell the Senate that. Did she tell the Senate how many old people had lost their dignity and their privacy as a consequence of that particular policy alone? No, she did not. Did she tell the Senate that a small proportion of nursing homes still do not meet the health regulations and requirements? Did she say that at the end of 13 years of Labor government 15 per cent of nursing homes did not meet health requirements and that a further 11 per cent did not meet fire requirements? No: zip the lip, absolutely not a syllable about that.

Did Senator Neal tell the Senate that in 1992-93 a total of $45 million was spent on capital stock but by 1993-94 it had declined to $26.5 million, by 1994-95 it was down to $15 million and by 1995-96 it was down to $10.7 million? For Senator Neal's benefit I emphasise this: that just happens to be a 75 per cent reduction in funding. Far from coming in here carping, criticising and scaremongering the way they have been doing for 18 months, they should be coming in here hanging their heads in shame and apologising to the aged people of Australia for slicing off 75 per cent of aged care funding during their 13 years of government.

It is an absolute and utter disgrace. It is something about which they should be appalled, but no. They come in here exaggerating, scaremongering, simply distorting every element of truth that is possible to be distorted and they have no shame—no shame whatsoever. That decline in funding represents, as I say, a $35 million decline. That took place over a very short number of years.

The difference is that the changes we are proposing are designed to bring better consumer protection, better and more sustainable funding, better buildings and better facilities for the care of residents. Yet the Labor Party comes in and complains about it. Having cut $35 million out of it just with the snap of a finger, they come in and complain about a policy that is designed to create those things. Where is their sanity? If they have lost all logic, surely to goodness they have not lost all sanity.

Senator Neal is about to walk out because she does not care about their legacy. She does not care about what they have done. She very carefully made sure that she did not tell the Senate about it. Here she has this longwinded mumbo jumbo notice of motion today. We have been forced to debate about their absolute and utter disregard for what they have left this government to deal with. That is just despicable, absolutely and utterly despicable.

The system, I have to say, was in total and utter crisis. Dementia support was all but ignored. How can anyone in this day and age exonerate any government that ignores that factor? Couples were sometimes forced to separate under the former Labor government. That was a regular occurrence, but we are not hearing about that today. Those types of issues are the very issues that we are trying now to reverse.

Yet what did the Labor Party do? They were the ones that created the problem. People who enter hostels were forced to enter a nursing home as soon as their needs changed. The majority of homes and hostels do provide good service. However, the highly intrusive and bureaucratic, yet inefficient, standard monitoring system of Labor all too often failed to identify and redress poor quality care. That is simply a statement of fact. If it were not a statement of fact, we would not have the situation that we inherited.

As I said before, there were 15 per cent of nursing homes that failed the health regulations and a further 11 per cent that failed the fire regulations. How could they preside over an administration that allows a system to have old people under such threat and yet come in here now and pretend that it did not even happen? It is just appalling. The restricted mobility, inadequate lighting and frightful toilet facilities shared by many people are the system that the Labor Party put in place. There were buildings with multiple storeys and yet no lifts. How could they possibly, in their right mind, allow that to happen? But these things need to be spelled out because this is the environment with which we were confronted on obtaining government in March last year. Yet the Labor Party now has the gall to criticise the very initiatives that are designed to redress these problems.

Australia absolutely needs reform after 13 years of Labor neglect. We have an ageing population, which they refused also to accept. In 1991 there were less than two million Australians aged over 65. In 30 years time there will be in excess of five million people aged over 65. The Labor government, over 13 years, should have been planning for that. Instead their planning went in the opposite direction. The funding was taken straight out of it. Why? Everyone knows. Blind Freddy knows that the population is getting older. Yet what happened? The funding was taken out of it.

These problems cannot be fixed overnight, but I can tell you that we are trying fix them as rapidly and as comprehensively as we can possibly do. The government has undertaken a substantial reform process which has been distorted by the Labor Party and which has been referred to a committee either chaired by me or of which I have been a member. I cannot get over the amount of distortion and the downright lies that were told during those hearings. There is no other description for some of the things that were claimed at that time.

I am not talking about witnesses because the witnesses, I have to say, in a lot of cases were purely and simply reflecting the misinformation that had been given to them by Labor senators and members in the other chamber—misinformation that had been put out in newsletters. In fact, Madam Deputy President, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) actually drew your attention to a newsletter that you had put out from your office at that time. I think that it is a very sad reflection, because you are someone who had been involved in this committee.

We need to have a responsibility not to terrorise old people—not to terrorise those who are getting to retirement age, but to tell them the truth. Measures contained in the aged care bill will bring substantial capital investment and major improvement to the quality of nursing homes. There is no getting away from that. That has been an accepted fact by most in the aged care industry: that there is a desperate need to make sure that there is a mechanism by which there can be increased funding allocated to aged care.

The 1996 budget laid out the clear vision and framework for the future of aged care. It provides flexibility by giving providers the funding to meet the changing needs of aged care consumers. That is all designed around the fact of providing and promoting security, dignity and compassion—three major elements that were missing in 13 years of Labor government. Newsletter after newsletter after newsletter going out from Labor senators and members are misrepresenting that mere fact.

What the government is trying to do is to ensure that access to care is still based on needs and not means. Again, only today we hear Senator Neal repeat yet again what she has repeated ad nauseam—that there are going to be two classes of residents in aged care hostels and nursing homes. She has been put straight on that issue time and time and time again in hearings. She has been told the facts, yet she still comes in here and misrepresents the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't fit the agenda.

—Exactly, Senator Calvert, it does not fit the agenda. We should be used to it by now—go way back to 1992‐93 and see the lies that were told endlessly about the Fightback package. We should not be surprised. But I am just waiting to see whether there is anyone on the Labor side this time who is prepared to actually tell the truth of what the aged care package is about to do, because I have not heard it from Senator Neal. She has, in fact, simply come in here today and repeated for the umpteenth time the allegations that she made in the committee hearings—the very allegations that were refuted time and time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: Has she said anything about the fact that the government has ensured that places are distributed evenly across Australia? No, she said the reverse. Has she said that the evidence that was given was that most people do not leave nursing homes? No, she said the reverse. Has she said that there is a preference by most people to have share accommodation and not private accommodation? What she is trying to imply is that it is only the wealthy who will get a private room. That is simply not true. The evidence that has been given to the committee has repeated it time and time again. Yet there is not one Labor senator who is prepared to refer to the Hansard, let alone their own memories, and say exactly what was told to them in the committee hearings.

Did Senator Neal come in here and say we will continue to allocate places according to the planning ratio of 100 places for every 1,000 people? No, she did not. She just came in here and said there will be two classes of nursing homes and all the other things that go with it. Did she also say that the assessment teams will continue to permit access according to need—no-one gets in unless they are approved for residential care by an assessment team? No, she did not. Did she say protection will be there for those who are financially disadvantaged or concessional residents and pensioners? She actually said quite the reverse of that.

How can someone keep coming in here misrepresenting so badly the information that they have been given? They could be forgiven if they did it once. But when they repeatedly do it, it is unforgivable. Everyone who has sat through any of the hearings, everyone who has read the bill and everyone who has read any information or literature put out on what has been planned knows full well that there are protections in place in the legislation package for the financially disadvantaged concessional residents and pensioners.

Let us see if we have it repeated yet again. Let us also see whether we have a statement of the fact that services will be required to set aside at the national average of 27 per cent a number of places for concessional residents. That is not what Senator Neal just said. She said the reverse; she said that those who are concessional residents will not get access. Here we have it said time and time again. But the fact of the matter is that 27 per cent of those places will be set aside for such people. The government is committed to a sustainable aged care system which responds to the needs of the ageing population.

I find this whole exercise that has been undertaken by the Labor Party today just so awful that words fail to describe it. I will listen with interest to see whether a shred of factual truth is offered by the Labor Party in any of this debate. I as sure as heck have not heard it from Senator Neal yet; in fact, I have heard the reverse. It is about time the Labor Party stopped terrorising the aged community right across Australia. We are trying to turn around a disgraceful 75 per cent reduction in funding that was wrought on this industry by the previous Labor government over 13 years of mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would they?

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent some time over the last couple of months visiting some aged care centres. One that I visited is in the area where I live, Heathcote in New South Wales. I have had some recent experience in talking to people who have come to me where their families are in that situation. In conclusion on this issue, I want to remind Senator Knowles that, quite clearly, the people involved in the provision of aged care know that your proposal will not work. Unfortunately, people are going to suffer before that is proven to this government. The government will not listen now but they will have to listen in 12 months or so, and they will certainly listen at the next election.

What other things has this government done? Looking through the record, I was trying to find something positive that the government has done for older Australians but I could not find one. I could find a long list of things that this government has implemented, either through the budgetary process or through legislation in the parliament, which will have a very deleterious effect on older people. For a start, let us look at health insurance.

This government trumpeted that it was going to fix the declining membership in private health insurance. Many older people have private health insurance because they believe that in their later years they are more susceptible to illness or accident and feel the need for greater security. More importantly, many older Australians are in health funds because they have been in those health funds for many years. They have stayed with the funds notwithstanding the huge increases in premiums that have occurred in the last 18 months whilst this government has been in office, increases in the order of 20 to 30 per cent. All the funds have been applying to put up their premiums and have been allowed to do so by this government.

In addition to elderly people having to find an extra $200, $300 or $400 per year for their health insurance coverage—and they are not in a position to opt out—this government has tried the old `fistful of dollars' trick. Remember Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser's famous fistful of dollars? That is what this government has done with respect to private health insurance. It has implemented a scheme whereby it says, `If you take out private health insurance, or if you already have it, we will give you $225 or, in the case of a family, $450 a year as a rebate.'

That did not come into operation until July 1997, the beginning of this financial year, so many people will not receive the rebate for 12 months, until the end of this financial year. The government, at the same time that they have offered that, have allowed the private health funds to savagely increase their premiums. I provided evidence during the Senate estimates hearings of elderly people who had written to me and to other members of the opposition—apparently, they had written to government members as well but they took no notice, of course—telling us how this supposed rebate system was not going to cover anywhere near the cost of increases in their health insurance premiums. So you have conned elderly people on that measure.

What else has this government done? The list goes on. Look what they have done with respect to pharmaceuticals. In the last budget, they de‐listed a number of drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits schedule—drugs which, if provided on prescription, were available at cheaper prices to all people, including elderly people. Many elderly people, as we know, have a greater need to visit doctors and they place great store in the advice of the medical profession.

This government has removed from the pharmaceutical benefits schedule prescriptions which include those for the treatment of common gastrointestinal problems and anti‐ inflammatory liniment for pain relief of sprains and muscle strains—something which many elderly people suffer from, as Senator Eggleston would know. They require pain relief for arthritis and similar conditions. This government has taken a number of those drugs off the list. They will be more expensive for elderly people to buy. The budget papers state that these changes will apply to eligible veterans and their dependants in respect of the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. So they do not even get an exemption from some of the increases that will apply because of de‐listing.

Because of what is known as the therapeutic group premiums changes, elderly people will be forced to pay higher prices for drugs which may be prescribed by their doctors for the treatment of depression, ulcers, high blood pressure or high cholesterol.

We have to seriously ask: what sort of government takes these measures, particularly when they will impact severely upon the most vulnerable groups in our community—the sick and the elderly? In the estimates committee hearings, we heard evidence that some of these drugs will be grouped, and only the cheapest drug will be available under the PBS. If a doctor prescribes a drug which is similar in nature but not quite the same, because he believes the patient needs that particular brand of drug and not the one that is listed on the PBS, in some cases they will pay up to $20, $30 or $40 for these drugs, rather than the subsidised price. Again, the elderly are being hit with potentially massive increases in their health care.

What about palliative care funding? If anything is important for the aged community, it is the provision of adequate palliative care. Fortunately, over recent years, society has recognised more and more the importance of palliative care for people in their later years. What did this government do? It reduced funding to the palliative care program by 10 per cent. Under the Labor government, during those 13 years that Senator Knowles talked about, funding for palliative care increased because, as Senator Knowles recognised, we have an ageing population. Also, as I said, there was a greater recognition that that area of health care required additional funds. But Senator Knowles did not talk about how funding increased during the 13 years of the Labor government. And she sure as heck did not mention how it went down in the first 18 months of this coalition government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there is so much to say that I should get an extension of time. We should be debating this matter for the rest of the day. What about the dental health program—a great initiative of the Labor government which provided free dental care for the elderly, for pensioners? What did this government do? It abolished it. It said, `Out; that's it, gone.'

What about the closure of Medicare offices? Forty‐three Medicare offices throughout Australia are to be closed down. Can you imagine the impact that that will have on elderly people? In the past they were able to go to the local Medicare office in their suburb. It gave them the opportunity to lodge their claims. They walked up the street one day and found that the office was gone. They might now have to get on a train or a bus and travel five or 10 kilometres to the nearest office.

BREAK.PARA: It is going to get worse, because this government has today introduced legislation into the other place which intends to corporatise—probably privatise, in the future—Medibank Private. In future, under that legislation, Medicare offices will no longer provide Medibank Private services. So, an elderly person who now is able to go to their local Medicare office, lodge their Medicare claim and lodge a claim with Medibank Private in future will not be able to do that. In future the 270‐odd Medicare offices throughout Australia that currently also provide Medibank Private facilities will all cease to provide those facilities and there will be only 70 Medibank Private offices throughout the country. I will say more on that when the legislation comes into the Senate.

Senator Knowles talks about 13 years of Labor government. She should go and visit some of the magnificent new facilities for aged care that were built in our era in government. She should go to John Paul II retirement village in Heathcote and have a look for herself. Then she should have a look at what this government has done in 18 months. The only good thing that is happening is that some of the people within the cabinet that have been responsible for these decisions are getting out. I fear, however, that the replacements are not going to be any better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to points (iii) and (v) of Senator Neal's notice of motion. Before I do so, I would like to say that so far the opposition speakers on this motion have engaged in a litany of misrepresentation and falsehood. Let us take what Senator Forshaw has just said about the closure of Medicare offices. He well knows that the government is introducing a system whereby people can lodge Medicare claims in pharmacies, and that is being trialled in this country at the moment. Instead of having to hop on a bus or a train and travel five or 10 miles to the nearest Medicare office, they will be able to go to the pharmacy and fill in a form; there will be a fax machine there which will fax it straight into Medicare. That will be a lot easier, a lot simpler and a lot less costly to the government. That is something that Senator Forshaw knows is in train. What he asserted is an example of the kind of misrepresentation that is going on in this chamber today on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Neal claimed, in true Labor scare tactic fashion, that there will be a massive transfer of funding responsibility from the general community to older people as a result of the government's aged care reform package. That, of course, is absolute nonsense. Nothing could be further from the truth. The government is providing a system under which the conditions and services provided to the aged will improve. When one considers that we are dealing with an opposition who, when they were in government, massively cut funding to aged care, one can only wonder at the depth of their hypocrisy on this matter. I repeat that point: the reality is that, while in government, the ALP massively cut funding to aged care.

As Senator Knowles has said—I repeat it for emphasis—in 1992‐93, when Labor were in government, some $45 million was available to nursing homes for capital improvement purposes. By 1995-96, this had been reduced to $10.7 million—a 75 per cent reduction. That is pretty massive in anybody's terms. Furthermore, only $2.7 million of this money was available for upgrading old and substandard services.

The appalling state of Australia's nursing homes which was left by Labor for older Australians is why the government has introduced the aged care reform package that it has. The reforms the government has introduced are critical, because aged care facilities in this country were left to decay as a result of the policies of the previous government. What we are talking about are dingy facilities with beds packed together in overcrowded rooms, shared toilets, and so on. Anybody who has been to many of the nursing homes in Australia can only be depressed by what they saw and appalled to think that our older citizens, at the end of their lives, are left to live in these forms of accommodation. Surely, the government argued, our older citizens deserved a lot better than the kinds of facilities that they had to go to.

BREAK.PARA: The government has sought to address the needs of Australia's ageing population. It has to be remembered that the number of aged persons is going up rapidly, and we are increasingly going to have to consider the needs of the aged. In 1991 there were fewer than two million Australians aged over 65. In 30 years time, there will be five million, and they will represent a much more significant percentage of our population than the aged do today. The greying of Australia is a real phenomenon which future governments will have to deal with.

In spite of what the opposition has said today, the measures the government is putting in place with respect to nursing homes will ensure that access to residential aged care is based on need and not means. I repeat: it will be based on need and not means and will provide equity for the Australian population. No-one will be denied care or access to a nursing home on the basis of their bank balance, and no-one will be forced to sell their home to gain entry to an aged care facility.

The coalition government is committed to providing both equity and social justice for all older Australians by introducing changes to funding arrangements for nursing homes. In fact, what the government is doing is following the pattern which the opposition, when in government, introduced for hostels. The government understands that few residents of aged care facilities can afford to pay for the whole cost of their care and also recognises that some contribution to the cost of care is a fair and reasonable expectation. The initiatives of the aged care reform package aim to ensure that facilities for aged care are at an acceptable standard to the community and also meet the needs of Australia's ageing population.

One of the great hypocrisies about the opposition's position today is that the reforms the coalition government has made to aged care—namely, the introduction of accommodation bonds—are similar, and copied from, a program which Labor introduced in 1988 to provide for accommodation bonds for entry to hostels. The purpose of that was to improve the standards of the hostels and improve the conditions under which hostel residents live. That program has been extremely successful. I find it totally hypocritical of the opposition to suggest today that a similar program introduced to nursing homes will not be equally successful in improving the standards of nursing homes.

It has been said by Senator Forshaw today that people will have to pay $80,000 to $100,000 to get into a nursing home. Of course that is not actually true. First of all, people do not have to pay any bonds at all for six months. They can pay a weekly accommodation fee. It is also true that something like 40 per cent of nursing home residents are not in residence after six months. It is only after six months that the question of paying a full accommodation bond arises. The reason 40 per cent of people or thereabouts are not in residence after six months is, rather sadly, that they have usually died. So the question of somebody who is terminally ill or in a critical state having to sell the family home to cover the cost of a high accommodation bond simply does not arise.

Senator Neal spoke at length about the possibility of a two-tiered system developing within our nursing home system in Australia. Again, as Senator Knowles has pointed out, that simply is not the case. By law, 27 per cent of the residents in all of these facilities will be concessional residents; that is, they will be people who are on social security. Thus, there will always be a mix in all of these nursing homes so that a two-tiered system simply does not develop.

I would like to go on to the question of pharmaceutical benefits. The claim that older Australians will face an unfair burden on the cost of pharmaceutical benefits is really quite unfounded—another example of the misrepresentation which has been going on here today. Senator Forshaw referred to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which was developed to provide affordable access for all members of the Australian community to necessary and cost-effective medicines. He talked about medications being taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list. He sought to imply, therefore, that older people would be disadvantaged and somehow left to suffer because things like liniment were being taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list.

That is absolute rubbish. Certainly medicines are being taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list all the time because the Department of Health and Family Services is constantly reviewing the list to ensure that the costs of providing medications do not get out of hand. Nevertheless, there is always medication available within that list of pharmaceutical benefits to cover all or most medical situations, particularly in the case of people suffering with arthritis. I assure him that there is an almost endless number of medications—non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)—available on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I have no doubt that a wide variety of choice in that kind of medication will remain there.

The fact of the matter is that the government carries over 80 per cent of the outlays on pharmaceutical benefits scheme medications. That amounts—I would like to record for the benefit of the opposition today—to some $2,500 million annually. That is the cost for 1996-97. There is both a concessional system and a safety net system in place which, from my understanding, means that the cost of pharmaceutical medicine is fairly and equitably shared by the Australian community.

Persons who, for various reasons, qualify for concessions pay only $3.20 per pharmaceutical benefit prescription, which is not a great deal of money. It means that they have access to the full range of medications at a vastly reduced cost. The safety net system is designed for both concessional and non-concessional patients, for old and young Australians. For instance, once the eligible expenditure of a person on medication exceeds $612.60 within a calendar year, the co‐payment or the actual cost to the patient decreases from $20 an item to just $3.20.

I do not see how this system is increasing the cost of pharmaceutical benefits to older Australians, whether concessional or non‐concessional. The safety net system can be said to provide equity of access to pharmaceutical benefits for all Australians, including older Australians. This is something which the opposition has sought to misrepresent here this afternoon.

Senator Neal also claimed that older Australians face a disproportionate share of funding cuts to home and community care—or HACC, as it is known. The HACC program's objective is to support frail older people and to enable them to remain in their homes by the provision of a comprehensive range of high quality and cost‐effective services. The government recognises the value of that and understands that it is much more cost‐effective to keep people in their homes than to have them in hospitals and being cared for in institutions. It is not only cost‐effective but also better for them psychologically because they are in their own home surroundings.

In the 1996‐97 budget, the government announced its commitment to maintain growth in the HACC program while at the same time recognising that the capacity to improve equity user charges across services should be recognised. In the 1997‐98 budget, the government announced further growth in the HACC program of some $25 million. I believe that this demonstrates that the government is committed to the continuance of the HACC program and sees the value of it. There is no question but that the government will maintain the home and community care program because it understands its value and importance to the aged and elderly people of Australia.

In conclusion, I believe that the changes the coalition government has made to aged care are both fair and equitable and that the government has demonstrated that it has an ongoing commitment to providing quality services to the aged people in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation with regard to unemployment for older Australians is this. In June 1997, 91,700 people aged 50 and over were looking for work. That is a very disturbing statistic indeed. Of these people, 44,000 have been looking for work for a year or longer. Whilst 12 per cent of unemployed people are 50 and over, this group accounts for 19 per cent of all people who are out of work for more than a year. Men aged 50 and over make up 20 per cent of the ranks of long‐term unemployed.

It is axiomatic that older people stay unemployed for very long periods and they are disproportionately represented in the ranks of the long‐term unemployed. Clearly, this is a very dismal situation and something that needs to be addressed.

In terms of the breakdown of age versus unemployment, the ABS found in a recent labour force survey that age was identified by 44 per cent of respondents aged 45 as the biggest single problem in securing employment. This is not good news for anybody, especially those of us—although we all are—getting older in relation to finding employment. At age 55, age was identified as the biggest single problem by 65 per cent of respondents. With regard to participation rate compared with 30 years ago and now: 30 years ago, the participation rate in the labour force for 45s and over was 80.
