In contrast, the Industry Commission notes that the Howard Government has cut economy‐wide labour market programs from $2.73 billion in 1995‐06 to $1.89 billion this year—
this is the editor's comment, not mine—

(maybe they had too much of Mr Keating in them). And the TCF Labour Adjustment Package— originally due to run until 2000 to help displaced workers get jobs outside the industry—was abolished in the 1996 budget. Sure, such labour market programs have a mixed record (but no more so than handouts to capital). And the Howard Government cutbacks are part of an innovative experiment in shifting the delivery of training programs to the private sector.

Whilst I obviously do not agree with all of it, basically this editorial is saying that there has to be some assistance to workers in these industries to provide predispositions for displacement and adjustment where industries are going through a major restructuring.
With regard to TCF again, the minority report prepared by Mr Philip Brass suggested:
It is unreasonable to permit the toll of tariff reform to fall so heavily on TCF employees, many of whom are drawn from vulnerable and disadvantaged groups in society.
It is from these groups that mature aged employees are represented.

Do not think white‐collar workers are safe from what is happening at the moment either. In terms of the white-collar sector, there is definitely attrition with regard to older workers. We have evidence that the tax office, for example, is having forced redundancies—something this government said it would not do. There have been 25 to date and there will be more to follow. Clearly, the ATO is being used as a groundbreaker with regard to forced redundancies and in terms of the so‐called reforms of the APS this government is embarking on.

So neither sector is being helped by this government. There is no clear industry policy and, for those of us who have been involved in the industry inquiry conducted by the Senate Economics Committee—and that includes you, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson—that is a message that is coming through loud and clear. There is no discernible industry policy.

What we have had is flip‐flopping, depending on the electoral imperatives or depending on how much pressure is put on the Prime Minister with regard to that. I understand that is causing some concern on the other side of the chamber, but there is no industry policy. Business is, therefore, not investing because it does not know what the preconditions are with regard to the economy and economic development.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the highest private sector investment figures in about 10 years at the moment. Did you see that? Don't let the facts get in the way of a good speech.

—I will remind the senator that we also have 8.7 per cent unemployment, and we have an employment minister who says that it is important that workers have less security. That is her panacea and this government's panacea for unemployment—make sure workers are more insecure, make sure they have less security and make sure they have less access.

SPEECH.PARA: What is this government doing? Not much, you would be surprised to know, other than adding to the economic insecurity and job insecurity which already exists in older Australians. I refer again to Senator Vanstone's comments at the CEDA meeting, where she said, `We need a freer labour market and lessened job security to reduce unemployment.' The quote was, `You have to have, it might be described as, lessened job security.'

Full marks to Senator Vanstone for telling the truth about what this government actually believes. She actually told the truth about what this government believes. Normally, we have these comments from the likes of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), who talks about flexibility. He says, `What we need is more flexibility.' That is code for reduced employment security and lessened job security. Senator Vanstone had the intestinal fortitude to actually come out and say it. She blew the whistle on what the agenda of this government is with regard to workers in Australia.

Senator Vanstone also said—and, again, full marks to her for saying this—that the government's spending cuts were partly to blame for high unemployment. Absolutely; 10 out of 10 to Senator Vanstone for telling the truth here. I do not think many of her colleagues on the other side appreciated it, but I am pleased to say that her comments have been echoed and agreed with around Australia, particularly in my home state of Tasmania, where the head of the TDR cited very clearly how expenditure cuts in a regional microcosm like Tasmania had affected unemployment—a state which, everybody in this chamber would be aware, has the highest unemployment rate in Australia.

What else has this government done? It has slashed labour market programs and not put anything in their place. There is no regional development policy. I note with some interest though that the papers a couple of weekends ago reported that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, would be forced to have a look at regional development policies because the economies in those regions were in such a parlous state that something had to be done. Hooray! How long has it taken Mr Howard to wake up to that?

Working Nation, a Labor initiative, was slashed. Why? As far as people in my state are concerned, they do not know why. Working Nation was a very worthwhile initiative. It was slashed because the government has a different ideological perspective with regard to employment generation. In my state and in other areas of high unemployment, the cuts to that program had a devastating effect.

In 1995‐96 there were 17 private or community sector case managers contracted by the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, ESRA, as mature age specialists. What has this government done? The government, under the new employment services provisions, has thrown the mature age unemployed to the market to determine their employability. It is a market which has already got a culture of not employing people who are 45 or over—that culture is unfortunately there—and a market that has declining job opportunities for the mature age unemployed.

In 1996 under Labor, we had 17 mature worker centres which helped the mature age unemployed improve their skills via education or training. These centres also provided counselling, development of activities to meet participants' training needs, job referrals and advocacy to prospective employers. There was also an emphasis—interestingly, because we are dealing with older workers here—on information technology training. Where are those mature age centres? What has happened now? They are gone. Abolished. Why? Because of cuts to skillshare. They are gone. That is what this government thinks of mature age workers.
Then we have the government's work for the dole scheme. That is not going to help young people—never mind people who are in the mature age category. I think it is farcical to believe otherwise.

We move on to what else the government has done and we move on to industrial relations, one of my favourite topics. Just harking back to Senator Vanstone's comment with regard to industrial relations, she talked about a freer labour market and lessened job security. The industrial relations provisions brought in by this government should satisfy Senator Vanstone, because that is precisely what they are intended to deliver. The industrial relations provisions provide for individual contracts, AWAs, between the employer and the employee where the employing power is definitely on the side of the employer. At estimates, we had some success getting some more information on these AWAs. I am grateful for that. It has taken a long time, and let us see how much we get.

During the passage of the workplace relations bill, we used the example of young people who have to go out and negotiate with their employers about their wages and conditions and we showed how disempowered they would be. Older workers are in exactly the same category.

As I said before, we have a culture whereby people who are 45 and over are finding it difficult to get jobs. If younger people are disempowered as a result of the provisions in the Workplace Relations Act, how do you think older people are faring? I do not think they are even getting in the door, never mind getting to the stage of actually negotiating an AWA with a prospective employer. So this so-called freer labour market—again, as Senator Vanstone has stated quite clearly as one of her objectives—is providing a less secure working environment.

In terms of the government sector, we also have outsourcing, downsizing and massive cuts—and many of the public sector workers are in fact older workers. We have the chan ges to superannuation, which I am sure my colleague Senator Sherry will cover in his contribution.

The bottom line under this government is that, if you are 45 or over and out of a job, you will not get any help. The government's policies highlight the government's incapacity, unwillingness and simple lack of care to play an active part in battling unemployment. The government prefers to deal with economic figures rather than human beings. This government prefers to talk about getting the economic fundamentals right and says that everything else will follow. Industry knows that is not right. Mature age workers know that is not right. Certainly, the people on this side of the chamber know that that is not right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to turn my attention back to the substantive matter of the motion before us. It is a shame that those on the other side could not find five speakers who could actually talk about aged care. It has been most interesting listening to Senator Mackay range over industrial relations, unemployment, skillshare reforms, et cetera. Perhaps we should look forward to Senator Sherry talking about child care when he gets up to talk to this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to turn my thoughts and comments this afternoon back to the substantive issue: older Australians. I actually agree with Senator Neal and Senator Forshaw that the interests of older Australians is an issue of utmost importance. It is an issue of importance because older Australians deserve dignity, respect and policies designed to protect and support their interests.

It is also an issue because of our demographics. We all know that Australia's population is ageing. In the next 50 years, the number of people over 80 will rise from one in five to one in three of the population. By 2020, one in every four Australians will be over 65. But it is at this point that my views and those of the Labor senators must diverge.

The coalition is well aware of the issues intrinsic in this situation but, unlike the last Labor government, we tackle the issues head on. The late Labor government's record in the area of aged care is a disgrace. When we took office, we discovered that the Labor government had neglected aged care to an extent that we could hardly comprehend—11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards, 15 per cent of nursing homes did not meet state health standards and 40 per cent of nursing home patients were in a room with four or more beds.

The Labor government neglected our older people in terms of safety, health and dignity. Many of those buildings have serious structural deficiencies and, as a result of the ALP's inactivity, residents and staff are placed in an unsafe environment. Some buildings constitute a serious fire danger—they may not have fire walls, fire exits are blocked and windows do not open. Too many people share a room, as Senator Knowles told us earlier today. Having eight beds in a room severely cramps movement and mobility and grants residents no privacy, no room for personal belongings.

Did the Labor Party care about social justice and equity, or are those issues only mentioned at election time, Senator Conroy? The ALP were warned. Professor Bob Gregory reported to them in 1985 that $125 million was needed to bring nursing home infrastructure up to an acceptable level. Their response to this was an allocation of $10 million a year on a tiered system standard aggregated module—sounds impressive, does it not! But all it really equalled was $3 a day per resident for capital upgrade.

The ALP's record is appalling. The coalition is determined to right this wrong, and the focus given to this area by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is a testament to the coalition's commitment to help and support older Australians. We are not ignoring the elderly. We are consulting, listening and addressing their concerns. We are protecting our people in all those areas where Labor failed them. We are putting in place standards, something Labor never did.

If the physical standards of a nursing home or hostel are inadequate, they will not be able to charge accommodation bonds. The Howard government is going to protect the security of those bonds. We committed ourselves to protect residents' funds, and we have. Under the Labor government, there was no such protection. Our program supports those already in nursing homes. They will not have to pay bonds. So we are protecting the financially disadvantaged, the people Labor neglected, even though they claim it is their major constituency.

For those in the community who cannot afford an accommodation bond, the government has mandated that a national average of 27 per cent of beds that nursing homes must allocate to the financially disadvantaged. Our reforms have been applauded by groups involved in caring for older people. Jim Toohey from the Assisted Living Association—Queensland's peak aged care organisation—welcomed the $12 a day subsidy. He said:
This is an incentive for providers to allocate more places for financially disadvantaged residents.
The Australian Catholic Health Care Association also welcomed the additional subsidy. They said:

With such a massive reform strategy soon to be under way, it is now more comforting knowing that the access for financially disadvantaged people to residential aged care services will be improved with these increased subsidies.

Far from being a problem, as the ALP is trying to make out, this reform helps the disadvantaged and, in addition, has been welcomed by those involved in the area of aged care. After all, our reforms have the overt support of Aged Care Australia, Anglicare, the Assisted Living Association, the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, Community Services Australia, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association—the list goes on. In fact, these reforms have been so well received that one peak organisation described our Minister for Family Services, Minister Moylan, `as the best federal minister for aged care in 20 years'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what your backbench thinks.

—The ALP just obviously could not cut it. So they try to scare people, a normal tactic for those on the other side. They are trying to tell people that they will lose their houses under our reforms—something which is, needless to say, simply and utterly untrue, Senator Conroy. It is typical of Labor though. This whole thing is just Labor scare mongering directed at one of the most important groups of people in our society—people who have invested their lives, skills and hopes in our community, and this is how you repay them. It is shameful for you to be attacking and undermining this most important group of people.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, what did you ever do for these people? You say that our policies have resulted in economic insecurity for older Australians and a decline in job opportunities. Look at your record. You were the ones who pushed their unemployment rates through the roof. Senator Neal and Senator Mackay had the audacity to raise the issue of unemployment amongst older Australians. Let me remind the Senate that, in December 1985, 5.3 per cent of males aged 55 to 59 were out of work. Within nine years, it had leapt to 10.9 per cent—more than double.

Senator Mackay gave us a wide ranging speech of some 18 minutes duration on unemployment. I will not. I believe those numbers speak for themselves. They stand alone. Unemployment amongst mature aged people under the Labor government doubled. You have not said sorry for losing 400,000 jobs during the recession we had to have. How do you think policies that put people out of work affected their ability to save and plan for getting older? How do you think that affected their economic security? You claim we are not looking after older Australians sufficiently and giving them enough security, but you did not provide for any group of Australians.

Under the Labor government, living standards declined precipitously. Australia's ranking on a world per capita basis dropped—plummeted, I might say—from 10th to 22nd position in the 10 years from 1983 to 1993. Indeed, research commissioned from the Economic Planning Advisory Commission found that between 1983 and 1994 real earnings of the lowest 10 per cent of earners fell. The gap between the rich and the poor under Labor increased markedly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—In 10 of the 11 years assessed, the poorest Australians earned less than they did in 1983. Let me point out to the honourable senator who said `rubbish' that in the worst year of 1990 they suffered a nine to 10 per cent decline in real earnings compared to 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are on living standards, let us for a minute reflect on the purchasing power of people's savings under Labor and now under the coalition. Of course, we all know how important inflation is to the whole equation. People who were no longer income earners had their savings eroded by extreme levels of high inflation under Labor. Your record on inflation is a disgrace. Inflation in the December 1985 quarter was 8.2 per cent. A year later, it was 9.8 per cent. In 1990, it was still up at 8.6 per cent.

What effect do you think these policies produced for older Australians, or do you just not care? Under the coalition, inflation is now at its lowest level for years—reminiscent of the good old days of the 1960s. In fact, it is an inflation rate of 0.3 per cent.

The coalition does not just talk about caring for older Australians; it demonstrates its caring in tangible outcomes. It does so with progressive policies designed to protect their needs and interests by creating an economy that preserves their lifetime earnings and makes their every day living expenses cheaper.

Our changes to aged care are taking effect and will continue to do so for years. After four years, this government expects to see its changes bring in $130 million a year to the nursing home sector for use in capital upgrade. That is $5 million more than the amount that members on the other side of the chamber were told was needed in 1985 when they refused to do anything. The coalition is helping. It is making a difference; it is caring.

The opposition does not care, though. You misrepresent at every opportunity. You, along with the media, frequently portray older women in Australia as being frail and inactive, which is simply not the case. Pru Goward, the head of the Office of the Status of Women, is very concerned about this. She said:

BREAK.PARA: The media preys on older women, feeding them fears about their physical frailty and their subsequent vulnerability to danger.

Often today these women are still active and healthy, not frail and doddering. Their life expectancy has increased by eight years since 1960, but you still want to portray them as victims and still do nothing to help them.

The Howard government will develop an aged women's policy in the next 12 months, something Labor never did. As part of that, we are going to look at the very issues that affect many women and contribute to any disadvantage they may experience, including issues like social security and superannuation. The Howard government is also fighting these damaging and negative stereotypes in other ways.

The Conference for Older Australians was established by the Prime Minister in conjunction with the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan. This conference has many roles: to coordinate the government involvement in the International Year of Older Persons in 1999; to devise strategies to promote an image, a positive image, of older people; and to help advise the government on strategies for dealing with an ageing population. It is an initiative that must have escaped your memory because you have failed to mention it today.

The establishment of this conference, which consists of a distinguished group of Australians, including Ita Buttrose and Major General Digger James, displays yet again this government's commitment not only to the consultative process but also to our senior citizens, the people the ALP accuses us of neglecting.

Labor was in government for 13 years yet did nothing to help these groups of older Australians. At the last election the Labor Party could produce only 200 words to demonstrate any interest at all in older Australians. That was the sum total of their election commitment—less than one page. All the ALP seemed capable of giving to older Australians was higher unemployment, increased living costs and greater debt. On the other hand, we are currently legislating to maintain the single rate of pension at no less than 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. We are acting to help older Australians.

Our government will never say, as Captain Wacky did, `This is as good as it gets.' This is the only government for all Australians. This is the government that cares about older Australians and values immensely their contributions to our society. This is the government that will not shirk the tough decisions the way that Labor did. The Howard government is a compassionate but strong government. We are doing the right things by older Australians and Labor scaremongering does nothing for the national good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points I would like to respond to in respect of Senator Synon's contribution. I note in her concluding remarks she said that Labor, in 13 years, did nothing for elderly Australians. I will be illustrating in the course of my remarks that Labor did a great deal. The purpose of the debate today is to focus on the failure of this government to protect the interests of older Australians. I think one of the central points I will make in my speech is what Labor did and what this government has done in respect of the incomes of older Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of debate over the last 10 or 15 years about our ageing population. In 1986, shortly after Labor came to power, there were 1.7 million persons in Australia over the age of 65. The last available statistics for 1996 were that there were 2.2 million persons over the age of 65. By the year 2006 it is forecast to reach 2.6 million. By the year 2026, when I suspect most of us will be long gone, there will be 4.6 million people over the age of 65. By the year 2051 there will be six million people over the age of 65. As a percentage of the population, which I think is the more relevant statistic, in 1986 just over 10 per cent of the population were over the age of 65 and by the year 2051 23 per cent, just over one in four, of the population will be over the age of 65.

Senator Synon made the comment that Labor did nothing for older Australians in its 13 years in government. I recall one of the first things Labor did when it came to power was increase the age pension to 25 per cent of male average ordinary time earnings—25 per cent minimum guaranteed. Labor has maintained that principle and that level of income support for pensioners in this country for retired persons ever since that time. On occasions it exceeded 25 per cent of male average weekly ordinary time earnings. That was very important to persons who were retired in Australia because it meant that there was an automatic movement of their income. We avoided the situation that occurred at budget time normally when sometimes there was an increase a few dollars here or there in the aged pension.

What did this government do when it came to power? One of the first things it did was commission the National Commission of Audit, which recommended a change to that formula for increasing the aged pension. The National Commission of Audit proposed to change the formula which would have meant that future increases would have been smaller than under the Labor formula. The government has not adopted that recommendation from the National Commission of Audit, not as yet anyway. It will be interesting to see what they do in that regard. But it is totally false for Senator Synon to claim that Labor did nothing. I am going to seek to avoid extravagant argument this afternoon, but in Senator Synon's extravagant argument she did not recognise what I think was one of the most important reforms for the elderly in our community in this country.

There is a wide range of other reforms that Labor carried out in power. I do not want to traverse them all. Medicare was another change. It is an enormous benefit to all Australians but particularly to elderly Australians. It took away a lot of the fear and uncertainty of retirement years.

Labor did not just assist Australians who had already retired; it recognised the ageing population and the particular problems this was going to lead to. I referred earlier to the increasing number as a total and as a proportion of the population of aged persons in Australia. Labor recognised that superannuation up to 1983 was fundamentally unfair in its application. Up until that date I think less than 40 per cent of Australian workers had superannuation. It tended to be confined to higher income persons in this country. It generally benefited male workers and the proportion of women who had it was very low.

Labor took some important steps during its 13 years in power to extend superannuation coverage to all Australians. The superannuation guarantee commenced at three per cent, phasing up to nine per cent by the year 2002, and Labor had a commitment to a co‐contribution of three per cent from the government direct and three per cent from employees. The new Liberal government made an identical promise to ensure that the three and three per cent co‐contribution were delivered. They broke that promise in the last budget and they repackaged it, largely in the form of a savings rebate.

I just wanted to highlight a few of the issues in respect of Labor's time in government, but I want to concentrate my remarks this afternoon on changes that took place in respect of social security and their effect on Australians who turn 55 years of age. They are particularly nasty. Certainly, I do not think it is overstating it to refer to them as vicious, the changes that occurred on Saturday for Australians who reach the age of 55. I would like to read a letter from today's Launceston Examiner. I think it really sums up very well the particular feeling of a person who wrote to the newspaper and their concerns at the measure that was introduced on Saturday. It says:
I am one of the 67,000 whose allowance has decreased. It makes me wonder what I have done, for this to happen?

I'm over 55 years old; I've been made redundant (seven years ago); I have searched and searched for a job, without success; I received a small pay‐out; I've not taken any holiday (i.e. going away) and I have lived sparingly to preserve as much as possible for old age.

Now the age for pension has increased to 65. Now everyone over 55 years in this position is penalised again. There are no rebates except a health care card. My health is the worst it has ever been and up go all the health funds along with many other necessities, just when needed most.

I pass the asset test easily but apparently superannuation, which is less than $100,000 is assessed as bringing in a certain rate—whether it does or not, whether it crashes or not, whether costs are half of it or not.

I can't believe after paying hefty taxes for years and struggling to provide security that this is happening. I don't think I deserve it. It is not my fault that I am in this position. I'm dreading ever reaching "old age", I like to be independent. It will be a struggle and everything will happen that I have tried to prevent. I urge others to very, very, wary.

It is signed: `Disillusioned, vulnerable and feeling very aged'. I hope particularly that Senator Newman, from Launceston in Tasmania, reads that letter today because that sums up, I think, the intense disappointment—even betrayal—of the 67,000 Australians. It may be more; we have been given government estimates of 67,000 who have been affected by the measures introduced on Saturday.

What were the measures that came into effect on Saturday? They affected a range of income that a person receives once they have reached the age of 55. They include: having received social security payment for nine months, any superannuation or rollover assets will be counted under the social security means test. Depending on the value of their superannuation assets and what other income and assets they have, their payment may be reduced or cancelled completely.

The second change under the new income maintenance test is that any cashed out annual leave, sick leave, long service leave or maternity leave included in their redundancy package will preclude any payment for the duration of the leave. Thirdly, under the new liquid assets tests, any liquid assets in excess of $5,000 for a couple, or $2,500 for a single person, would preclude any payments for up to 13 weeks. That is a summary of the changes that commenced last Saturday.

What it means, of course, is that a person who has turned 55—and I think everyone here would acknowledge this—is at their most vulnerable in terms of losing their job and of finding alternative employment. If you are made redundant or lose your job at the age of 55, it is not easy to find another job. Unfortu nately, there is an attitude among many employers that a person who has reached the age of 55 may not be suited to employment altogether, and I think that is a very unfortunate attitude that is widely held amongst Australian employers.

There is a range of problems. Many of the workers who have been made redundant have been involved in traditional trade and non‐trade blue collar occupations. In many cases they do not have the degree of understanding of computers, for example, that is required in the modern economy. They find it very difficult to re‐educate or retrain and to adjust to the modern economy. There is a particular problem facing older Australians in this regard.

What is this government's response? As from Saturday, a person who has turned 55 years of age, who may have struggled for much of their working life to put aside moneys for their retirement, in the form of superannuation, finds the goal posts have been shifted. Instead of that superannuation being there for when they want to retire—when they reach their 60s—they are now required to draw down in part or whole on that superannuation asset which they have, in many cases, struggled to accumulate over the last 10, 20 or 30 years in the hope that they could build that nest egg up and have it there for their retirement.

Of course, many people who have lost their jobs at the age of 55 do not want to retire. They are out there actively seeking alternative employment, as difficult as it is to find that alternative employment. But this government has shifted the goalposts. The government has changed the rules, in effect retrospectively, and said to those people who have struggled for many years, `You will now have to draw down on some or all of your superannuation to survive. If you have been made redundant and have cashed out annual leave, sick leave, long-service leave or maternity leave, you should use that up as well.' I have referred to the liquid assets test of $2,500 for a single person.

As I said earlier, these are very nasty and very vicious measures that have been introduced by this government. I have looked through the Liberal Party election manifesto and I certainly cannot see any indication of these measures. The Liberal-National Party government continues to claim that these sorts of changes are fair for elderly Australians. We have had a response to the excuses—and that is all they are—that have been presented for these new measures that took effect on Saturday.

Senator Newman has referred time and time again to millionaires rorting the system. As I have mentioned before, in my home state of Tasmania there are many hundreds of people who have been affected by this new measures. There are very few Tasmanians who are millionaires full stop, let alone there are not many millionaires who have been affected by these new measures at all.

If there were any truth to that claim, then the government could have, as Labor suggested, exempted persons under a certain level of superannuation asset from being affected by this measure. Labor suggested a superannuation cut-off point of $250,000. Let us get the millionaires out. If you want to hit the millionaires, you can design specific measures to tackle the millionaires—such as they are in Tasmania; I do not think there would be more than two or three millionaires in Tasmania. Unfortunately, this measure has affected in my home state—I have not seen the breakdown of figures—I think, at least 1,500 or 2,000 persons.

Another interesting point about this issue is that there will be an ever increasing number of persons affected by this measure because the current group of people largely affected are people who have acquired superannuation over long periods of time. As I mentioned earlier, Labor introduced national superannuation for all Australian workers. It commenced in the late 1980s, depending upon the particular industry in which a worker was employed. So superannuation for all Australians has been established and will grow and accumulate with the introduction of the superannuation guarantee. As workers reach the age of 55 and lose their jobs, there will be many more—tens of thousands—ageing Australians who will be affected by this new measure that commenced last Saturday.

BREAK.PARA: Another point I make about this new measure is that one of the central thrusts of the government has been to encourage and, in some cases by legislation, require people to keep their superannuation until the age of 60. It is proposing to close off, for example, accessing superannuation if you have got less than $500. If you are going overseas, you will not be able to access your superannuation. It is announced that it is going to require preservation of superannuation from age 55 to 60.

But what has the government done with this measure? It has taken a totally contrary approach. It is effectively saying, `When you get to 55 and can't find another job, you have to declare yourself retired to access your superannuation in order to live and survive.' As I have said on many occasions, this is a very nasty and vicious measure.

To rub salt into the wound, many of the people who have complained to Labor about this measure have locked in their superannuation arrangements for some years in advance. The government introduced the new measure, but they have locked their superannuation into a range of retirement vehicles and now they have to unravel those arrangements in order to access their superannuation. That will come at a cost. They will be charged. There will be a fee for unravelling their superannuation arrangements if they wish to access all or part of it in order to survive.

As I said earlier, this is a very vicious and a very nasty measure that affects tens of thousands of elderly Australians. It has certainly meant a reassessment by many people in the Australian work force who are coming up to the age of 55 about what they can do in terms of saving and their superannuation and about what will happened to their redundancy payments if they are made redundant. This is just a money grab by this government—I am sure recommended by Treasury. It is uncaring and, above all, it is unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —The ALP is very keen to marginalise groups of Australians and it is doing a disservice to older Australians by this motion. The opposition's suggestion that this government has failed to protect the interests of older Australians is ludicrous. The concept that Labor has a mortgage on older Australians is wrong. The polls up to the present time have borne this out.

SPEECH.PARA: People over 50 cannot accept that the agenda followed by the Hawke-Keating government was correct. During those years, Labor tended to become an apologist for almost everything that older Australians thought about what it meant to be an Australian. The latest Newspoll, which breaks up the primary voting intention of people over 50, indicates that as late as April‐June—which are the latest figures I have for primary voting intention—the coalition government had a 16‐point margin over Labor; that is, a primary vote of 49 to 33 per cent.

The welfare and wellbeing of older Australians has always been one of the coalition's highest priorities, both in opposition and in office—and well might it be, because we are an ageing population. Labor would have us believe that older Australians had a better deal under them. How is it that the comprehensive review by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) of this country's aged care facilities has found so many substandard operations? Labor had 13 years to fix things up: they did not and could not.

Whether it is access to medical care, social security benefits, the care of returned service men and women, the concerns of self‐funded retirees or the provision of aged care, this government is delivering for older Australians and making changes for the better. We have made practical changes that make sense to older people. Just yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) launched Centrelink, this government's new one‐stop shop which combines the services previously offered by four government departments. At over 400 offices across the country, many in regional areas, it will be easier for older Australians to get advice and easier for them to organise access to the age pension, the pensioner concession and the Commonwealth seniors health card. This group, perhaps more than any other, will appreciate the convenience and efficiency of these new arrangements.

In addition, there is already easier access for older Australians to Medicare claim processing through the introduction of elec tronic lodgment direct from doctors' surgeries and processing of Medicare claims by pharmacies, and this will be expanded. Also, there is a commitment of an additional $10 million over four years for people with dementia and for their carers, $14.7 million has been allocated to further extend funding for the palliative care program in 1997‐98 and there is funding of $36.7 million over four years for a new national `respite for carers' program which will be established around Australia.

We have made changes to benefit older Australians financially. We have introduced a tax rebate which is equal to the value of the pension tax rebate. Under that scheme, lower income retirees of pension age will be able to receive a tax break of up to $1,229 per year for a single person. The unjust legacy to low income, self‐funded retirees was discriminatory.

Labor taxed self‐funded retirees at an income level of $5,400 where other pensioners were able to enjoy a tax‐free income level of $11,185. This was unfair. The coalition reversed the ALP's policy and now Australians who have saved for their own retirement have seen their tax‐free income increase to $11,185 per annum for singles and $19,850 for couples. This is not to say that we are leaving aside those people who do not have some income and therefore qualify as self‐funded retirees. We are interested in all older people, but, in the interests of the way that the government dollar is spent, we must be fair. Under the previous government's arrangements, they tended to pick winners and certainly were not fair in the way that some of their policies were administered.

In the May 1997 budget, the government introduced a new savings rebate which will enable people to claim a 15 per cent rebate on up to $3,000 of savings interest, equivalent to a tax cut of up to $450 a year. The National President of the Association of Independent Retirees, Mr Ray Trestrail, believes many of his group's members will benefit from this move. He was not the only one to applaud the government's efforts to encourage national savings and reduce our debt. Clearly one of the very big important issues that we face is to increase our national savings and reduce our debt.

The coalition has also delivered on a promise that the previous government was not prepared to make. We propose legislation—which has been passed in the House of Representatives—which will make sure that the value of the age pension is maintained at 25 per cent of male total weekly earnings. That is something which is to be applauded and something which all older people on the pension are very pleased about.

As I mentioned before, early in our term this government took a very hard look at the provision of aged care in the community. Generally speaking we found it in a parlous state and took immediate action to improve it. We have extended the existing entry contribution system that applies to hostels to cover nursing homes from 1 October. An accommodation bond will be payable to enter certified nursing homes. The accommodation bond will not affect current residents in nursing homes. For them, nothing will change. Anyone who has assets of less than $22,500 or is in a financially disadvantaged state will not be charged an accommodation bond. To suggest otherwise is scaremongering and inappropriate.

Contrast this with the ALP's response to the needs of our ageing population: they cut funding on capital expenditure while not allowing nursing home operators to charge a bond. We are about providing help where it is needed and also about using the taxpayer's dollar wisely. Community responsibility is important. Australia was substantially built on it and recognises it, and all decisions that we will make will be based on that sense of community.

Nursing homes suffered under Labor. In 1992‐93, $45 million was available for nursing home capital purposes. By 1995‐96, this figure had dropped to $10.7 million, a startling fall of 75 per cent. But the worst part is that this figure only included $2.7 million for upgrading old and substandard services. The rest was for new construction work. The result was that too many nursing homes do not meet acceptable, basic standards on fire safety, on privacy, on space and on facilities. There was, and unfortunately remains, an urgent need for action. We are addressing that need.

Labor has tried to frustrate us at every turn. Rather than admitting their failing, they have put their energy into scaremongering and misinformation campaigns designed to frighten older Australians—and, of course, they are the easiest target of all to frighten.

This government is in touch with the needs of older Australians. Many of them told us that they were in no rush to retire, so we developed a deferred pension bonus plan to benefit them. I commend this decision; it is a great idea. I am sure that the previous government would have liked to have thought of it, and I would have applauded them if they had. The plan operates on the basis that, if you choose to stay at work for at least 25 hours a week, the government will pay you a bonus of 9.4 per cent of the basic age or service pension. It is paid as a tax‐free lump sum when you take the pension later on. If you do your sums on that, it means that if a single person chose to keep working for an extra five years after the normal pension age, they would receive a tax‐free bonus of $21,250, which is a very substantial amount of money.

The coalition government is committed to meeting the needs and aspirations of all older Australians. We are committed to providing proper care and facilities, no matter where older Australians may be living. The assertions put forward by Senator Neal and subsequent speakers really are baseless. In addition, we have provided a generous package targeted at carers and the people they care for, which focuses on their needs, respite care, and financial assistance for carers, and on carers who need assessment, information and advice.

For carers themselves, additional financial assistance came in the carers' package in the recent budget. It includes a $16.60 per fortnight increase in the domiciliary nursing care benefit; the extension of the carer payment to a carer providing constant care of a child under 16 years with profound disabilities; extension of the carer payment to a carer who is required to care for an adult as well as the care of, or supervision of the care of, a child; and the alignment of the arrangements which allow someone to be temporarily out of care for 63 days a year before the payment to the carer is affected.

In addition, we have provided further assistance for care of dementia sufferers. We will provide $10 million over four years to provide for the more accurate diagnosis and assessment of people with dementia. For their carers, more appropriate and timely treatment, care and support services will also be provided.

Changes to the child disability allowance criteria will result in fairer and better targeting of the allowance. And, in a very important area of support and information for carers, more than $8 million over four years has been allocated to provide support and information to carers, including resource material in English and, very importantly, in other languages; information about government services; health information; and support for carer networks and volunteer training. In addition to the national respite for carers program which was announced in the budget, there will be funding of nearly $37 million over four years for the new national respite for carers program, which will soon be established right around the country. There has been an allocation of $54 million over four years to state and territory governments for accommodation support to assist an additional 500 people with severe and profound disabilities and their families.

Older Australians, including those on fixed incomes, will benefit by up to $450 per year due to the tax cut on savings interest or personal superannuation contributions. As I have said, the government is offering a bonus to many Australians who are able and keen to work past 65 years of age. The deferred pension bonus plan will pay a bonus to people of age or service pension age who defer the pension and who continue in gainful employment for at least 25 hours a week. The bonus will be 9.5 per cent of the basic age or service pension entitlement for each year of pension deferral, up to a maximum of five years. In addition, there is much easier access for older Australians to Medicare claims processing through the introduction of elec tronic lodgment direct from doctors' surgeries, and from the processing of Medicare claims through pharmacies.

Another election commitment which we have honoured is the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, which has already been legislated by the parliament and took effect on 1 July last year. This will provide an effective tax cut to provisional taxpayers of some $180 million over the 1996‐97 financial year, and it represents an important reduction in the provisional tax burden. This will be of benefit to many self‐funded retirees.

In the recent budget, the government announced reforms to the social security means testing of income stream products such as superannuation pensions and annuities. These reforms will ensure that people with money invested in income streams that provide an orderly draw down of capital over the expected retirement period, and which allow no further access to that money, will not have that money treated as an asset under the means test. This will be the case even if the money invested is from non‐superannuation savings. These changes aim to ensure that the means testing of income streams is consistent and equitable, and that it offers fair treatment to those retirees who have made provision for their retirement period.

The government is also aware that the cost of private health insurance is a burden for many retirees, and it will be meeting its commitment to provide incentives for private health insurance. The incentives will address the ongoing decline in private health insurance membership by reducing the costs of private health insurance for low‐ and middle‐income families and individuals. The incentives will be available to single people with a taxable income up to $35,000, and to couples and families with dependent children and a combined taxable income of up to $70,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party would not do that.

—They would not. They did not think of it and, as a result, membership of private health insurance funds has plummeted. The size of the incen tives will vary according to whether people are single, couples or families with dependent children. They will also vary according to the level of private health cover people hold. For people with hospital cover only, there will be a rebate of $100 a year for single people, $200 for couples and $350 for families with dependent children. For those with ancillary cover as well, there will be $125 for single people, $250 for couples and $450 for families with dependent children. The incentives were available from 1 July 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

In taking note of the advances to the Minister for Finance, I particularly want to address the advance to the Department of Transport and Regional Development, which goes to the payment of the Bass Strait passenger equalisation scheme, which was introduced on 1 September 1996 for the purpose of reducing the cost for motorists of transporting accompanied vehicles when travelling across Bass Strait.

The scheme was aimed at increasing demand for travel across Bass Strait, with direct benefits to the tourist industry and a potential growth in jobs. The budget allocation for the year 1996‐97 was $7½ million, and it would appear that the scheme is now running over budget. The point that needs to be made with regard to that is that there has not been any real net increase in tourism. What appears to have been happening—maybe this is something that the government needs to check—is that people numbers per vehicle have actually decreased. Therefore, it would seem that this scheme and the quite substantial amount of money being used to fund it is certainly not achieving the desired objective. The scheme may well be being misused by some car selling companies that have one person who drives a vehicle on to the boat and travels across. I understand from reports that this is particularly so with regard to second hand cars where, for instance, cars are being bought in Melbourne at reasonable prices by some Tasmanian dealers and are being brought across to Tasmania more cheaply than they otherwise would do so. The dealers then make an increased profit.

The government took a reasonable approach in trying to bring down the costs of travel across the Bass Strait, which is very important to people of Tasmania. But we want to avoid all these hucksters and remove the possibility of this scheme being pulled apart.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could that be the jeremiad of Tasmania?

—It could end up being the jeremiad of Tasmania, and we could end up seeing the whole scheme being eviscerated. Nevertheless, what is important is that Tasmania was deserving of getting some form of subsidy for travel across the Bass Strait, because that is a major impediment to the state. Before the last federal election, we proposed to pay for a new catamaran to operate on the service. The one benefit that that would have had, and would still have, over the current scheme is that it would have helped the state to replace the existing vessel.

BREAK.PARA: The existing vessel has a substantial amount of debt and it is in decline. When the government chooses a time to replace it, it will probably lose a substantial amount of money. We will still have the subsidy, but what would be more important for the state in the longer term would be to have a different application. Fast ferries—I am not necessarily talking about catamaran‐style ferries—do have the potential to provide a more efficient, faster and cheaper service. That would be a cheaper service for everybody, not just for those bringing across motor vehicles. All this subsidy does is provide a benefit in relation to motor vehicles.

I am going to very carefully watch how this scheme runs. It is already running at about $1.2 million over budget. I want to make sure that Tasmania gets the appropriate benefit from this sort of budgetary expenditure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Multilateral Treaty—Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I note that the document talks about albatrosses and small cetaceans, such as the dusky dolphin and the speckled porpoise, which are in Australian waters.
Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We might eviscerate the people who are actually causing harm to these species. These species are threatened due to long‐line fishing activities, the ingestion of plastics, predation, breeding habitat modification, pollution and disease. Of course the people who are responsible for this—and, in a lot of cases, human beings are—could be described as nothing but hucksters.

SPEECH.PARA: The document goes on to talk about other species, particularly the albatross. Apparently the albatross is a bird that dives for fish. So, of course, the long‐line fishing activities of certain nations are absolute predators to these poor birds.

We are also talking about small whales and many other wild animals of these migratory species. The convention provides a framework for enhancing the conservation status of migratory species through the cooperative efforts of the countries along the migratory paths of those species, which are called the `range states'. There is significant national and international concern about the conservation status of albatrosses and other animals such as the dusky dolphin and the speckled porpoise. Australia is a signatory to this convention, and so it should be. It is quite an admirable thing to be a signatory to.
Under the heading `Consultation', the document states:

With the support of Commonwealth Ministers with a portfolio interest in this treaty action, the Minister for the Environment wrote to his counterparts in the States and Territories seeking their views on the proposed action. A favourable response was received from all jurisdictions.
I am quite happy to know that there was a favourable—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I think this speech is jeremiad. I would just like to point that out to the chamber.
—Senator Heffernan, you know very well that, as amusing as that contribution may be, there is no point of order.

—It is jeremiad, and I suppose that is because the document was put in my hand exactly one minute before I had to make this speech. So I have not thoroughly read the document, but it is a very important document.

BREAK.PARA: These wildlife species of the sea are of great concern to everybody. If we do not protect these species now, then future generations will not have the opportunity to enjoy the fruits of the sea, as we have. So I think these particular animals of the sea should be saved from these hucksters who are out there trying to destroy them. Quite frankly, if I got my hands on them, I would eviscerate them.

TITLE.XREF: HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION (REFORM AND SEPARATION OF FUNCTIONS) BILL 1997

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Knowles, I would like to present the report of the Community Affairs Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Health Insurance Commission (Reform and Separation of Functions) Bill 1997 , together with submissions and transcripts of proceedings.
