PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September 1997, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled Super: restrictions on early access was tabled this week. It again shows the litany of broken promises by this government. They said before the election that nobody's superannuation would be worse off if they came to power. What a pack of hucksters!

SPEECH.PARA: Since they were elected they have come into this parliament and made change after change; people have become more and more worse off, yet they still pretend that the position they have delivered does not mean that people will be worse off. Every single step of the way on superannuation they have made people worse off. Workers in this country are worse off by over $100,000.

This latest report highlights the unfairness and the attempt to eviscerate people's superannuation plans. Australians who go overseas are no longer able to get access to their superannuation. It does not matter if they are coming back, it does not matter that they have to contribute to superannuation in the country that they go to; they cannot get their superannuation from Australia—it has to sit here. Fees have to be paid and the total amount will possibly go backwards because this government is so small‐minded.

There is another situation. When temporary workers from overseas come here it does not matter whether the workers have to contribute to superannuation in their home country; what matters is that they have to contribute to superannuation here—they have to contribute twice. There was a suggestion that we could negotiate with all countries to try to get some equity into the situation, but we would have years and years of bilateral negotiations that would get us nowhere. This government is mean spirited and very vicious in its approach to superannuation.

This report highlights broken promises. The government pretended that it had a black hole that it had to fill; it pretended that it had to deal with an economy that was in trouble, in debt. There has been nothing from the government but a jeremiad of complaints about the state of the economy. The government has flattened the economy. It has pulled $10 billion out of the economy. Is it any wonder that no‐one can get a job and confidence is down?

The other day the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) admitted at last that perhaps the government's fiscal strategy was partly responsible for the flatness in employment growth. She is an absolute huckster—no question about that. She is out there pushing this line that she is like a farmer waiting for the drought to break on jobs. What a farce!

This week we have seen the implementation of another of the government's broken promises on superannuation—the inclusion of superannuation assets in the assets test. What an outrage. Thousands and thousands of Australians have been made redundant in the last few years. What is happening to them? They are not able to get a job, particularly if they are older workers. Now they have to run down their superannuation before they are allowed to get a pension. It is a disgrace—an absolute disgrace. We have seen broken promise after broken promise on superannuation. This report highlights more of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to have the report in front of me, but I think I can speak from memory, having been on the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, and having sat through quite a few days of hearings on the three issues that the report dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: The report dealt with three government initiatives. The first proposal was to restrict access to superannuation under $500 or small amounts. The second proposal was to disallow Australian citizens who move overseas or temporary residents—it is often executives or middle management persons who are permitted to work in Australia—from transferring their money overseas when they leave the country. The third proposal was to introduce something which is more clearly defined, but with much tougher hardship provisions. I do not want to traverse too much of the history of superannuation. I suspect we could be here until midnight if I attempt that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've only got 10 minutes.
—I have only got 10 minutes, as Senator Carr has pointed out. I well remember the days when, unfortunately, there was some degree of mis‐selling of superannuation products.
—You are jeremiad, are you?

—No, I think `huckster' is the word in vogue today. I am not sure whether `hucksterism' is an appropriate word to use in the English language. There was a considerable amount of aggressive selling of superannuation products. It does go on today, to some extent, but it is much more minimal, I am pleased to say—in large part because of the reforms of the Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to traverse the mis‐selling, the over‐selling or the wrongful charging that occurred in respect of some superannuation products in the past. Suffice to say that, when the three measures proposed by the government in the last budget were examined by the Senate select committee, I do not think it was realised by the persons affected by these three measures that the measures could be carried out by regulation. There was no legislation required. The announcements were made and then almost overnight, with very little notice, they were implemented by regulation.

I gave notice today that next Monday I will be moving the disallowance of these regulations. We have only two options with respect to regulations. We either approve them by not disallowing them, or when we disallow them we have to disallow them as a whole; we cannot amend the regulations. Labor members, including my colleagues Senator Chris Evans and Senator Steve Conroy who serve on the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, heard over a period of days extensive and highly critical evidence and damning comments about the three changes that the government has proposed. So we are in a position where we cannot amend the regulations; we have to disallow them as a whole and hope that the government sees commonsense and that the government takes some notice of the recommendations made in the report.

With respect to the small amounts—amounts under $500—in the past, persons who had less than $500 could eviscerate their superannuation accounts. You have to ask yourself why this was allowed. In reality, there is little sense in forcing most people to keep small amounts of $500 or less. The amount of accrued interest, offset by administrative fees and charges over time, really means that small amounts such as $500 or less are not going to make any significant contribution to superannuation retirement savings—either in total or for the individual in this country.

We asked questions about the modelling of the specific increase in national savings as a result of the measure in respect of amounts of less than $500. Whilst the government attempted to assure us that the general and other changes in the budget will lead to an increase in national saving, they are very reluctant to give us the very precise detail. In fact, most of the increases in superannuation national savings that result from the last budget announcements occur because of the critical measure that Labor introduced, which was the superannuation guarantee—currently six per cent, rising to nine per cent by the year 2002. We heard a series of submissions and very long and loud complaints about the proposals that the committee examined.

The second issue relates to transferring money overseas. A number of individuals and companies made representations to us. I think what concerned Labor senators, particularly in respect of Australian citizens, was that a number of people have encountered the following kind of problem. I have had two former police officers from Tasmania contact me. One was planning to move to New Zealand; one was planning to go to the United Kingdom. They had retired from the police force, had received their moneys and were all set to go, taking their superannuation with them. One of them wants to set up a small business; the other wants to remarry in the United Kingdom. Their plans have been totally disrupted by the government's new regulations, which prevent them from taking their money. If these sorts of changes are to be made, you would think that the government would give some sort of reasonable notice period—at least for those people who have put plans to leave the country in place.

The other measure in respect of transferring assets of superannuation out of the country related to temporary residence. We have a visa system of temporary residence. This largely involves skills that are not attainable or are in short supply in Australia. We had an interesting presentation from the American Chamber of Commerce represented by Mr Blunt. Some members would recall that Mr Blunt was a former Leader of the National Party. I do not know whether he is still a card‐carrying member of the National Party, but I have rarely seen a person so comprehen sively criticise such a measure and its effect. I do not think Mr Blunt used the description `jeremiad'; he definitely did not use that word. But we got a very long, incisive, mournful collection of complaints from Mr Blunt—justified complaints. He pointed out that when chief executives come into this country, they have employment contracts that stipulatethat, when they leave the country, they can either take their superannuation or, if they take it, they may have to pay it to their employer.

The point was that the government's new regulations are overriding existing contracts of employment. I suppose if compromise were possible on this measure the compromise should be that it should apply to new contracts of employment. So when a person comes in from overseas, if the government is to apply this measure, it should apply to new contracts of employment.

The government argues that it needs this measure to hold these moneys in Australia, because it wants to negotiate social security arrangements with other countries. There may be some validity to that, although there was precious little evidence given to the committee about this. In fact, contradictory evidence was given by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs—much to the embarrassment of the Department of Social Security, I think—about the alleged grounds for requiring all future superannuation to be kept in the country.

Mr Blunt certainly well and truly bagged Mr Costello and the government. He said it overrode existing contracts; it was the sort of practice that occurred in Third World countries; the members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia were absolutely outraged by this measure; it was affecting investment opportunities; and it was affecting Australia's ability to attract foreign headquarters. I have rarely seen such a comprehensive criticism.
The third measure was the hardship provisions. I am sure that if any of my colleagues are going to speak on that aspect of the report they can well and truly cover the issue. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I would not say I was provoked into speaking on this report, but I was disappointed to hear Senator Conroy, who is a member of that committee, in his youthful exuberance—some would say it is youthful exuberance; he either tends to be youthfully exuberant or an angry young man, and I guess after he has spent some more time in this place, he will probably mature a little—attempt to trivialise some of the matters raised in that report.

SPEECH.PARA: That scenario was brought about by the fact that I think Senator Conroy found a dictionary today for the first time in his life. I happened to be here when he opened it, because I was in the chair, and he found three new words which he thought could be used to help draw attention to himself. One of those words actually borders very close to being unparliamentary, and while I was in the chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one—`eviscerate'?

—One of them borders on being unparliamentary and you know which one I mean. I am not going to use it because I would not like the Acting Deputy President to have to ask me to withdraw. If a senator chooses to trivialise a report like this by trying to inject into the debate what he would consider to be schoolboy humour, I think it takes away from the work that has been done by this committee in bringing down its 26th report.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing I want to refer to is Senator Sherry's remarks about the fact that, from the days of the inception of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, there was a great deal of bipartisanship—and there was—all along the way, because everybody knew there were a lot of major changes that needed to be made to superannuation. Many of those changes were made in a very bipartisan way because people knew changes had to be made. Some of the issues that are now coming before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation are not major issues, as they were in the early days, but they are issues which will try to refine the existing legislation that we have.

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, Senator Sherry's and the Labor Party's view of a bipartisan approach is that, when you are in government and the opposition of the day actually does its best to have a bipartisan approach, you have what is called a bipartisan approach to superannuation. Now that the Labor Party is in opposition, a bipartisan approach to them means when the government agrees with what the opposition wants to do—

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have broken promise after promise.
—When the government agrees with the changes that the opposition wants to make. That is not the situation that existed prior to 1996, when the opposition did all that it could—
—Deliver on your election promise.

—I got on this committee almost as soon as I got into this parliament, Senator Sherry, and I can tell you that the opposition in those days went out of its way to make sure the reports that came down from that Senate committee were as bipartisan as they possibly could be. In the 12 reports I was involved in in that three‐year period, I believe there was only one that was not unanimous—I stand corrected, but I think there was only one—because of the degree of bipartisanship that the then opposition, which was us, was prepared to put into the work of that committee to make sure the reports were for the benefit of the Australian people.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to say that an issue that has been raised a couple of times—and this is not directly related to this report, but it was raised by Senator Conroy in his little contribution to this debate—is the issue of the people who are being forced to access rollover accounts or superannuation assets if they are over 55 and have been out of work for more than nine months. That came into effect on 20 September.

It is unfortunate that, whenever this is raised, people talk about workers' accounts and the amount workers have in these small superannuation funds. Having been involved in the superannuation industry for some seven years prior to coming into this place, I know for a fact that most of the accounts people are now being asked to draw on—particularly any that have been in place for a long time—are self-employed accounts. A lot of people who reach the age of 55 have little or no super, so they are not affected by the changes made by this government and recently announced by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman.

Because of the history of the superannuation changes and the fact it has taken a long time to get more universality in superannuation, many people chose to provide for their retirement in other ways. Many of them chose to provide for their retirement by selling their small business and using the asset to provide them with some retirement income.

I do not see any reason why a person who sells an asset and uses that as their retirement income should be treated differently from someone who has put all their money into a superannuation fund, as such, and is asked to access it. If people have saved for their retirement and they are not in a superannuation fund, once they reach the age of 55, they are required to take those assets into account when working out whether they are entitled to get any government benefit by way of social security. They are required to take those into account.

Yet what the opposition is saying is that, if it happens to be in a superannuation account, you should not have to take it into your assets. So you are differentiating between people who have retirement benefits in a superannuation fund and people who have provided for their retirement income in another way outside of a superannuation fund. In many cases, they are using that asset to provide themselves with a retirement income without any help—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I have a point of order: Senator Ferguson is not actually addressing the committee report at all. It is a totally separate report and a totally separate piece of legislation. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to direct him to the report.
—I have been listening intently to this. Senator Ferguson has been covering the field of superannuation, and I think that is what the report is about.
—The report is about this specific piece of government legislation.
—I cannot uphold your point of order. I call Senator Ferguson.

—I am actually rather sorry I was in the chair when Senator Conroy was making his contribution because I am quite sure I could have taken a few points of order myself. I chose not to because I thought, `If you give Senator Conroy enough rope, he'll hang himself,' which he probably has done and will probably continue to do until he reads a few more words out of that dictionary so he can string a different sentence together.

BREAK.PARA: Can I say that the whole issue of a bipartisan attitude to superannuation is one that I believe the government, the opposition and the Democrats should consider more carefully when dealing with issues which are what I would call, in many cases, to do with the finetuning of the superannuation policy. Much of our superannuation policy was brought in with bipartisan support from the period of the late 1980s through to 1996.

There were some issues which we as a party opposed. We opposed them on principle but, once they were put in place by the previous Labor government, we accepted that, in order to provide some certainty for people in the community, we would not seek to change them—particularly the superannuation guarantee charge, which, as you know, in the early days was not part of coalition policy. But, once it was put in place, our parties decided that, in order to provide some certainty for people who were involved in superannuation contributions, it should be left in place.

The only things that this government has changed, which have been changed only in very recent times, are issues which we do not think are completely fair. The issue that I raised, Senator Conroy—I am not sure you were here when I referred to it—was how we treat people who have reached the age of 55 and who may not be using superannuation to provide their retirement income but may have to rely on assets that have been accumulated in some other way, which was the only way that was available to many people prior to the early 1980s when superannuation became more universal.

I think the previous government did some very good things for superannuation, and I would congratulate them on the work that they did. They should not now try to restrict this government, it having been elected, from making some changes which we think will further benefit and refine the superannuation system. We do not expect you to agree with all the things that we want to do, in the same way that we did not agree with all the things that you wanted to do. But, having done them, we were prepared to let them stay in place for the sake of those people who are now involved in far more universal superannuation coverage, I agree, than was ever available prior to the early 1980s and the mid-1980s when I became involved in the superannuation industry.

So, Senator Conroy and Senator Sherry, if you are looking for bipartisanship, you are the ones who can provide it. Bipartisanship is a two-way thing, not a one-way thing. It would do you good to look back and see the bipartisan approach that was taken to all these matters by the coalition when it was in opposition and perhaps model some of your attitudes towards changes to superannuation on the way you were treated when you were in government until 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Until Senator Ferguson made his comments, I really was not going to speak on this matter. I really cannot let those comments lie.
—You might want to be careful because he might rule you out of order in a minute.

—I look forward to it. In fact, having noted the change of occupant of the chair, I must say that I do find it hard to understand, firstly, his comment that the word used by Senator Conroy—and that word was `huckster', which means, as I understand it, a person who uses aggressive methods of selling—
—Senator O'Brien, I must stop you there. That may be one definition of the word using a dictionary, but I took advice from the clerk and there are other dictionaries which provide a much wider—
—Cut it out.
—I took advice from the clerk. It does have a much wider meaning, one which does adversely reflect on another senator. I think you should be very careful in using it.
—I did not use it in relation to anyone.
—I know you did not, but I am just saying that is why I ruled that way.

—The situation is that I appreciate now your advice in the chair, Mr Acting Deputy President, as distinct from your immediately prior statement in your capacity as a senator. I felt that it was appropriate to draw to the attention of the Senate that it is a question of understanding the meaning of the word. I think that, in the context of the debate, that meaning has been made quite clear. In that respect, I would say that it is quite arguable as to whether those comments are entitled to be made in the way that Senator Conroy made them.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, can I say that I would accept that it is desirable that the committees of the Senate, in reviewing matters, strive as far as is possible within the context of the material before them to have a common view on the outcome of any particular inquiry. Of course, that is not always possible. In debates such as these, which enable members of the Senate to comment upon reports of committees, I think matters are open to overt or alternative views—and, indeed, the evidence, which is in the Hansard, which might reflect upon a position of one party or the other.

It might be that in the past there has not been a great deal of disagreement about the streamlining of the superannuation system. I think that is probably the best way I can describe your description of what occurred in the 12 reports that the committee has made whilst you have been participating and in opposition. Having been involved in negotiations on behalf of employees over many years in relation to their superannuation entitlements, I can recall talking to one major international company who, when asked about superannuation and trying to improve the benefits of employees, said, `That's not a matter that we even want to discuss.'

Things have come a long way since that time. There have been High Court cases about superannuation, and there is no doubt that the work of the committee has been very important in bringing superannuation to the point that it is at now. Others can be very proud of the work that you have done to bring superannuation, which is now available for the overwhelming majority of Australians—and that was something that was not the case in the past—to the point that it is at now.

It is arguable that some of the changes the government is making to the superannuation system in this country will fundamentally alter the system. I would suggest that the proposals which are being put forward about, for example, the question of choice of superannuation funds could lead to a great risk of a fall in the confidence of ordinary employees in the superannuation system. I saw an article in a paper last week which talked about whether employers might find themselves the subject of legal action for their advice on the availability of super schemes were they to offer their employees a choice of fund.

There has been a pursuit of the issue of choice without a real understanding and pursuit of the issue of how people in the community understand superannuation and how they will make an informed choice. It is realistic to say that it is important that, when these matters are considered by the Senate, there is consensus about this issue. It is important because this government needs, whether it considers it has a mandate or not, to consider whether it is going to make changes which will eviscerate the superannuation system in this country and which will undermine its credibility with ordinary people.

The superannuation system which has been created is the envy of a great many countries. We have established—and you, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, have been part of this—a superannuation system which provides a retirement income base for a country with an aging population. I have been to superannuation conferences where representatives of superannuation industries in other countries have frankly said that we have got the Rolls Royce model and that they are a long way behind, and I am talking about countries with their own pension funds.

I do not think it is wrong in this chamber to raise issues on superannuation which are matters of debate between the parties. But I do accept the point that you make that we should try, as far as is possible, to have consensus on the streamlining of the system so that we continue to have a superannuation system which is the envy of the rest of the world. We can say with pride that we have had a part in creating and directing a system to meet the needs of this country in the future.

If this system breaks down we will have people bemoaning the fact that we do not have an adequate retirement incomes policy and the tax system is unable to cater for the ageing population of Australia. That is the issue that we have to grapple with. We should not undermine confidence in the system, because, if we do, we will be emitting a jeremiad for the industry in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 September, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not want to be accused by Senator Heffernan of being jeremiad, but I have in fact spoken before on the government's response to the report of the Economics References Committee on outworkers in the garment industry. The clerks have informed me that is it appropriate for me to make further comment at this stage of the Senate's deliberations. I will take the opportunity to spend some more time addressing the government's response.

BREAK.PARA: I took note of Senator Ferguson's earlier comments about the importance of committee bipartisanship and how productive Senate committees can be when they deal with matters in a bipartisan way. I think it is important to note that, in relation to the Senate Economics References Committee's work and deliberations in this matter, there was, on the whole, apart from a couple of small exceptions, a bipartisan approach to this report. As Senator Ferguson noted, bipartisanship is a two way thing. We certainly hope that he will join with us in trying to get some more out of the government, so to speak, in terms of its response.

The Senate may recall that my original comments in relation to this report could be described somewhat as disappointment. In relation to the committee's recommendations—I cannot recall the exact numbers now—I think about nine of the responses to our recommendations were just simply noted, with one or two not agreed with and one agreed with in part.
Senator Mackay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no, Senator Mackay. The committee's work was certainly bipartisan. When it moved beyond that, unfortunately the government did not adequately respond to the considerable effort that was put in by senators from the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats. I seem to recall that Senator Murray also spoke on the report when it was tabled. He indicated an element of disappointment, probably more on behalf of former Senator Sid Spindler who was involved in a crusade, in a sense, in this area during his term in the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: I should perhaps remind the Senate that the description that this sector of the textile, clothing and footwear industries put to the committee of how work is organised within this committee could be depicted as involving a number of hucksters. I am sure it is parliamentary to use that word in that sense since I am not actually describing another senator or a member in the other chamber. Unfortunately, the government's response to the report did not even acknowledge the level of concern raised by the committee about some of the conduct or practices that exist and certainly did not follow on from that by recognising that particular initiatives needed to be conducted.

When I last spoke on this report it was before the government had responded to the Industry Commission report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries relating to tariffs. At the time I was fearful that their response in relation to this report might bode ill for the sort of response which might come down in that area. I am pleased to say that since that time the government has in fact been convinced a new approach should be applied to the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I am hopeful now that the government might give some further consideration to our recommendations in this report.

I certainly hope the government looks at some of the issues that relate to outworkers in the context that some of the problems relate to adjustment which has occurred in the industry as a consequence of the reduction in tariffs to date; namely, to continue to exist in some sectors of the industry some employers have contracted their work to outworkers who, because of how the industry is organised, are often employed in very poor circumstances. In fact, there is confusion amongst many in the industry about whether workers are actually employees or contractors. That was one of the areas where we thought the government should do more to resolve that problem.

If you look at the nature of the work in this industry you could say that some seem to expect workers in this area to eviscerate themselves to get a dollar. In particular, some migrant women spend very, very long hours working for very, very small amounts of money—often as low as about $2 an hour. Again, they worked very long hours because of tight time frames and it also involved the care of young children. Young children themselves were performing the work as well. So a child labour issue was also dealt with by the committee and recommendations.

With respect to the TCF issues, I think it is important to realise that the government's response on TCF industry tariffs is not the only issue. It was only earlier this week we were dealing with the question of China. The Textile Council, the group of textile manufacturers, made a submission to that inquiry highlighting an example, for instance, where Australia could end up being flooded with cotton products under the current proposals for anti-dumping legislation. The Chinese government continues to control the price of these products by controlling the price of inputs, such as cotton, and sets up commercial type enterprises which simply hem the products, so to speak, and then send them offshore. Obviously the price is going to be significantly less than what our textile manufacturers can compete with here. The textile industry manufacturers were very concerned that they could be competing unfairly if proposed changes to the anti-dumping laws go through.

The final point I can make in relation to this report is that the committee has undertaken to review what transpires in the industry in the 12 months since we last reported. That will occur later this year. In that review we will be able to assess what progress has been made in relation to a voluntary code of practice. Obviously, if very little progress has been able to occur, the committee may want to address what other measures might be necessary of a more or less voluntary nature to get some movement in relation to some of the exploitation that occurs in this industry.

I look forward to that review and hope, to take up your point, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, that we will still be able to address this issue in a bipartisan fashion. I also hope that the government will consider that as a significant issue in its response and perhaps take more note than the several notes which appeared in this last report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same matter, this is not a jeremiad on my part, I can assure you. It is a real protest about the inadequate response that the government has furnished here tonight. There is no doubt that this report does eviscerate the heart and soul of the original report and leave it but an empty shell. The industry is characterised by many a huckster who runs a sweatshop and, under those circumstances, the response that the government has given to this report is very pertinent indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: If one examines the response of the government, whilst it is fairly verbose, it nonetheless fails to address the issues that were raised quite correctly, I believe, by the members of this committee. The fact remains that these people are the most important people in the work force. They are people who are out there being exploited left, right and centre. This report sought to address that particular issue.

It should be noted that the response by the government is very deficient. In many places, whilst it uses the word `noted', it fails in any positive way to address the issues raised in the original report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Consideration of committee reports and government responses has now concluded and I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to comment tonight on the new structure of the Human Rights and Responsibilities Commission. I know that some scorn has been heaped on the fact that the name is not very different. But, of course, the new commission symbolises a shift to the community assuming some broader responsibility for combating discrimination rather than the outdated perception of the commission as a Lone Ranger battling against the odds single‐handedly.

SPEECH.PARA: The new commission consists of a president and three deputy presidents. One deputy president will be assigned responsibility for sex discrimination and equal opportunity, one will be allocated human rights and disability discrimination, and the other will be responsible for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander social justice and race discrimination. The new structure will retain all the best features of the current system while adding a more focused and streamlined approach to the protection and promotion of human rights.

The new structure ensures that the commission serves all Australians without requiring individuals to fit into pigeon holes. It will also assist in removing perceptions that the commission seeks only to protect those in the community for whom a specific commissioner exists. This is surely a valuable measure in encouraging some community ownership over the serious problem and perpetuation of discrimination. In a recent interview, the Attorney‐General said:

If an individual has a right, then the community or people in the community have the responsibility. We ought to have a greater focus on the community side. We ought to be—the Commission to be assisting business, assisting Government and assisting the community.

What is the rationale behind the restructure? Firstly, the motivation behind the new structure is about efficiency. I do not mean saving a buck or two here or there but taking the necessary steps to ensure that the protection and promotion of human rights can be managed quickly and effectively to the benefit of all Australians. It is no secret that the commission in its past had its problems. No‐one, I think, ever pretended it was perfect. Sir Ronald Wilson made no secret of that fact before the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade last year, where he said:

One of the amendments made a year or two ago required the commission to demonstrate a collegialty. It was a shame really and an embarrassment that it was considered necessary to incorporate that in legislation.
There is no doubt that the structure of the commission has caused some problems for consumers. Yesterday's press release by the Law Council of Australia said:
The old Commission—where there were separate Commissioners for each area of human rights—was not administratively ideal.
For example, it was not the best structure when a particular case raised various aspects of human rights and equal opportunity law. Cases like that should not be split up between specialist agencies.

The second rationalisation for the restructure is to review the commission's unprecedented growth, especially in light of the transfer of the hearing of complaints from the commission to the Federal Court as a constitutional requirement after the High Court ruling in the Brandy case found that the commission has no constitutional power to enforce decisions.

Over the last decade the commission's growth had been disproportionate to other areas of government. Over the past nine years funding to the former HREOC had increased from about $4 million to more than $20 million. Over the same period staff increased from 51 to 200, at one stage exceeding 220. Growth, of course, by itself is not a bad thing, but there were some serious concerns as to the use being made of the commission. For example, it has been reported that since the Racial Discrimination Act administered by the commission was passed 20 years ago only 20 cases that had gone to a public hearing had been upheld.

The government recognises that the commission's top heavy structure was probably unnecessary and certainly unstainable, and I am pleased to report that the role of education and prevention will be strengthened. The commission will retain its current powers to investigate and conciliate complaints, but will also have an important role in both education and prevention. No longer hampered by structural problems which have beset the commission in the past, the deputy presidents will be free to play a prominent role in educating business and the community and in setting out guidelines to actually avoid discrimination.

What does this mean for women? It constantly amazes me that commentators and critics alike assert that the Howard government would deliberately or intentionally alienate its largest constituency base—women, who now make up 50.5 per cent of the Australian population. The changes to the commission that I am outlining are good news for women. The enhanced educative function means that for women, in particular, changing the culture of the workplace does not have to wait until a complaint about discrimination is made.

Make no mistake—in 1995‐96 sexual harassment continued to be the largest single ground of complaint, comprising 48 per cent of complaints under the Sex Discrimination Act. While sexual harassment is an ongoing issue for women, and to a lesser extent for men, the commission's 1995-96 annual report suggests that the number of conciliated outcomes, private settlements and withdrawals tends to indicate a better understanding of the legislation by all concerned.

It is encouraging to note that the feedback on the restructure so far is positive. The commission described the restructure as a welcome compromise and stated that `the maintenance of some degree of specialisation is a positive recognition of the needs of people who are particularly vulnerable and disadvantaged'. Mr Brett Walker SC from the Law Council of Australia welcomed the announcement when he said:

BREAK.PARA: The establishment of the new Commission with overall responsibility—but with three deputy presidents each having responsibility for various areas of human rights, rather than one mutually exclusive area—is a sensible reform, and one which the Law Council has favoured for some time.

But, as expected, the opposition continue to try to rain on the government's parade without much success. The claim by the shadow Attorney‐General and shadow Minister for Justice, Senator Bolkus, that up to 43 per cent has been cut from the commission's budget is clearly unsustainable. The reduction in the commission's budget amounts in real terms to about 27 per cent—not the 40 per cent or more some people have claimed.

I am aware that the opposition has been running a scare campaign that has needlessly caused anxiety amongst specific community groups. Certainly, it got a lot of women anxious. I have had a lot of correspondence. I say to the Physical Disability Council of Australia, which has recently written to me about its concerns, that the government has no intention of withdrawing its commitment to facilitating the social and workplace participation of people with disabilities.

As the Prime Minister's appointee, I am a director on the Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment. In that capacity I recognise, as does the government, the vital role that the commission has played in encouraging business to develop action plans under the Disability Discrimination Act to eliminate discrimination in the workplace. I look forward to greater gains being made in the future.

The commission is a watchdog worth saving. The reforms under way will strengthen the role of the commission as a strong and independent champion of human rights in Australia and as a model for our neighbours in the region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight about `Travelgate'. We have a situation now where the federal opposition is on a hat trick—Mr Sharp gone, Mr Jull gone and Mr McGauran about to go. We have witnessed extraordinary events in the Australian parliament today. We have a government in total and complete disarray. Now, on top of all that has happened, we know that one of the Prime Minister's most senior advisers was informed of Mr Sharp's dodgy travel claims, and his underhand and covered‐up repayment back in May.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing less than a full, open, honest, transparent and legal inquiry will be satisfactory now for the issues that have been raised in parliament over the past four days to be addressed. The inquiry that Mr Howard has established—the investigation by the Auditor-General—obviously, is not satisfactory. Its terms of reference are too limited. It must be a full legal inquiry. The terms of reference that Mr Howard has devised need to be extended to Mr McGauran. Obviously, the terms of reference have to be expanded to include the period from 1 January 1992 to 24 September 1997 to be consistent with the period covered by the travel details tabled by Mr Jull on 29 May this year.

There must be full access to Mr McGauran's and Mr Sharp's Comcar records, charter aircraft records, DAS fuel card records, original travel claim forms and much other material. There also needs to be a correlation of all charter flights undertaken by Mr Sharp and Mr McGauran and their travel allowance claims. Only a full legal inquiry with adequate terms of reference can get to the bottom of the issues that have now been raised.

Tonight we have the extraordinary situation where the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has indicated that two staff members in his own office were informed about this matter. What was the motive of Mr Jull's senior adviser, Mr John Sutherland, in revealing today that he had briefed the Prime Minister's senior adviser and the Prime Minister's closest confidant, Mr Grahame Morris, and the Prime Minister's office manager, Ms Fiona McKenna, on the Sharp affair in May this year? That needs to be established. When was the Prime Minister given Mr Sutherland's statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before question time.

—We know it was before question time because, just before the House of Representatives adjourned this evening, Mr Howard informed the House of Representatives that that was the case. At that time, as late as possible before the House of Representatives rose, Mr Howard, Honest John, owned up.
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: quite clearly, under standing order 193 Senator Faulkner is imputing improper motives to a member of the House of Representatives.

—I withdraw. Why didn't the Prime Minister inform the parliament of this critical information before question time? Why did he wait until the last possible opportunity before the parliament adjourned for three days?

SPEECH.PARA: You have to ask: how can we believe that Grahame Morris and Fiona McKenna did not pass information of such enormous sensitivity on to the Prime Minister? Are they also claiming amnesia? The Prime Minister tells us that he was not informed and he tells us, I understand, that both Mr Morris and Ms McKenna confirm that this is the case. There really is a recurrence of the sort of amnesia we saw in the Prime Minister's office over the Bob Woods affair. We are dealing with a particularly contagious form of amnesia that appears to have completely spread through the Prime Minister's office.

How can we really believe, at the meetings which the Prime Minister has admitted to having with Mr Jull and Mr Sutherland over the Sharp affair, that neither Mr Sutherland nor Mr Jull referred to the May briefing of Grahame Morris and Fiona McKenna? We know that Grahame Morris was present at these meetings. We have read that in the newspaper. Why did he not mention that he had been made aware of this affair back in May?I suppose it is typical of the track record of Mr Morris.

We know that Mr Morris is very close to the Prime Minister; we know he is his closest political adviser and closest confidante in this place. This is the same Mr Morris who ran the sleaziest, most vicious advertising campaign ever seen in Australian politics in the Northern Territory. This is the same Mr Morris who put the fix on the DDB Needham, Burson‐Marsteller guns buy‐back campaign, along with a couple of members of the parliamentary Liberal Party, to make sure that Liberal mates received $2 million for their advertising contract.

This is the same Mr Grahame Morris who was responsible for trying to stitch up one of Australia's most senior political journalists, Kerry O'Brien, in the Senate estimates committee when even two Liberal senators, Senator Coonan and Senator Eggleston, would not swallow the line of questioning that had been passed to them by Mr Morris. We read reports in Wednesday's newspapers that Mr Morris participated in the deliberations where decisions were made to sack Ministers Sharp and Jull. `Locked in a meeting with them,' it said. It is inconceivable that he had not told the Prime Minister that he knew already. This is what we are being asked to believe.

It is inconceivable that this so‐called professional, political operator, the mastermind of so many political campaigns for the Liberal Party, did not front up and tell his boss. These were meetings about the sacking of Mr Jull and Mr Sharp—that is what they were for—with, amongst others, the Liberal Party's most senior political adviser, the Liberal Party's most senior machine figure in this country. When we found out, after the cover‐up was exposed, Mr Howard sacked, eventually, his two ministers—after Laurie Oakes exposed what was happening. Mr Sharp was sacked; Mr Jull was sacked. Why has Mr Morris not been sacked? That is the question, Madam Deputy President.

We have here a situation where this government is in total disarray. This is a government out of control. This is a government now paying the price for its lack of understanding of and respect for due process and transparency which was most obvious and started right here when Senator Colston's vote was bought for the deputy presidency of the Senate.

The Prime Minister himself has to take responsibility for this state of affairs. He has now revealed that his most senior advisers are implicated at the very heart of this affair. At the very heart of the matter, the cover‐up, the fix has gone in in the Prime Minister's office. I said previously in this parliament that Mr John Howard was the weakest Australian Prime Minister since Sir William McMahon, but I defamed Sir William McMahon. He was probably the worst, he was probably the weakest, but I am sure that in the minds of the Australian people there is no doubt that Mr John Howard is the most disappointing Prime Minister this country has ever had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —You can always tell when Senator Faulkner has not really got his heart in something because he uses the very quiet voice, not the ranting, raving voice that we hear in question time when he thinks he really has a powerful point to prove. We see tonight the very quiet Senator Faulkner, the moderate man, the man who thinks he is being very reasonable, trying to put a point over. The real Senator Faulkner ought to come forward with his usual ranting and raving and then we might think that he has actually got his heart in what he is talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen Senator Faulkner's quiet little effort. Let us compare this government's record; when you talk about the record of the Hawke and Keating governments, when you talk about propriety and when you talk about the propriety of the actions of their ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six, and counting.
—How many are left?
—Order!
—You talk about standards, Senator Faulkner. You have your little team in here behind you. Wheel in all the team so that you can have a bit of support because it is the one chance that you will get.
—Order! Senator Ferguson, would you please address the chair.
—Madam Deputy President, we all know when Senator Faulkner comes in to make one of his quiet little speeches, that he brings the team in behind him because he needs—
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President.
—Order! Can I hear the point of order, those on my left.

—That is the point of my point of order, Madam Deputy President. You have asked Senator Ferguson to direct his comments through the chair, which is correct. The reason he is not doing that is that the people on the Labor side are being disorderly. I ask you to call them to order.
—There is no point of order. If interjections are disorderly, I will ask that they cease, and Senator Ferguson will address the chair.

—This Prime Minister has acted on any perceived impropriety more quickly than any previous Prime Minister that this country has ever had. You need only to look back at your own record in acting on matters of impropriety. We do not have to go back very far, because a lot of you will still remember 1995 and the so‐called Carmen Lawrence and Penny Easton affair. How quickly did your previous Prime Minister act in that situation? The Marks royal commission found that Carmen Lawrence had lied about her tabling of the Easton petition in the Western Australian state parliament. She refused to step down. Where were your standards of propriety? Why didn't you—
—Senator, how did you phrase the comment you made about Dr Lawrence?

—I spoke about the Marks royal commission finding that Carmen Lawrence had lied about her knowledge of the tabling of the Easton petition. That was the finding of the Marks royal commission. The previous government took no action whatsoever on Carmen Lawrence, and were prepared to let their own standards be quite evident to the Australian public. They had no standards of propriety at all. Their propriety extended to agreeing to cover the costs of her appearance before a royal commission, but the Senate voted against funding her appeal against its establishment. An amount of $560,000 of debt remains to be paid, with the Commonwealth only agreeing to meet $50,000 of it, on the grounds that the Carmen Lawrence defence fund should be used to cover the balance due.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are the sorts of standards of propriety that we find on the part of those people opposite who would choose to criticise the current government, and the standards of propriety that this government demands of its members.I can tell you that no Prime Minister has ever acted more quickly on any perceived standards of impropriety than this Prime Minister has on the issue of the resignations of ministers Sharp and Jull.

There are also other standards of impropriety in the opposition. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) and former Prime Minister Keating attacked Mr Justice Marks and the counsel assisting, Ms Ann Vanstone, over their involvement in the royal commission. Mr Keating called it a `kangaroo court with a crook commission'. Mr Evans called the commission a `witch hunt', and then Mr Evans attacked Ms Vanstone, the sister‐in‐law of Senator Vanstone, as `family members who prey together'. Those are the sorts of standards of propriety which you had during your time in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a kangaroo court.

—Senator Cook still insists it was a kangaroo court. That is the sort of thing we would expect from the opposition because they had no standards of propriety whatsoever when they were in government. Yet what did we have in the situation on Tuesday when Minister John Sharp resigned his position? He had voluntarily repaid amounts, because the situation could bring some embarrassment to the government. Yet not once, on any occasion, did we see the sorts of standards which are expected of this government by those opposite ever applying to themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: They never tabled in the parliament their travel allowance details. It was not until this government came into being and got travelling allowances actually tabled in parliament that we could see exactly the extent to which they had used travel allowances for their own benefit.

BREAK.PARA: I would not want to quote some of the high amounts for ministerial travel within Australia—except ones that have been quoted before. Senator Sherry's $41,000 as a parliamentary secretary, of course, was a well‐known average. But there was no public scrutiny of that by the parliament because, in those days, they were not put down. So you see, Madam Deputy President, that the standards of propriety which are required by this government are far in excess of any standards of propriety that were ever accepted or demanded by the previous government of its ministers or, indeed, its members.

We do remember, if we would like to go that far back, the initial discrepancies in Senator Colston's allowances, but no mention of that was made at all by the previous government. There was no mention at all of Senator Colston, when he was a Labor senator, repaying money to DAS for amounts which had been over‐claimed. Yet because of the publishing of travel allowance details, and because they are freely available for everybody to scrutinise, a minister goes back of his own free will to check and make sure that his claims were in order, and then voluntarily repays that amount, which he said may have been an over‐claim.

Processes have been put in place for an investigation by the Auditor‐General to see what actually took place. When the Auditor‐General has had the opportunity to go through the whole situation that has occurred with regard to the resignation of these two ministers, and makes his report, only then will you be able to pass judgment as to what exactly took place.

It is all very well to come in here and talk about ministers who have resigned this week—ministers who, because of a situation which has developed through the publication of these travelling allowances, have decided that they would resign because those are the standards of propriety that are required by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The Prime Minister himself has demanded those standards, and at all times the Prime Minister has been able to achieve those standards by acting very quickly whenever there was any public perception regarding these matters.

We can even go to Laurie Oakes, the person who originally brought this to the public in his article; you people would have known nothing about it if Laurie Oakes had not done his work as a journalist. In his article, Mr Oakes said:

Sharp himself says that, when the T/A claim records were sent to his office for checking in May, he told a staffer to go through them carefully and delete any claims for any overnight stays about which there was any doubt at all. As he explains it: "I said, `I don't want an argument about any of this. It's not worth it. Wherever there could be an argument about where I was, if we can't substantiate it with an airline ticket or Comcar records or something like that, just strike it off.'"

So here is a minister who voluntarily says to his staff, `Go through my records and make sure that any claims that have been made are totally in order and, where there are any doubts, strike it off.' That is the difference between the standards that are applied by this government and the standards that were applied by those opposite when they were in government. When there was any doubt, their ministers hung on for dear life, hoping that they would never be found out. So we had the situation with the Lawrence affair where they hung on and hung on, to your detriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I want everyone in the Senate to try to recall where they were on 26 December last year, 1996. I will declare my interests: I was at the cricket for the first day of the Melbourne test. Mr Peter McGauran was staying at his family home in Melbourne and claimed travel allowance for Boxing Day—$320. Where was he? Was he at the cricket? Did he go to the sales? What public duty did he perform that day to claim travel allowance on Boxing Day, one day after Christmas? One wonders. This is the same Mr McGauran whom the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) tabled a statement from in the House of Representatives yesterday. Mr McGauran made the following claim, which I will share with the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: Each and every claim is accurate and verifiable and paid correctly in accordance with the guidelines. My records are complete in this regard. I did not wrongly claim, I was not wrongly paid and I exercised my own judgment.

Thirty hours ago he said that. Just an hour ago he came into the House of Representatives, having been challenged three times only in the House of Representatives this afternoon to justify travel allowance. He was able to proudly boast that our first query that he had claimed travel allowance and was in Melbourne on the said night was wrong. But the problem was, the other records show that he had a charter flight on 15 March, and the total cost was $1,042. Yet he was in Melbourne. So who was on the charter flight? Three state National Party MPs. He had to cancel at the last moment, so the plane took them off.

Guess what? The bill came in. The Commonwealth paid. In case anyone does not know, it does not get paid automatically. That bill is always sent to a minister and the minister must certify they have met all the conditions. I have to tell you, one of the conditions is that you have got to be on board the plane. Still, the McGauran empire tonight is $1,042 worse off.

Unfortunately, with respect to the other two questions he was asked, he did take the next two flights, but he has had to come into the House of Representatives tonight and say, `I'm sorry, I was not in Melbourne that night and I was not in Canberra that night, and the taxpayers can have another $465 back.' This is a very numerate person, as we know. Guess what, even when he paid all the money back previously, he paid $100 too much for the nights that he wiped out. So he can't even add up.

When did all this start? If you go back through the historical records relating to Mr McGauran, he was a shadow minister then a minister. We find that, for the financial year 1993‐94, Mr McGauran claimed 138 nights in all—not exceptional—but he claimed 41 nights in Melbourne at a cost of $7,790. This becomes a bit like cocaine addiction, as you will find. By 1994‐95, he claimed 140 nights, but look at the Melbourne nights. He is up to 68 nights in Melbourne as a shadow minister, staying at the family owned residence, and charging the taxpayers $12,920. But, you have guessed it, next year, he got a bit greedier. He claimed only 114 nights overall. That was modest. But, guess what? Seventy‐five of those nights were spent in Melbourne, at $320 a night, staying at the family owned residence, costing the taxpayer $14,250.

On 11 March he was sworn in as a minister, and then he really got his hand in the honey jar. From March 1996 to March 1997, he claimed 213 nights travel allowance. I can just think of one of my ex‐colleagues rolling over in his bed at the moment in absolute envy at this. He managed to claim 108 nights in Melbourne, at the higher ministerial rate, for a total of $34,560. That is for living at home at his residence in East Melbourne. What do his colleagues think of this? What does Senator Alston, who does a more important job than he does, think of a colleague who, if you take tax into account, is getting an increase in income of $70,000 a year over and above Senator Alston? What we have over a four‐year pattern is 292 nights claimed in Melbourne at a cost of $69,520, tax free, to Mr McGauran.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the McGauran pastoral company.

—Or wherever else. That is simply unbelievable. If we were having a travel allowance Olympics—we have got a lot of competitors in it at the moment—certainly he would not have won the decathlon. One of my ex‐colleagues would have won that. But Mr McGauran would have won the marathon for the consistent stamina of claiming $69,000. And he would have broken the two‐hour barrier while he was at it.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as that, if you look at the period from March 1996 to March 1997, you find that he claimed 20 Saturday and Sunday nights. Incidentally, seven of them were when his favourite football side was playing home games. He claimed $6,400 for Saturday and Sunday nights at home, watching Hamish Macbeth, et cetera.
How do you get on to this? Why did I not think of this as minister? Go and look at my travel allowance claims. I will do a Gary Hart. The most was $27,000 a year, I think, in the Gulf War year.

BREAK.PARA: This is just gargantuan. Have a look at that March to March figure and see how it is broken down. The very hardworking Mr McGauran manages to claim 108 nights in Melbourne, 83 nights in Canberra, 21 nights elsewhere around Australia and 22 nights overseas. I tell you what: that farm in rural Gippsland does not see him too often.

However, when all of this was published—and he took all this money because he thought it would never be published—what does he do? He says in his statement that he asked his member of staff to go through randomly and knock out travel allowance claims. There is no randomness about it. He knocks out from 24, 25 and 26 March. He then knocks out about 19, 20 or 25 days in April 1997, another 14 or so days out of May and three spouse $10 ones. So there is nothing random. He really said, `Knock out every date that I have claimed from 24 March right through to 25 May.' I think 25 May was just about the time these claims were published in the parliament. Then he does not claim for June at all.

Were any of these adjustments recorded by Mr Jull and put in the figures like they were for other ex-ministers? No, they were not. Nothing was said. It is another cover‐up. The figure is $9,200, and I have to say that he is entitled to $100 back because he could not add up. Now he has gone for another $465 travel allowance, and then he is going to go for the $1,000.

The fact is, and he may not be aware, that we have all the lists of his charter from March 1996 through to December 1996. Mr McGauran's charter—this is not VIP; this is not Comcar; this is not air fare—comes to $39,179. There is the list. Look at the number of trips he did. This entitlement is for ministerial stuff, but some of the trips are only a 10-minute flight around his electorate. He uses the same firm every time. If he wants a plane from Canberra to home, he gets it to come up from Bairnsdale, then he takes it back home. All the charges are there.

What he is going to have to do now is reconcile all of his travel allowance claims with the list of all the trips that we have. We have speared him three times, and we have got him three times. If we get in nine questions at question time in the Reps next week, we have two days worth of questions on this.

Who is out defending him? Is the chief political adviser to the Prime Minister now out defending Mr McGauran? No, he is not. He is out sleazing around the galleries saying, `Hold on, Mr Sutherland is not telling the truth. I don't ever recall him briefing me. I don't care what the Prime Minister said in the parliament.' He is now putting the spin on that Mr Sutherland is basically lying. He has not told the truth and never briefed him back in May. So McGauran has been cut loose by the chief political adviser. He is out trying to save himself.

The point should be made that Mr Jull and Mr Sharp were sacked for not telling the Prime Minister. Mr Morris is not sacked for not telling the Prime Minister. You have to ask yourself why, or what Mr Morris knows about the Prime Minister that gives him immunity from the very sacking he deserves. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do departmental information technology (IT) contracts contain clauses relating to privacy.
(2) What are those clauses.
(3) Are these clauses included in all IT contracts; if not, why not.
(4) Are there any other clauses that relate to privacy that are included in any departmental IT contracts; if so, what are they.
(5) (a) Who decides which privacy clauses go into an IT contract; and (b) from whom do they get advice.
(6) What policy or guidelines does the department follow in preparing its IT contracts.
(7) Are there or have there ever been any deviations from these guidelines in the past 7 years.
(8) Is any guidance or training provided to contractors about the privacy obligations set out in the IT contracts.
(9) Does the department allow subcontracting or include subcontracting provisions in any of its IT contracts.
(10) Do the terms relating to privacy in the principal contract bind the subcontractor.
(11) Is any guidance or training provided to subcontractors about the privacy obligations set out in the IT contracts.

(12) Are any contractors and subcontractors of IT located on departmental premises or do any have access to departmental databases which contain personal information; if so, what measures are taken to ensure those persons do not access personal information beyond the scope of their contract or subcontract.
(13) Have contractors and subcontractors breached information privacy principles in the past 7 years; if so, when and how.
(14) Does the department have electronic mail; if so, what policy or guidelines apply to ensure personal information is not dealt with contrary to the information privacy principles.
(15) Is there any information that the department would never outsource.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department uses two types of IT contracts. One type of contract covers the engagement of contractors and the other type covers the purchase and maintenance of hardware and software.

IT contractors are selected from the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) common‐use contract, PE68. PE68 is a panel of contractors assessed by DAS against extensive criteria, as qualified to deliver IT services to the Commonwealth. In gaining admission to the PE68 panel, IT contractors agree to the protection of personal information provisions in Clause 55. Also, representatives of IT contractors must sign the Deed of Confidentiality and the Deed of Undertaking required by PE68, before commencing work in the Department.

Hardware, software and related maintenance purchases are made under the relevant DAS common‐use contracts which include the common confidentiality clause from the Government Information Technology Conditions (GITC). Where vendors' representatives have access to Departmental information, they are required to sign the Deeds of Confidentiality and Undertaking.
(2) The clauses and deeds referred to in the answer to Question 1 are as follows:
. PE68, Clause 55—Attachment A;
. PE68, Attachment 2, Deed of Confidentiality—Attachment B;
. PE68, Attachment 3, Deed of Undertaking—Attachment C; and
. GITC, Clause 19—Attachment D.

(3) Some minor purchases of software and hardware are made under a short‐form contract drafted by the Attorney‐General's Department. While this contract does not contain privacy or confidentiality provisions, the vendor is simply supplying a product and has no access to the Department's IT facilities.

(5) (a) The privacy and confidentiality clauses listed above are mandated in the DAS common‐use contracts. DAS advises that the clauses have been approved by the Attorney‐General's Department. The Deeds of Confidentiality and Undertaking are also approved by the Attorney‐General's Department.
(b) IT purchasing staff seek advice from the Department's Legal and Review Division, where appropriate.

(6) The Department's IT purchasing procedures follow the Commonwealth Government Procurement Guidelines which are promulgated by DAS. These are supplemented by the Secretary's Financial Management Instructions (SMFIs) which mandate the use of the DAS common‐use contracts.

(7) Prior to the release of PE68 in June 1996, all IT contractors were engaged under a short‐form consultancy contract provided by the Attorney‐General's Department. The contract contains the disclosure and security clauses at Attachment E.

(8) The Department does not provide formal training to its contractors in the application of the contracts to which they are parties. The privacy obligations are, however, spelt out clearly in the contracts.
(9) Yes, under clearly specified conditions.

(10) Where the contractor has arranged for the subcontractor and employees to sign the Deeds of Confidentiality and Undertaking, then the subcontractor and his/her employees will be bound by the contract.

In any event persons seeking access to DEETYA systems are required to make a formal request for that access, and must acknowledge that they are aware of the Crimes Act 1914 offence provisions for the misuse of data and of the Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) contained in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988.
(11) See answer to Question 8 above.

(12) There are contractors located on the Department's premises with access to personal information. Contractors requiring access to any of the Department's systems are allocated user IDs and security access for each of the systems they need to access. Security access is strictly controlled by the contractor's project officer and Branch manager.
(13) The Department is not aware of privacy breaches by contractors or sub‐contractors.

(14) The Department has electronic mail. The policy guidelines covering the use of electronic mail specify that all users must comply with the obligations under the Privacy Act and the Information Privacy Principles—see Attachment F.
(15) Only that information held on the Department's computer systems, and to which access is tightly controlled through those systems, has been included in the scope of outsourcing.
Attachment A
PE68
C55. Protection of Personal Information
C55.1 The Contractor agrees with respect to all services performed under the Contract:

PARA.TAB: (a) to use Personal Information held in connection with the Agreement only for the purposes of fulfilling its obligations under the Contract;

(b) not to disclose Personal Information without the written authority of the Customer, except for the purpose of fulfilling its obligations under the Contract. The Contractor shall immediately notify the Customer where it becomes aware that a disclosure of Personal Information may be required by law;
(c) not to transfer Personal Information outside Australia, or allow parties outside Australia to have access to it, without the approval of the Customer;

(d) to ensure that an employee of the Contractor or of any sub‐contractor requiring access to any Personal Information makes an undertaking in writing in accordance with Attachment 3 not to access, use, disclose or retain Personal Information except in performing their duties of employment and is informed that failure to comply with this undertaking may be a criminal offence and may also lead to the Contractor to take disciplinary action against the employee;
(e) to immediately notify the Customer where the Contractor becomes aware of a breach of this Clause C55.1 (a) to (e) by itself or any sub‐contractor;

(f) to co‐operate with any reasonable requests or directions of the Customer's Representative arising directly from, or in connection with the exercise of the Privacy Commissioner under the Privacy Act 1988 or otherwise including, but not limited to, the issuing of any guidelines concerning the handling of Personal Information; and

(g) to indemnify the Commonwealth in respect of any loss, liability or expense incurred arising out of or in connection with a breach of the obligations of the Contractor under this Clause C55 or for a breach of an obligation of confidence whether arising under the Privacy Act or otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: C55.2 For the purposes of Clause C55.1(g) `liability' includes any liability assumed by the Customer on behalf of the Commonwealth to pay a person a reasonable amount as compensation for loss or damage suffered by that person as a result of any breach of this Clause C55 by the Contractor for which the Commonwealth would have been liable under the Privacy Act 1988 if such breach had been that of the Customer.Attachment A/2

C55.3 A complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual shall be handled by the Customer in accordance with the following procedures as varied in accordance with the Annex Part B Section 7:

PARA.TAB: (a) where the Customer receives a complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual by the Contractor, it shall immediately notify the Contractor of only those details of the complaint necessary to minimise any breach or prevent further breach of this Clause C55;

(b) where the Contractor receives a complaint alleging an interference with the privacy of an individual by the Contractor, it shall immediately notify the Customer of the nature of the complaint but shall only release to the Customer Personal Information concerning the complainant with that person's consent;

(c) after the Customer has given or been given notice in accordance with Clause C55.3 (a) or (b), it shall keep the Contractor informed of all progress with the complaint as it relates to the actions of the Contractor in connection with the allegation of an interference with the privacy of an individual; and

(d) the Customer shall give the Contractor 14 days written notice of an intention to assume a liability, loss or expense in accordance with this Clause C55 including in that notice an explanation of how that liability or expense was assessed and the Contractor's proposed share of that liability.

ANSWER.PARA: C55.4 This Clause C55 shall continue to have effect after the termination or expiration of the Contract.
