ANSWER.PARA: DEED OF CONFIDENTIALITY
(Clause C54.3)
BY THIS DEED DATED THE [DATE] 1997
BETWEEN The Department Employment Education, Training & Youth Affairs ("the Customer")
AND [NAME] ("the Confidant")
PURPOSE:

A. In the course of the Confidant performing certain Services for the Customer (whether directly or indirectly), the Confidant may become aware of information belonging to or in the possession of the Customer that is confidential.
B. Improper use or disclosure of that information would severely damage the Customer's ability to perform its governmental/statutory functions.

C. The Customer requires, and the Confidant agrees, that it is necessary to take all reasonable steps (including the execution of this Deed) to ensure that the Customer's Confidential Information is kept confidential and that the Confidant performs those services faithfully and without any conflicting interest.
AGREED COVENANTS:
1. RECITALS

PARA.TAB: The Parties acknowledge the truth and accuracy of the Recitals in every particular.

ANSWER.PARA: 2. INTERPRETATION

PARA.TAB: 2.1 Definitions
In the interpretation of this Deed unless the contrary intention appears or the context otherwise requires or admits the following expressions shall have the following meanings:
"Confidential Information" means information that:
(a) is by its nature confidential;
(b)is designated by the Customer as confidential; or
(c) the Confidant knows or ought to know is confidential; and includes:‐
(d) information comprised in or relating to any Intellectual Property Rights of the Customer;

(e) information relating to the financial position of the Customer and in particular includes information relating to the assets or liabilities of the Customer and any other matter that does or may affect the financial position or reputation of the Customer;
(f) information relating to the internal management and structure of the Customer, or the personnel, policies and strategies of the Customer;

(g) information of the Customer to which the Confidant has access other than information referred to paragraphs (d), (e) and (f) that has any actual or potential commercial value to the Customer or to the person or corporation which supplied that information;

(h) in the case of the Customer, relating to the policies, strategies, practices and procedures of the Government of [Commonwealth/ State/Territory] and any information in the Confidant's possession relating to the [Commonwealth/State/Territory] Public Services; and
(i) information in the Confidant's possession relating to the Customer's clients or suppliers, and like information;

"Intellectual Property Rights" includes copyright, trade mark, design, patent, semiconductor or circuit board layout rights, trade, business or company names, confidential or other proprietary rights, or any rights to registration of such rights, whether created before or after the date of this Deed and whether created in Australia or elsewhere;
"notice" means notice in writing given in accordance with this Deed; and
"writing" means any mode of representing or reproducing words, figures, drawings or symbols in a visible form delivered, posted or transmitted electronically.

ANSWER.PARA: 2.2 General

PARA.TAB: Unless the contrary intention appears:
(a) monetary references are references to Australia currency;
(b) the clause and subclause headings are for convenient reference only and have no effect in limiting or extending the language of the provisions to which they refer;
(c) a cross reference to a clause number is a reference to all its subclauses;
(d) words in the singular number include the plural and vice versa;
(e) words importing a gender include any other gender;

ANSWER.PARA: 6. POWERS OF THE CUSTOMER
Production of Documents

Legal Proceedings

8. NO EXCLUSION OF LAW OR EQUITY

PARA.TAB: This Deed must not be construed to exclude the operation of any principle of law or equity intended to protect and preserve the confidentiality of the Confidential Information.

Cumulative

Other Instruments

11. VARIATIONS AND AMENDMENTS

PARA.TAB: No term or provision of this Deed may be amended or varied unless such amendment or variation is reduced to writing and signed by the Parties hereto in the same manner as this instrument.

ANSWER.PARA: 12. APPLICABLE LAW

PARA.TAB: This Deed shall be governed and construed in all respects in accordance with the law of the Australian Capital Territory and the Parties hereto hereby submit to the jurisdiction applicable of the Courts of the said Territory and the Commonwealth of Australia in respect of all matters arising hereunder or relating hereto.

ANSWER.PARA: 13. NOTICES

13.2 A notice or other communication which may be given to or served on the Customer under the Deed shall be deemed to have been duly given or served if it is in writing, signed by or on behalf of the Confidant and is either delivered by hand, posted or a copy transmitted electronically to the Customer at the address set out herein or such other address as may be notified in writing to the Confidant from time to time.

ANSWER.PARA: Interim Code of Practice—Use of e‐mail
1. E‐mail must be used only for work related purposes. E‐mail is a means by which information can be transferred. The e‐mail must not be used for the distribution of junk mail.

PARA.TAB: In the past Staff Bulletins and Newsletters contained information about social club activities and classified advertisements such as "For Sale" notices. With the discontinuation of Staff Bulletins and Newsletters, staff will be able to use the electronic bulletin board to post such notices. However, such notices must not be sent for general distribution by e‐mail.

Use of e‐mail and bulletin boards by unions Union delegates can use e‐mail to communicate between themselves in undertaking DEET related industrial relations work. Communication (by e‐mail) between union delegates and union members must be only through electronic bulletin boards. Nominated union delegates will be provided with write access to enable authorised notices to be broadcast on bulletin boards. Unions are required to comply with this Code.

ANSWER.PARA: 2. E‐mail must not be used for mischievous, offensive or frivolous purposes and must not be used to spread gossip.

PARA.TAB: Staff members using e‐mail must avoid the use of language which may be considered offensive or which may be considered to be harassment, whether based on sex, race or disability.

A staff member using the e‐mail system to spread gossip is leaving him/herself open to an action in defamation. Where a staff member uses e‐mail inappropriately, such as for gossiping, the Department would not meet the officer's legal costs or liabilities. Further if proceedings were brought against the Department for the actions of such an officer the Department may seek to recover its costs and any damages from the officer concerned.
In a recent Western Australia case, damages of $40, 000 were ordered because a defamatory message was written on an electronic bulletin board.

ANSWER.PARA: 3. Staff must comply with obligations under the Privacy Act 1988 and the Information Privacy Principles (IPPs), in particular IPPs 4, 10 and 11.

PARA.TAB: IPP 4 requires the Department to keep information provided to it safe from use, misuse or disclosure to unauthorised persons. IPP 10 states that information obtained for a particular purpose may be used only for that purpose unless specific exemptions apply. Similarly, under IPP 11, information can be disclosed to third parties only if there has been consent to the disclosure or limited exceptions apply. The Privacy Act applies to all personal information whether it is true or not and whether it is client or staff information.

ANSWER.PARA: Attachment F/2

4. E‐mail messages should contain only information that a staff member would be prepared to write in a formal minute. Staff should be wary of responding to an e‐mail message in the heat of the moment where the response might later lead to misinterpretations of messages.

5. Staff should send an e‐mail message only to a person to whom they would write a minute. The usual protocols over who would sign a minute to another person in the Department continue to apply. A person sending e‐mail must identify his/her title in the organisation.

6. E‐mail should be used to send a message to staff only if the person(s) need(s) to know that information. Written minutes are often copied to other persons in the Department who need to know the progress of an issue. With e‐mail, staff should copy e‐mail only to those persons who have a genuine need to know that information.
7. The e‐mail system is not to be used as a filing system. Staff are responsible for reading and deleting mail. If an e‐mail message is required, it should be printed and filed.

PARA.TAB: E‐mail users should retain on e‐mail only those documents that are necessary for current use.

ANSWER.PARA: 8. E‐mail must not be used to send classified or sensitive information. Separate arrangements are being finalised for the use of e‐mail to send classified or sensitive information.

9. Documents addressed to the Ministers or the Parliamentary Secretary must be sent through the Parliamentary Liaison Section. Communications with staff in the Offices of the Ministers or Parliamentary Secretary may be sent by e‐mail.

10. Senders of e‐mail messages should always be aware that they have no control over the use of the message by a recipient of the message. Receivers of e‐mail must respect the integrity of messages sent to them.
11. Where information is provided by e‐mail the recipient must still satisfy him or herself that the information is accurate.

12. Staff are reminded that computer software and hardware (including disks) are the property of the Department. An officer nominated by the Secretary may, at any time, access and examine documents or files contained on the hard disk, the file server or floppy disks and, if necessary, remove files or documents.

13. E‐mail must not be used to download or transmit computer programs (including games). Where there is a work related need to send such files, arrangements for the transfer must be made through the Local Information Technology Unit.
